Section 156(3) Cr.P.C. - Police Officer's power to investigate cognizable cases.
judgment: The High Court allowed the petition, setting aside the Magistrate's order. It held that the Magistrate must record specific reasons for satisfaction before directing an investigation under Section 156(3) Cr.P.C. and that a general reference without application of mind or specific reasons is not permissible.

judgment: The High Court dismissed the criminal petition for anticipatory bail, considering the serious nature of the allegations. However, the petitioner was directed to surrender before the trial court, and their bail application, if filed, was to be disposed of within two working days.

question: What did the High Court decide regarding To declare the continuation of the LOC despite bail as illegal and violative of Article 21, and to set aside the LOC, and to direct the authorities to provide a copy of the LOC. under Article 226 of the Constitution of India (for writ of Mandamus and Declaration), Article 21 of the Constitution of India (Right to Life and Personal Liberty), Guideline No. 6(N)(v) of the office Memorandum dated 22-02-2021. The case pertains to the conditions under which an LOC can be issued and maintained, especially post-bail.?
facts: The petitioner was granted bail in a criminal case. However, a Look Out Circular (LOC) was continued against him, restricting his travel abroad. He was also stopped at immigration and not provided a copy of the LOC.
charge: To declare the continuation of the LOC despite bail as illegal and violative of Article 21, and to set aside the LOC, and to direct the authorities to provide a copy of the LOC.
law: Constitution of India, Code of Criminal Procedure (Cr.PC)

The case pertains to the conditions under which an LOC can be issued and maintained, especially post-bail.
judgment: The writ petition sought an appropriate writ or direction to declare the action of the respondents in continuing a Look Out Circular (LOC) against the petitioner, despite his being granted bail, as illegal and violative of Article 21. The petitioner also sought a declaration that the failure to provide a copy of the LOC at immigration was arbitrary.

facts: The petitioner, accused No. 3, sought anticipatory bail under Section 438 of Cr.P.C. in connection with Crime No.63 of 2016, registered for offences under Section 302 r/w 34 of IPC. The case had been initially closed as a suicidal death but was reopened for fresh investigation by CB-CID.

judgment: The Investigating Officer is directed to strictly follow Section 41-A Cr.P.C. and the guidelines in Arnesh Kumar v. State of Bihar, directing the officer to enlarge the petitioner on bail in the event of his arrest, provided the petitioner cooperates with the investigation.

question: What did the High Court decide regarding Quashing of FIR and proceedings or stay of arrest in a case registered under Sections 420, 406, 409 IPC and Section 7 of Essential Commodities Act. under Section 482 Cr.P.C. - Powers of the High Court to pass any order necessary to secure the ends of justice, including quashing of proceedings. Section 41-A Cr.P.C. - Procedure to be followed by police officers for arrest. Guidelines from Arnesh Kumar v. State of Bihar for arrest.?
facts: The petitioner, accused no. 7 in Crime No. 167/2023 registered under Sections 420, 406, 409 IPC and Section 7 of Essential Commodities Act, approached the High Court seeking to quash the proceedings or stay further proceedings including arrest. The FIR was registered based on a complaint, and the petitioner claimed to have been intentionally dragged into the case without valid reasons. Initially, the petitioner's name was not in the FIR or added by the investigating authority.
charge: Quashing of FIR and proceedings or stay of arrest in a case registered under Sections 420, 406, 409 IPC and Section 7 of Essential Commodities Act.
law_content: Section 482 Cr.P.C. - Powers of the High Court to pass any order necessary to secure the ends of justice, including quashing of proceedings. Section 41-A Cr.P.C. - Procedure to be followed by police officers for arrest. Guidelines from Arnesh Kumar v. State of Bihar for arrest.
judgment: The High Court, considering that the punishment prescribed for the alleged offences is less than seven years, directed the petitioner to appear before the Investigating Officer on a specific date and time. The Investigating Officer was directed to follow the procedure under Section 41-A Cr.P.C. and the guidelines from Arnesh Kumar v. State of Bihar. The petitioner was also directed to cooperate with the investigation. The Court clarified that Section 409 IPC might not be applicable to the petitioner. The criminal petition was disposed of.

question: What did the High Court decide regarding Seeking a writ of mandamus to direct the Regional Passport Officer to process and renew the petitioner's passport, despite a pending criminal case and chargesheet. under Article 226 of the Constitution of India - empowers High Courts to issue writs for the enforcement of fundamental rights and for other purposes. Sections 420, 423, 468, 471 IPC - deal with cheating, fraudulent deeds, forgery, and using forged documents as genuine, respectively. Section 120(B) IPC - relates to criminal conspiracy.?
facts: The petitioner applied for the renewal of his passport. The Regional Passport Officer refused to process the application citing an FIR registered against the petitioner under various sections of the IPC, including cheating and forgery, and a pending criminal case based on the chargesheet filed in that FIR. The petitioner argued that the case was falsely foisted upon him and sought the renewal of his passport, contending that the denial was arbitrary.
charge: Seeking a writ of mandamus to direct the Regional Passport Officer to process and renew the petitioner's passport, despite a pending criminal case and chargesheet.
law: Constitution of India, Indian Penal Code (IPC)
law_content: Article 226 of the Constitution of India - empowers High Courts to issue writs for the enforcement of fundamental rights and for other purposes. Sections 420, 423, 468, 471 IPC - deal with cheating, fraudulent deeds, forgery, and using forged documents as genuine, respectively. Section 120(B) IPC - relates to criminal conspiracy.
judgment: The court directed the passport authorities to process the renewal of the petitioner's passport without prejudice to the pending criminal proceedings. The court observed that a passport can be impounded or revoked under Section 10(3)(e) of the Passport Act, 1967, only if the passport holder has, in the opinion of the central government, committed an offence or been convicted of an offence involving moral turpitude. Since the petitioner's conviction had not yet been established and the case was pending trial, the passport authorities were directed to consider the renewal application.

question: What did the High Court decide regarding Quashing of proceedings in D.V.C. No. 20 of 2023 and stay of further proceedings. under Section 482 Cr.P.C. - This section empowers the High Court to make orders to prevent abuse of process or secure ends of justice. Protection of Domestic Violence Act, 2005 - The Act provides remedies for domestic violence. The judgment cites a precedent (Gaddameedi Srinivas vs. State of Telangana) stating that an appeal against the act of taking cognizance and numbering of a D.V.C. is not maintainable, and the Act itself affords an efficacious remedy.?
facts: The petitioners filed a criminal petition under Section 482 of the Code of Criminal Procedure seeking to quash proceedings in D.V.C. No. 20 of 2023, pending before the Principal Junior Civil Judge-cum-Judicial Magistrate of First Class, Medak. They also sought to stay further proceedings, including their appearance. The case relates to alleged acts under the Protection of Domestic Violence Act, 2005.
charge: Quashing of proceedings in D.V.C. No. 20 of 2023 and stay of further proceedings.
law: Code of Criminal Procedure, 1973; Protection of Domestic Violence Act, 2005
law_content: Section 482 Cr.P.C. - This section empowers the High Court to make orders to prevent abuse of process or secure ends of justice. Protection of Domestic Violence Act, 2005 - The Act provides remedies for domestic violence. The judgment cites a precedent (Gaddameedi Srinivas vs. State of Telangana) stating that an appeal against the act of taking cognizance and numbering of a D.V.C. is not maintainable, and the Act itself affords an efficacious remedy.
judgment: The Court observed that the judgment in Gaddameedi Srinivas vs. State of Telangana implies that a petition to quash proceedings under the Protection of Domestic Violence Act, 2005 is not maintainable as the Act itself provides an efficacious remedy. Therefore, the petitioners were granted liberty to avail the said alternative remedy. The appearance of the petitioners in the D.V.C. was dispensed with, except when their presence is required by the trial court. The criminal petition was disposed of accordingly.

facts: The petitioner is accused of provoking other accused via mobile phone to kill the deceased. The incident involved a quarrel between political party activists, leading to a death. The petitioner claims he was not present at the scene of the alleged attack.
charge: Seeking anticipatory bail under Section 438 of Cr.P.C. for offences under Sections 302, 341, and 506 read with Section 34 of IPC.
law_content: Section 438 Cr.P.C. deals with the provisions for anticipatory bail, allowing a person to seek bail in anticipation of arrest.
judgment: The Court granted anticipatory bail to the petitioner, directing him to surrender and furnish a personal bond with sureties, and to cooperate with the investigation.

instruction: Summarize the facts, legal issue, provisions applied, and the High Court’s decision.
question: What did the High Court decide regarding The petitioner sought to quash the FIR registered against him for alleged offences. under Section 482 Cr.P.C. - Saving of inherent powers of High Court. This section saves the inherent powers of the High Court to make such orders as may be necessary to give effect to any order under the Code, or to prevent abuse of the process of any Court or otherwise to secure the ends of justice.?
facts: The petitioner, Mohammed Khadeer, filed a criminal petition under Section 482 of Cr.P.C. seeking to quash the proceedings in FIR No. 704 of 2023, registered at Abdullapurmet Police Station. The petition also sought interim stay of further proceedings, including arrest, and release of seized livestock.
charge: The petitioner sought to quash the FIR registered against him for alleged offences.
law_content: Section 482 Cr.P.C. - Saving of inherent powers of High Court. This section saves the inherent powers of the High Court to make such orders as may be necessary to give effect to any order under the Code, or to prevent abuse of the process of any Court or otherwise to secure the ends of justice.
judgment: The learned counsel for the petitioner sought permission to withdraw the criminal petition with liberty to challenge the charge sheet. Permission was granted, and accordingly, the criminal petition was dismissed as withdrawn.

instruction: Summarize the facts, legal issue, provisions applied, and the High Court’s decision.
question: What did the High Court decide regarding The petitioners sought to quash the FIR and subsequent proceedings for alleged offences under Sections 447, 427, 353 r/w 34 of the Indian Penal Code. under Section 482 Cr.P.C. - Saving of inherent powers of High Court. This section allows the High Court to make orders to prevent abuse of process or secure ends of justice. Sections 447, 427, 353 r/w 34 IPC relate to criminal trespass, mischief causing damage, assault or criminal force to deter public servant from discharge of duty, and common intention respectively.?
facts: The petitioners, Surimilla Ranjith and Surimilla Bharath, filed a criminal petition under Section 482 of Cr.P.C. seeking to quash the proceedings in FIR No. 310 of 2023, registered at CCC Naspur Police Station for offences under Sections 447, 427, 353 r/w 34 IPC. They also sought an interim stay of proceedings and to dispense with the filing of the certified copy of the FIR.
charge: The petitioners sought to quash the FIR and subsequent proceedings for alleged offences under Sections 447, 427, 353 r/w 34 of the Indian Penal Code.
law: Code of Criminal Procedure, 1973 and Indian Penal Code, 1860
law_content: Section 482 Cr.P.C. - Saving of inherent powers of High Court. This section allows the High Court to make orders to prevent abuse of process or secure ends of justice. Sections 447, 427, 353 r/w 34 IPC relate to criminal trespass, mischief causing damage, assault or criminal force to deter public servant from discharge of duty, and common intention respectively.
judgment: The Court directed that the petitioners shall cooperate with the investigation and produce relevant documents. The Investigating Officer was directed to consider the documents before filing a report, and the police were directed not to take any coercive steps against the petitioners until the investigation is completed. The criminal petition was disposed of accordingly.

instruction: Summarize the facts, legal issue, provisions applied, and the High Court’s decision.
question: What did the High Court decide regarding To quash the proceedings in D.V.C. No. 1 of 2023 filed under Section 12 of the Protection of Women from Domestic Violence Act, 2005, or to dispense with the personal presence of the petitioner. under Section 482 Cr.P.C.: Saving of inherent powers of High Court. Section 12 of the Protection of Women from Domestic Violence Act, 2005: Procedure to be followed by Magistrate.?
facts: The petitioner, a CRPF Constable working in Madhya Pradesh, filed a criminal petition under Section 482 of Cr.P.C. seeking to dispense with his personal attendance in D.V.C. proceedings due to the difficulties in availing leave and attending court dates in Telangana.
charge: To quash the proceedings in D.V.C. No. 1 of 2023 filed under Section 12 of the Protection of Women from Domestic Violence Act, 2005, or to dispense with the personal presence of the petitioner.
law: Code of Criminal Procedure, 1973 and Protection of Women from Domestic Violence Act, 2005
law_content: Section 482 Cr.P.C.: Saving of inherent powers of High Court. Section 12 of the Protection of Women from Domestic Violence Act, 2005: Procedure to be followed by Magistrate.
judgment: The High Court disposed of the criminal petition by dispensing with the petitioner's attendance, subject to conditions including filing an affidavit and appearing when specifically required by the Magistrate.

instruction: Summarize the facts, legal issue, provisions applied, and the High Court’s decision.
question: What did the High Court decide regarding Offence under Section 138 of the Negotiable Instruments Act, 1881. under Section 138 NI Act: Deals with the penal consequences for dishonour of a cheque for insufficiency of funds to draw the amount, or when the amount exceeds the arrangement made with the bank. It requires the cheque to be presented within its validity period, returned unpaid, and notice to be given to the drawer, followed by failure to pay within 15 days of receipt of notice.?
facts: The appellant filed a criminal complaint against the respondent for an offence under Section 138 of the Negotiable Instruments Act, 1881, alleging that a cheque issued for a property transaction was dishonored due to a stop payment instruction. The trial court acquitted the accused, finding that since the complainant failed to deliver vacant possession of the property, there was no legally enforceable debt.
charge: Offence under Section 138 of the Negotiable Instruments Act, 1881.
law_content: Section 138 NI Act: Deals with the penal consequences for dishonour of a cheque for insufficiency of funds to draw the amount, or when the amount exceeds the arrangement made with the bank. It requires the cheque to be presented within its validity period, returned unpaid, and notice to be given to the drawer, followed by failure to pay within 15 days of receipt of notice.
judgment: The appeal is dismissed. The trial court's finding that there was no legally enforceable debt due to non-delivery of vacant possession of the property, and thus the accused was not guilty under Section 138 of the NI Act, is upheld.

instruction: Summarize the facts, legal issue, provisions applied, and the High Court’s decision.
question: What did the High Court decide regarding Seeking registration of FIR for offences under Sections 442, 422, 323 and 506 of IPC based on a complaint. under Section 154 CrPC: Mandates the procedure for recording information relating to the commission of a cognizable offence. Lalita Kumari v. Government of U.P. (2014): Supreme Court guidelines stipulating that registration of FIR is mandatory upon receiving information disclosing a cognizable offence, with limited exceptions.?
facts: The petitioner lodged a complaint alleging cognizable offences against respondents 4 to 7. The petitioner's grievance was that the police station (respondent No.3) had not registered an FIR despite the complaint disclosing cognizable offences, and in contravention of the guidelines in Lalita Kumari v. Government of U.P. The police, however, submitted that they had registered a case based on the complaint.
charge: Seeking registration of FIR for offences under Sections 442, 422, 323 and 506 of IPC based on a complaint.
law: Code of Criminal Procedure (CrPC), Constitution of India
law_content: Section 154 CrPC: Mandates the procedure for recording information relating to the commission of a cognizable offence. Lalita Kumari v. Government of U.P. (2014): Supreme Court guidelines stipulating that registration of FIR is mandatory upon receiving information disclosing a cognizable offence, with limited exceptions.
judgment: The writ petition is closed as the grievance of the petitioner has been redressed. The police have registered a case (Crime No. 16 of 2024) for offences under Sections 442, 422, 323 and 506 IPC, thus complying with the complaint's requirements.

instruction: Summarize the facts, legal issue, provisions applied, and the High Court’s decision.
question: What did the High Court decide regarding Quashing of criminal proceedings under Sections 406, 420, 447, 427, and 506 r/w 34 of the Indian Penal Code. under Section 482 of the Cr.P.C. grants inherent powers to the High Court to make such orders as may be necessary to give effect to any order under the Code, or to prevent abuse of the process of any Court or otherwise to secure the ends of justice. Sections 406, 420, 447, 427, and 506 of the IPC deal with criminal breach of trust, cheating, criminal trespass, mischief, and criminal intimidation respectively.?
facts: The petitioner, an accused in a criminal case, seeks to quash proceedings based on allegations of land trespassing and cheating. The dispute arose from a sale deed where the survey number of the property was allegedly misrepresented. The petitioner claims their land is in the correct survey number as per revenue records and sale deeds, and the complaint was lodged after a significant delay.
charge: Quashing of criminal proceedings under Sections 406, 420, 447, 427, and 506 r/w 34 of the Indian Penal Code.
law: Code of Criminal Procedure, Section 482, Indian Penal Code, Sections 406, 420, 447, 427, 506
law_content: Section 482 of the Cr.P.C. grants inherent powers to the High Court to make such orders as may be necessary to give effect to any order under the Code, or to prevent abuse of the process of any Court or otherwise to secure the ends of justice. Sections 406, 420, 447, 427, and 506 of the IPC deal with criminal breach of trust, cheating, criminal trespass, mischief, and criminal intimidation respectively.
judgment: The Criminal Petition was allowed, leading to the quashing of proceedings. This indicates the court found the dispute to be primarily civil and that the criminal proceedings were an abuse of process or lacked the necessary ingredients for the alleged criminal offenses.

instruction: Summarize the facts, legal issue, provisions applied, and the High Court’s decision.
question: What did the High Court decide regarding To direct Respondent No. 4 (Station House Officer) to register the petitioner's complaint. under Section 154(3) of Cr.P.C mandates the police to register a cognizable offense upon receiving information. Section 200 of Cr.P.C provides for the procedure to be followed when a private complaint is filed before a Magistrate. IPC Sections 448 (punishment for house-trespass), 427 (mischief causing damage), and 506 (punishment for criminal intimidation) are relevant to the alleged offenses.?
facts: The petitioner filed a writ petition seeking a direction to the police to register his complaint, alleging that his complaint was not registered despite written complaints submitted to the police. The police stated that a complaint by the petitioner's sister-in-law, covering similar facts, had already led to the registration of a crime under Sections 448, 427, and 506 IPC.
charge: To direct Respondent No. 4 (Station House Officer) to register the petitioner's complaint.
law: Article 226 of the Constitution of India; Section 151 CPC; Section 154 (3) of Cr.P.C; Section 200 of Cr.P.C; Indian Penal Code (IPC) Sections 448, 427, 506.
law_content: Section 154(3) of Cr.P.C mandates the police to register a cognizable offense upon receiving information. Section 200 of Cr.P.C provides for the procedure to be followed when a private complaint is filed before a Magistrate. IPC Sections 448 (punishment for house-trespass), 427 (mischief causing damage), and 506 (punishment for criminal intimidation) are relevant to the alleged offenses.
judgment: The High Court observed that the petitioner's complaint contained similar allegations to that of his sister-in-law, which had already resulted in a registered FIR. While acknowledging the slight differences in allegations, the court found it appropriate to dispose of the writ petition by granting liberty to the petitioner to file a private complaint under Section 200 of Cr.P.C before the concerned Magistrate. The court noted that the Station House Officer had already acted on a complaint concerning the same set of facts.

instruction: Summarize the facts, legal issue, provisions applied, and the High Court’s decision.
question: What did the High Court decide regarding Extension of time to comply with bail conditions. under Section 482 Cr.PC (Inherent powers of the High Court) likely invoked for the bail petition, and procedural rules for compliance with court orders.?
facts: The petitioners filed an application seeking an extension of time to comply with the bail conditions previously imposed by the court in Crl.P.No.120 of 2024. The original conditions required them to surrender and furnish bail bonds with sureties, which they were unable to fulfill due to financial constraints. The deadline for compliance was approaching.
charge: Extension of time to comply with bail conditions.
law_content: Section 482 Cr.PC (Inherent powers of the High Court) likely invoked for the bail petition, and procedural rules for compliance with court orders.
judgment: The court granted the extension, allowing the petitioners 15 days from the date of receipt of the order to comply with the modified bail conditions.

instruction: Summarize the facts, legal issue, provisions applied, and the High Court’s decision.
question: What did the High Court decide regarding Quashing of criminal proceedings. under Section 482 Cr.PC, which pertains to the inherent powers of the High Court to make such orders as may be necessary to give effect to any order under this Code, or to prevent abuse of the process of any Court or otherwise to secure the ends of justice.?
facts: The petitioners, who are accused parties (A.1 to A.5), filed a criminal petition seeking to quash the proceedings against them in C.C.No.5 of 2018 pending before the First Additional Judicial First Class Magistrate at Kothagudem. The charge sheet in this case was filed in 2018.
charge: Quashing of criminal proceedings.
law_content: Section 482 Cr.PC, which pertains to the inherent powers of the High Court to make such orders as may be necessary to give effect to any order under this Code, or to prevent abuse of the process of any Court or otherwise to secure the ends of justice.
judgment: The court directed the trial court to conclude the trial within six weeks from the date of receiving a copy of the order, as the contentions raised required factual verification. The appearance of petitioners 2 to 5 was dispensed with unless specifically required.

instruction: Summarize the facts, legal issue, provisions applied, and the High Court’s decision.
question: What did the High Court decide regarding Quashing of proceedings in DVC No. 64 of 2023. under Section 482 of CrPC allows the High Court to make orders to secure the ends of justice, including quashing proceedings. Section 29 of the Protection of Women from Domestic Violence Act, 2005, provides an alternative remedy of appeal against orders taking cognizance.?
facts: The petitioners filed a criminal petition under Section 482 of the CrPC seeking to quash proceedings in a Domestic Violence Case (DVC) filed against them. The respondent No. 2 is the defacto complainant. The respondent No. 1 is the State.
charge: Quashing of proceedings in DVC No. 64 of 2023.
law: Section 482 of CrPC, Protection of Women from Domestic Violence Act, 2005
law_content: Section 482 of CrPC allows the High Court to make orders to secure the ends of justice, including quashing proceedings. Section 29 of the Protection of Women from Domestic Violence Act, 2005, provides an alternative remedy of appeal against orders taking cognizance.
judgment: The High Court held that a petition to quash proceedings in a Domestic Violence Case is not maintainable under Section 482 CrPC, as Section 29 of the Domestic Violence Act provides an efficacious remedy of appeal. The petitioners were granted liberty to avail the appellate remedy. The appearance of petitioners No. 2 to 7 was dispensed with except when required by the trial court.

instruction: Summarize the facts, legal issue, provisions applied, and the High Court’s decision.
question: What did the High Court decide regarding Quashing of FIR and stay of arrest under Sections 420, 465, 471 r/w 34 IPC. under Section 482 Cr.P.C. allows the High Court to quash proceedings in certain circumstances. Sections 420, 465, 471 IPC relate to cheating, forgery of valuable security, and using a forged document as genuine, respectively. Section 34 IPC deals with acts done by several persons in furtherance of common intention. Section 41-A Cr.P.C. relates to notice of appearance before a police officer.?
facts: The petitioners are accused of offences under Sections 420, 465, and 471 read with Section 34 of the Indian Penal Code (IPC). They filed a criminal petition seeking to quash the proceedings and stay their arrest in FIR No. 408 of 2023.
charge: Quashing of FIR and stay of arrest under Sections 420, 465, 471 r/w 34 IPC.
law: Code of Criminal Procedure (Cr.P.C.), Indian Penal Code (IPC)
law_content: Section 482 Cr.P.C. allows the High Court to quash proceedings in certain circumstances. Sections 420, 465, 471 IPC relate to cheating, forgery of valuable security, and using a forged document as genuine, respectively. Section 34 IPC deals with acts done by several persons in furtherance of common intention. Section 41-A Cr.P.C. relates to notice of appearance before a police officer.
judgment: The court directed the petitioners to appear before the investigating officer and ordered the officer to follow the procedure under Section 41-A Cr.P.C. and the guidelines from Arnesh Kumar v. State of Bihar. No arrest or coercive steps were to be taken until the investigation is completed and a decision is made on documents filed by the petitioners.

instruction: Summarize the facts, legal issue, provisions applied, and the High Court’s decision.
question: What did the High Court decide regarding Quashing of FIR and stay of arrest under Sections 353, 504 r/w 34 IPC. under Section 482 Cr.P.C. empowers the High Court to quash proceedings in specific situations. Sections 353 IPC deals with assault or criminal force to deter a public servant from discharging his duty, and Section 504 IPC relates to intentional insult with intent to provoke a breach of the peace. Section 34 IPC pertains to acts done in furtherance of common intention.?
facts: The petitioner is accused of offences under Sections 353 and 504 read with Section 34 of the IPC. They filed a criminal petition seeking to quash the proceedings and stay their arrest in FIR No. 389 of 2023.
charge: Quashing of FIR and stay of arrest under Sections 353, 504 r/w 34 IPC.
law: Code of Criminal Procedure (Cr.P.C.), Indian Penal Code (IPC)
law_content: Section 482 Cr.P.C. empowers the High Court to quash proceedings in specific situations. Sections 353 IPC deals with assault or criminal force to deter a public servant from discharging his duty, and Section 504 IPC relates to intentional insult with intent to provoke a breach of the peace. Section 34 IPC pertains to acts done in furtherance of common intention.
judgment: The court directed the petitioner to appear before the investigating officer and instructed the officer to follow the procedure under Section 41-A Cr.P.C. and the guidelines from Arnesh Kumar v. State of Bihar. The court also ordered that no arrest or coercive steps should be taken against the petitioner until the investigation is completed and a decision is made on the documents submitted by the petitioner.

instruction: Summarize the facts, legal issue, provisions applied, and the High Court’s decision.
question: What did the High Court decide regarding Withdrawal of Criminal Revision Case. under Sections 397 and 401 of the Cr.P.C. allow the High Court to call for records and examine proceedings and powers of revision. The general principles of procedural law allow for the withdrawal of cases by the petitioner.?
facts: The petitioner filed a criminal revision case under Sections 397 and 401 of the Cr.P.C. against an order dated 08.11.2023 made in CRL.MP.No.4731 of 2023 in Cr.No.272 of 2023. The petitioner later sought permission to withdraw the revision case.
charge: Withdrawal of Criminal Revision Case.
law_content: Sections 397 and 401 of the Cr.P.C. allow the High Court to call for records and examine proceedings and powers of revision. The general principles of procedural law allow for the withdrawal of cases by the petitioner.
judgment: The court granted the petitioner's request to withdraw the criminal revision case, and accordingly, the case was dismissed as withdrawn.

instruction: Summarize the facts, legal issue, provisions applied, and the High Court’s decision.
question: What did the High Court decide regarding Quashing of proceedings in DVC No. 17 of 2023 and dispensing with personal appearance. under Section 482 Cr.P.C. allows the High Court to pass any order for the purpose of securing the ends of justice, but this power is not absolute. Section 29 of the Protection of Women from Domestic Violence Act, 2005 provides an alternative remedy of appeal against orders taking cognizance.?
facts: The petitioner filed a criminal petition under Section 482 of Cr.P.C. seeking to quash proceedings in a Domestic Violence Case (DVC No. 17 of 2023) filed under the Protection of Women from Domestic Violence Act, 2005. The petitioner also sought to dispense with their personal appearance in the said DVC.
charge: Quashing of proceedings in DVC No. 17 of 2023 and dispensing with personal appearance.
law: Code of Criminal Procedure, 1973; Protection of Women from Domestic Violence Act, 2005
law_content: Section 482 Cr.P.C. allows the High Court to pass any order for the purpose of securing the ends of justice, but this power is not absolute. Section 29 of the Protection of Women from Domestic Violence Act, 2005 provides an alternative remedy of appeal against orders taking cognizance.
judgment: The High Court held that a petition to quash proceedings in a Domestic Violence Case is not maintainable under Section 482 Cr.P.C. if an appeal remedy is available under Section 29 of the DV Act. The petitioner was granted liberty to avail the alternative remedy of appeal. However, the petitioner's personal appearance in the DVC was dispensed with, except when required by the trial court.

Section 29 of the Protection of Women from Domestic Violence Act, 2005 provides an alternative remedy of appeal against orders taking cognizance.?
facts: The petitioner filed a criminal petition under Section 482 of Cr.P.C. seeking to quash proceedings in a Domestic Violence Case (DVC No. 17 of 2023) filed under the Protection of Women from Domestic Violence Act, 2005. The petitioner also sought to dispense with their personal appearance in the said DVC.
charge: Quashing of proceedings in DVC No. 17 of 2023 and dispensing with personal appearance.

law_content: Section 482 Cr.P.C. allows the High Court to pass any order for the purpose of securing the ends of justice, but this power is not absolute. Section 29 of the Protection of Women from Domestic Violence Act, 2005 provides an alternative remedy of appeal against orders taking cognizance.
judgment: The High Court held that a petition to quash proceedings in a Domestic Violence Case is not maintainable under Section 482 Cr.P.C. if an appeal remedy is available under Section 29 of the DV Act. The petitioner was granted liberty to avail the alternative remedy of appeal. However, the petitioner's personal appearance in the DVC was dispensed with, except when required by the trial court.

question: What did the High Court decide regarding Quashing of FIR in crime No. 275 of 2023 registered under Sections 420, 406, and 506 of IPC. under Section 482 of the Cr.P.C. allows the High Court to quash proceedings in certain circumstances. Sections 420 (cheating), 406 (criminal breach of trust), and 506 (criminal intimidation) of the IPC define the alleged offences.?
facts: The petitioners are accused in FIR in crime No. 275 of 2023, registered at PS Khammam Town for alleged offences under Sections 420, 406, and 506 of the IPC. They have filed a criminal petition seeking to quash the proceedings.
charge: Quashing of FIR in crime No. 275 of 2023 registered under Sections 420, 406, and 506 of IPC.
law_content: Section 482 of the Cr.P.C. allows the High Court to quash proceedings in certain circumstances. Sections 420 (cheating), 406 (criminal breach of trust), and 506 (criminal intimidation) of the IPC define the alleged offences.
judgment: The criminal petition was dismissed as infructuous because the charge sheet had not been filed. The court granted the petitioners liberty to move a fresh petition if the cause subsists.

instruction: Summarize the facts, legal issue, provisions applied, and the High Court’s decision.
question: What did the High Court decide regarding Cancellation of bail granted to accused persons. under Section 439(2) Cr.P.C. relates to the power of the High Court or Court of Session to cancel bail.?
facts: The State filed petitions under Section 439(2) of Cr.P.C. to cancel the bail granted to accused persons in a criminal case. During the hearing, the State's counsel reported that the trial had been completed, making the bail cancellation petition infructuous.
charge: Cancellation of bail granted to accused persons.
law_content: Section 439(2) Cr.P.C. relates to the power of the High Court or Court of Session to cancel bail.
judgment: The criminal petitions filed by the State seeking cancellation of bail were dismissed as infructuous because the trial had already been completed.

question: What did the High Court decide regarding Seeking regular bail for Accused No.4 in an alleged murder case (Section 302 r/w 34 IPC). under Sections 437 and 439 of Cr.P.C. which deal with the grant of bail.?
facts: The petitioner, accused no.4, sought regular bail in a criminal case where the investigation was complete and charge sheet had been filed. The prosecution alleged that the petitioner and seven others attacked the deceased, leading to his death. Accused 1, 2, and 3 had already been granted bail.
charge: Seeking regular bail for Accused No.4 in an alleged murder case (Section 302 r/w 34 IPC).
law_content: Sections 437 and 439 of Cr.P.C. which deal with the grant of bail.
judgment: The High Court granted regular bail to the petitioner/Accused No.4, subject to specific conditions regarding personal bond, sureties, and appearance in court.

question: What did the High Court decide regarding Direction to register a crime and quash proceedings. under Section 154 of Cr.P.C. - Procedure for registration of information relating to the commission of a cognizable offence.?
facts: The petitioner filed a writ petition seeking a direction to register a crime based on a complaint alleging cognizable offenses. The petitioner contended that the 3rd respondent (Station House Officer) failed to register a crime against respondents 4 and 5, despite the complaint disclosing cognizable offenses. The petitioner also sought to declare the inaction of the respondents as illegal and arbitrary.
charge: Direction to register a crime and quash proceedings.
law_content: Section 154 of Cr.P.C. - Procedure for registration of information relating to the commission of a cognizable offence.
judgment: The writ petition was dismissed for non-prosecution as the petitioner did not appear before the court on multiple occasions, including when the matter was listed for dismissal.

instruction: Summarize the facts, legal issue, provisions applied, and the High Court’s decision.
question: What did the High Court decide regarding Transfer of maintenance case. under Section 407 of Cr.P.C. - Procedure for transfer of criminal cases. Sections 498-A and 406 of IPC - Relating to cruelty by husband or relatives and criminal breach of trust.?
facts: The petitioner (husband) filed a petition seeking to transfer a maintenance case (M.C.No.3 of 2023) from the Family Court at Sangareddy to the Family Court at Ranga Reddy District. The wife had previously filed for divorce, and later a maintenance case was filed in Sangareddy. The husband also highlighted that the wife had lodged a complaint against him under Sections 498-A and 406 of IPC.
charge: Transfer of maintenance case.
law_content: Section 407 of Cr.P.C. - Procedure for transfer of criminal cases. Sections 498-A and 406 of IPC - Relating to cruelty by husband or relatives and criminal breach of trust.
judgment: The petition was allowed, transferring the maintenance case from Sangareddy to the Family Court, Ranga Reddy District, at L.B. Nagar. The court considered the convenience of the parties and the pendency of related matters.

instruction: Summarize the facts, legal issue, provisions applied, and the High Court’s decision.
question: What did the High Court decide regarding Seeking a declaration that the inaction of the respondents in concluding the investigation and filing a chargesheet/final report in FIR No. 30 of 2022 is illegal and arbitrary, and directing them to conclude the investigation. under Article 226 of the Constitution of India (for filing the writ petition), Article 21 of the Constitution of India (for protection of life and personal liberty, including the right to speedy investigation), Sections 406, 415, 417, 419, 494, 495, 506-II read with 34 of IPC (offences for which FIR was registered), Section 156(3) of CrPC (police referring private complaint for investigation).?
facts: The petitioner lodged a complaint alleging fraud, criminal breach of trust, cheating, and bigamy against his wife and her parents. The police registered a case (FIR No. 30 of 2022) under various IPC sections. The petitioner contends that the investigation is not being conducted properly and no chargesheet has been filed for two years.
charge: Seeking a declaration that the inaction of the respondents in concluding the investigation and filing a chargesheet/final report in FIR No. 30 of 2022 is illegal and arbitrary, and directing them to conclude the investigation.
law: Constitution of India, Indian Penal Code (IPC), Code of Criminal Procedure (CrPC)
law_content: Article 226 of the Constitution of India (for filing the writ petition), Article 21 of the Constitution of India (for protection of life and personal liberty, including the right to speedy investigation), Sections 406, 415, 417, 419, 494, 495, 506-II read with 34 of IPC (offences for which FIR was registered), Section 156(3) of CrPC (police referring private complaint for investigation).
judgment: The High Court heard the submissions. The respondent's counsel stated that the complaint was closed due to lack of evidence, but the closure report was not provided to the petitioner. The Court is proceeding with the case.

instruction: Summarize the facts, legal issue, provisions applied, and the High Court’s decision.
question: What did the High Court decide regarding To quash the proceedings initiated under FIR No. 440 of 2023 of Moinabad Police Station. under Section 482 of CrPC (inherent powers of the High Court to quash proceedings), Sections 447, 427, 504, and 506 of IPC (offences related to criminal trespass, mischief, intentional insult, and criminal intimidation). Section 41-A CrPC (procedure of notice of appearance before police officer).?
facts: The petitioner is accused in FIR No. 440 of 2023 for alleged offences under Sections 447, 427, 504, and 506 of the IPC. The petitioner claims to be the lease owner of the property, not the owner, and argues the complaint is baseless.
charge: To quash the proceedings initiated under FIR No. 440 of 2023 of Moinabad Police Station.
law: Code of Criminal Procedure (CrPC), Indian Penal Code (IPC)
law_content: Section 482 of CrPC (inherent powers of the High Court to quash proceedings), Sections 447, 427, 504, and 506 of IPC (offences related to criminal trespass, mischief, intentional insult, and criminal intimidation). Section 41-A CrPC (procedure of notice of appearance before police officer).
judgment: The High Court directed the petitioner/accused to appear before the Investigating Officer on a specified date and time. The Investigating Officer is to follow the procedure under Section 41-A CrPC and the Arnesh Kumar guidelines. No arrest or coercive steps are to be taken against the petitioner until the investigation is completed and a decision is made on the documents submitted by the petitioner. The petition is disposed of with these directions.

instruction: Summarize the facts, legal issue, provisions applied, and the High Court’s decision.
question: What did the High Court decide regarding Quashing of charge sheet filed under Sections 498A and 506 IPC. under Section 482 Cr.P.C. allows the High Court to pass any order necessary to give effect to any order under the Code or to prevent abuse of the process of any Court or otherwise to secure the ends of justice. Sections 498A IPC relates to cruelty by a husband or his relatives, and Section 506 IPC pertains to punishment for criminal intimidation.?
facts: The petitioner, accused No.1, filed a petition under Section 482 Cr.P.C. to quash the charge sheet in C.C.No.950 of 2012, filed under Sections 498A and 506 IPC. The petitioner argued that the de-facto complainant is not in India and that charges against other co-accused were previously quashed. The marriage occurred in 2008, and the petitioner left for the USA shortly after. The respondent filed for divorce in 2012 and remarried, suggesting no substance in the complaint.
charge: Quashing of charge sheet filed under Sections 498A and 506 IPC.

facts: The petitioner is accused in C.C. No. 271 of 2019 for alleged offences under Sections 270, 273, and 353 of IPC and Sections 7(2) r/w 20(2) of the Cigarette and Other Tobacco Products Act, 2003. The petitioner seeks to quash these proceedings.

law_content: Section 482 Cr.P.C. - The High Court has inherent power to make such orders as may be necessary to give effect to any order under this Code, or to prevent abuse of the process of any Court or otherwise to secure the ends of justice. Sections 270, 273, 353 IPC, Sections 7(2) r/w 20(2) COTP Act, 2003.
judgment: The Criminal Petition is allowed, quashing the proceedings in C.C. No. 271 of 2019, in terms of a previous common order passed by the High Court in a similar case. The Investigating Officer is directed to return seized property upon proper identification and verification.

instruction: Summarize the facts, legal issue, provisions applied, and the High Court’s decision.
question: What did the High Court decide regarding Quashing of an order refusing interim custody of passport and seeking directions for its release. under Section 482 of the Code of Criminal Procedure (Cr.P.C.) empowers the High Court to make orders necessary to give effect to any order under the Code or to prevent abuse of the process of any Court or otherwise to secure the ends of justice.?
facts: The petitioner, an accused in a criminal case, sought the release of his passport to travel to Australia for his job. The trial court had dismissed his application, citing the risk of absconding.
charge: Quashing of an order refusing interim custody of passport and seeking directions for its release.
law_content: Section 482 of the Code of Criminal Procedure (Cr.P.C.) empowers the High Court to make orders necessary to give effect to any order under the Code or to prevent abuse of the process of any Court or otherwise to secure the ends of justice.
judgment: The High Court considered the petitioner's submission that he needed to travel for his livelihood and relied on previous judgments. The court noted that the investigation was supposed to be completed within a given time frame and that police authorities cannot seize passports. The petition was seeking quashing of the lower court's order and release of the passport.

question: What did the High Court decide regarding Setting aside of a maintenance order by the appellate court. under Sections 397 and 401 of the Cr.PC were invoked for filing the criminal revision case against the appellate court's order.?
facts: The petitioner (wife) filed a maintenance case against the respondent (husband) after alleging harassment and bigamy. The trial court granted maintenance, which the husband appealed. The appellate court set aside the trial court's order. The wife filed a criminal revision case challenging the appellate court's order.
charge: Setting aside of a maintenance order by the appellate court.
law_content: Sections 397 and 401 of the Cr.PC were invoked for filing the criminal revision case against the appellate court's order.
judgment: The High Court dismissed the criminal revision case as the petitioner's counsel did not appear, despite multiple opportunities. The court noted that it could not dismiss the appeal for non-prosecution without examining the merits, but proceeded to dismiss the revision due to the petitioner's non-appearance.

judgment: The petitioners were directed to appear before the Investigating Officer within 15 days. No further extensions will be granted until they appear.

question: What did the High Court decide regarding Conviction under Section 3(1)(x) of the Scheduled Castes and Scheduled Tribes (Prevention of Atrocities) Act, 1989. under Section 3(1)(x) of the Act pertains to the offence of intentionally insulting or intimidating with intent to humiliate a member of a Scheduled Caste or Scheduled Tribe by calling them by their name, using their hereditarily traditional caste name, or making caste based utterances.?
facts: The appellant was convicted by the Special Judge under Section 3(1)(x) of the Scheduled Castes and Scheduled Tribes (Prevention of Atrocities) Act, 1989. The conviction was based on the allegation that the appellant used derogatory caste-based words against the complainant. The appellant contended that the complainant did not belong to a Scheduled Caste and the words used were not listed in the Act.
charge: Conviction under Section 3(1)(x) of the Scheduled Castes and Scheduled Tribes (Prevention of Atrocities) Act, 1989.
law: The Scheduled Castes and Scheduled Tribes (Prevention of Atrocities) Act, 1989
law_content: Section 3(1)(x) of the Act pertains to the offence of intentionally insulting or intimidating with intent to humiliate a member of a Scheduled Caste or Scheduled Tribe by calling them by their name, using their hereditarily traditional caste name, or making caste based utterances.
judgment: The High Court allowed the criminal appeal. It noted that the provision of Section 3(1)(x) of the Act, as extracted, was not attracted by the allegations made in the complaint. Therefore, the conviction was set aside, and the appellant was acquitted.

question: What did the High Court decide regarding Seeking a direction for the registration of a crime based on a complaint, challenging the inaction of the police. under Section 154 Cr.P.C. mandates the registration of information concerning the commission of a cognizable offense. facts: The petitioners lodged a complaint with the police alleging a cognizable offense against respondents 4 to 6. The police did not register a crime, stating that the matter was a civil dispute. The petitioners sought a writ of mandamus to direct the police to register the FIR.

law_content: Section 154 Cr.P.C. mandates the registration of information concerning the commission of a cognizable offense. Article 21 of the Constitution guarantees the right to life and personal liberty.
judgment: The High Court directed the respondent police to furnish a copy of the closure report to the petitioners. This would enable the petitioners to take appropriate steps as available under the law. The writ petition was disposed of with this direction.

question: What did the High Court decide regarding Seeking direction for the Magistrate to pass orders on the protest petition. under Section 482 Cr.P.C. - Saving of inherent powers of High Court. The High Court can pass orders to secure the ends of justice or prevent abuse of process of any court.?
facts: The petitioner lodged a complaint, leading to a case being registered. The police filed a closure report due to lack of evidence. The petitioner filed a protest petition, but the trial court failed to pass orders, despite the matter being adjourned multiple times and the petitioner submitting requested documents.
charge: Seeking direction for the Magistrate to pass orders on the protest petition.
law_content: Section 482 Cr.P.C. - Saving of inherent powers of High Court. The High Court can pass orders to secure the ends of justice or prevent abuse of process of any court.
judgment: The High Court directed the trial court to pass appropriate orders on the protest petition within fifteen days from the receipt of the order, noting the prolonged delay in passing orders.

facts: The petitioner, accused no.1, filed a criminal petition under Section 482 of Cr.P.C. seeking to quash the proceedings in FIR No.1011 of 2023, registered under Sections 420 and 406 of the Indian Penal Code. The petitioner also sought a stay on further proceedings and arrest.

question: What did the High Court decide regarding Criminal revision against conviction and sentence under Section 138 of the Negotiable Instruments Act. under Section 138 of the Negotiable Instruments Act, 1881 deals with the offense of dishonor of a cheque for insufficiency, etc., of funds in the account.?
facts: The appellant (accused) was convicted under Section 138 of the Negotiable Instruments Act for issuing cheques that bounced due to insufficient funds. The complainant had lent money to the accused, and the cheques were issued towards repayment. The conviction was upheld by the Sessions Court. The accused argued about procedural defects. The complainant passed away during the pendency of the revision.
charge: Criminal revision against conviction and sentence under Section 138 of the Negotiable Instruments Act.
law_content: Section 138 of the Negotiable Instruments Act, 1881 deals with the offense of dishonor of a cheque for insufficiency, etc., of funds in the account.
judgment: The High Court partly allowed the revision. While upholding the conviction, it set aside the sentence of imprisonment due to the accused's age (around 77 years). However, the fine amount was increased to the cheque amount (Rs. 3 lakhs) and was to be paid as compensation to the complainant's legal heirs.

judgment: The court directed that in the event of any crime being registered against the petitioner for offences punishable up to seven years, the police shall follow the procedure laid down under Section 41-A Cr.P.C. and the guidelines in Antesh Kumar v. State of Bihar. The petitioner was also directed to cooperate with the police. The criminal petition was disposed of.

law_content: Section 311 Cr.P.C. - Any Court may recall a witness or examine a witness again, if their evidence appears essential to a just decision. However, this power must be exercised with caution and for strong reasons to meet the ends of justice.
judgment: The High Court allowed the criminal petition, setting aside the trial court's order. It granted the petitioner an opportunity to further cross-examine the witness, emphasizing the need for a fair opportunity for the accused to defend their case.

question: What did the High Court decide regarding Whether the Passport Authority can refuse renewal of a passport solely on the pendency of a criminal case without conviction. under Section 6(2)(f) of the Passports Act, 1967, pertains to refusal of passport if the applicant is facing trial. The judgment also refers to Supreme Court pronouncements on the conditions for refusal, generally requiring conviction within a certain period for offenses involving moral turpitude.?
facts: The petitioner applied for the renewal of their passport. The Regional Passport Officer rejected the renewal on the grounds that the petitioner was an accused in a criminal case (Cr.No.142l2O15 U/s 353, 427, 323, 290 rtw 34 IPC). The petitioner argued that they had not been convicted and that the refusal was contrary to the Passports Act, 1967 and Supreme Court judgments.
charge: Whether the Passport Authority can refuse renewal of a passport solely on the pendency of a criminal case without conviction.
law_content: Section 6(2)(f) of the Passports Act, 1967, pertains to refusal of passport if the applicant is facing trial. The judgment also refers to Supreme Court pronouncements on the conditions for refusal, generally requiring conviction within a certain period for offenses involving moral turpitude.
judgment: The High Court found that the Passport Authority cannot refuse passport renewal solely on the ground of a pending criminal case without conviction, citing relevant provisions and precedents. The court directed the authorities to consider the renewal application.

question: What did the High Court decide regarding Contempt of Court for alleged willful and deliberate violation of a court order directing consideration of a passport application. under Section 12 of the Contempt of Courts Act, 1971, deals with the punishment for contempt. The court examined whether the respondent's actions constituted a willful and deliberate violation of the previous court order.?
facts: The petitioner filed a contempt case alleging willful disobedience of a court order dated 14.11.2022 in W.P.No.41352 of 2022. The previous order had directed the respondent (District Collector) to consider the petitioner's online passport application within eight weeks after providing notice to affected parties. The petitioner claimed they submitted the application, but the respondent did not act on it.
charge: Contempt of Court for alleged willful and deliberate violation of a court order directing consideration of a passport application.
law: Contempt of Courts Act, 1971; Constitution of India
law_content: Section 12 of the Contempt of Courts Act, 1971, deals with the punishment for contempt. The court examined whether the respondent's actions constituted a willful and deliberate violation of the previous court order.
judgment: The High Court found no willful or deliberate violation of the order by the respondent. The court noted that the respondent's inability to comply was due to another pending writ petition and an interim order in that matter. The contempt case was closed, with liberty granted to the petitioner to file a fresh contempt if advised.

Section 3(1)(xii) of the SCs & STs (POA) Act, 1989, addresses offences where a person in a position of authority dominates the will of a woman from a SC/ST community and forces her into sexual intercourse.?
facts: The appellant was convicted for offences under Sections 417, 420 IPC and Section 3(1)(xii) of the SCs & STs (POA) Act, 1989. The victim alleged cheating and refusal to marry after physical intimacy. However, the appellant later married the victim, and a child was born prior to the marriage registration.
charge: Conviction for offences under Sections 417, 420 IPC and Section 3(1)(xii) of SCs & STs (POA) Act, 1989.
law: Indian Penal Code (IPC), The Scheduled Castes and Scheduled Tribes (Prevention of Atrocities) Act, 1989 (SCs & STs POA Act)
law_content: Sections 417 and 420 of the IPC deal with cheating. Section 3(1)(xii) of the SCs & STs (POA) Act, 1989, addresses offences where a person in a position of authority dominates the will of a woman from a SC/ST community and forces her into sexual intercourse.
judgment: The judgment of the trial court was set aside, and the appellant was acquitted. The court held that the ingredients of cheating were not made out as the marriage had taken place, and the elements of Section 3(1)(xii) of the SCs & STs (POA) Act were not proven.
