facts: The petitioner filed an application seeking an extension of time to appear before the trial court. The trial court refused to grant the extension. Consequently, the petitioner filed a criminal petition seeking to quash the order of refusal.
charge: Quashing of the order in Crl.M.P.No. 4746 of 2018 in C-C.No.174 of 2017, refusing extension of time to appear before the trial court.
law_content: Section 482 - Saving of inherent powers of High Court. This section allows the High Court to make such orders as may be necessary to give effect to any order under this Code, or to prevent abuse of the process of any Court or otherwise to secure the ends of justice. This is often used to quash criminal proceedings.
judgment: The Criminal Petition was dismissed as the cause for seeking extension of time to appear in court no longer survived.

instruction: Summarize the facts, legal issue, provisions applied, and the High Court’s decision.
question: What did the High Court decide regarding Seeking to quash FIR and stay arrest. under Section 482 Cr.P.C. - Powers of the High Court to make orders to secure the ends of justice.?
facts: The petitioner, an Assistant Professor, filed a criminal petition seeking to quash proceedings against him in FIR No. 1291 of 2021, registered for alleged offences under Sections 466, 467, 468, 471, 417, 203 read with Section 34 of the IPC. The petitioner also sought a stay on his arrest.
charge: Seeking to quash FIR and stay arrest.
law_content: Section 482 Cr.P.C. - Powers of the High Court to make orders to secure the ends of justice.
judgment: The High Court directed the police not to arrest the petitioner until the investigation is completed, considering his employment as an Assistant Professor. The petitioner was also directed to cooperate with the police for an expeditious investigation.

instruction: Summarize the facts, legal issue, provisions applied, and the High Court’s decision.
question: What did the High Court decide regarding Quashing of proceedings in FIR No.12 of 2023 dated 25.01.2023 registered for the offences punishable under Section 304(A) of the Indian Penal Code. under Section 438 Cr.PC relates to directions required in case of arrest to a person apprehending arrest. Section 304A IPC deals with causing death by negligence, and Section 304 Part II IPC deals with culpable homicide not amounting to murder.?
facts: The petitioner is the owner of a tractor driven by another person who caused an accident resulting in a death. The FIR was initially registered under Section 304A IPC and later altered to Section 304 Part II IPC. The police are attempting to arrest the petitioner, who is the owner of the tractor.
charge: Quashing of proceedings in FIR No.12 of 2023 dated 25.01.2023 registered for the offences punishable under Section 304(A) of the Indian Penal Code.
law: Indian Penal Code (IPC), Section 304A, 304 Part II; Code of Criminal Procedure (Cr.PC), Section 438
law_content: Section 438 Cr.PC relates to directions required in case of arrest to a person apprehending arrest. Section 304A IPC deals with causing death by negligence, and Section 304 Part II IPC deals with culpable homicide not amounting to murder.
judgment: The Court observed that the owner of a vehicle cannot be arrested for the negligent driving of another person to whom the vehicle was handed over, and thus disposed of the criminal petition.

instruction: Summarize the facts, legal issue, provisions applied, and the High Court’s decision.
question: What did the High Court decide regarding Contempt of court for non-compliance with a previous High Court order. under Section 10 to 12 of the Contempt of Courts Act, 1971, deal with the punishment for contempt of court.?
facts: The contempt case was filed for non-compliance with a High Court order concerning the construction of a boundary wall around a Muslim graveyard. The petitioner alleged a violation of the court's order. The respondents, including the Chief Executive Officer of the Waqf Board and the District Collector, were asked to respond.
charge: Contempt of court for non-compliance with a previous High Court order.
law_content: Section 10 to 12 of the Contempt of Courts Act, 1971, deal with the punishment for contempt of court.
judgment: The contempt case was disposed of as the Additional Advocate General submitted that the construction of the boundary wall was completed. The petitioner was given liberty to pursue other remedies if their grievance persisted.

instruction: Summarize the facts, legal issue, provisions applied, and the High Court’s decision.
question: What did the High Court decide regarding Allegation of willful disobedience of court orders under the Contempt of Courts Act, 1971. under Sections 10 to 12 of the Contempt of Courts Act, 1971 deal with the definition, punishment, and procedure related to contempt of court.?
facts: The petitioner filed a Contempt Case alleging that the respondents willfully disobeyed the orders passed by the High Court in a previous Writ Petition (W.P.No.573 of 2013) which directed the disposal of an appeal and maintenance of status quo. The petitioner contended that the respondents took possession of the subject property in violation of the status quo order. The respondents argued that they took possession subsequent to the orders of the appellate authority and that the petitioner's grievance was addressed in a subsequent pending writ petition.
charge: Allegation of willful disobedience of court orders under the Contempt of Courts Act, 1971.
law_content: Sections 10 to 12 of the Contempt of Courts Act, 1971 deal with the definition, punishment, and procedure related to contempt of court.
judgment: The Court found no merit in the contempt case, concluding that the respondents had not violated the court's previous orders. The possession was taken subsequent to the appellate authority's order. The contempt case was closed, with liberty granted to the petitioner to raise all available grounds in the pending writ petition.

instruction: Summarize the facts, legal issue, provisions applied, and the High Court’s decision.
question: What did the High Court decide regarding Issuance of a writ in the nature of Habeas Corpus directing the police to produce the petitioner's husband, who is accused in a criminal case and against whom a non-bailable warrant has been issued but not executed. under Sections 498A and 406 IPC deal with cruelty by husband or relatives and criminal breach of trust, respectively. Sections 4 and 6 of the Dowry Prohibition Act relate to the demand and payment of dowry. Article 226 allows for writs to enforce rights or for other purposes. A Habeas Corpus writ is typically used to challenge illegal detention.?
facts: The petitioner is the wife of Respondent No. 6, and they have matrimonial disputes. The petitioner had lodged a complaint, leading to a charge sheet against Respondent Nos. 6 and 7 under Sections 498A and 406 of IPC and Sections 4 and 6 of the Dowry Prohibition Act. A non-bailable warrant was issued against Respondent No. 6, but the police were not executing it. The petitioner filed a Writ of Habeas Corpus seeking the production of her husband.
charge: Issuance of a writ in the nature of Habeas Corpus directing the police to produce the petitioner's husband, who is accused in a criminal case and against whom a non-bailable warrant has been issued but not executed.
law: Indian Penal Code, Sections 498A, 406; Dowry Prohibition Act, Sections 4, 6; Code of Criminal Procedure; Constitution of India, Article 226
law_content: Sections 498A and 406 IPC deal with cruelty by husband or relatives and criminal breach of trust, respectively. Sections 4 and 6 of the Dowry Prohibition Act relate to the demand and payment of dowry. Article 226 allows for writs to enforce rights or for other purposes. A Habeas Corpus writ is typically used to challenge illegal detention.
judgment: The Writ of Habeas Corpus was dismissed because it is a summary proceeding to determine illegal detention, which is not the case here. The court granted liberty to the petitioner to take steps for the execution of the non-bailable warrant against Respondent No. 6.

instruction: Summarize the facts, legal issue, provisions applied, and the High Court’s decision.
question: What did the High Court decide regarding Conviction under Sections 449 and 302 of the Indian Penal Code. under Section 374(2) CrPC - Appeal against conviction. Section 449 IPC - Punishment for house-trespass in order to commit offence punishable with death. Section 302 IPC - Punishment for murder.?
facts: The appellant was accused of entering the residence of the complainant and brutally attacking two deceased individuals with a knife. The motive was reportedly a rejected advance by the appellant towards one of the deceased. Both victims succumbed to their injuries during treatment. The appellant was apprehended with the murder weapon and other evidence at the scene.
charge: Conviction under Sections 449 and 302 of the Indian Penal Code.
law: Indian Penal Code, 1860; Code of Criminal Procedure, 1973
law_content: Section 374(2) CrPC - Appeal against conviction. Section 449 IPC - Punishment for house-trespass in order to commit offence punishable with death. Section 302 IPC - Punishment for murder.
judgment: The High Court dismissed the appeal, upholding the trial court's judgment of conviction against the appellant for offences under Sections 449 and 302 of the IPC.

instruction: Summarize the facts, legal issue, provisions applied, and the High Court’s decision.
question: What did the High Court decide regarding The petitioner sought release on bail. under Sections 437 & 439 Cr.P.C. – Provisions relating to the grant of bail.?
facts: The petitioner, Perala Hari Hara Krishna, filed a criminal petition seeking bail in S.C. No. 387 of 2023, related to offences under the SCs and STs (POA) Act. The case was being tried by the Special Sessions Judge for Trial of Offences Under SCs and STs (POA) Act.
charge: The petitioner sought release on bail.
law_content: Sections 437 & 439 Cr.P.C. – Provisions relating to the grant of bail.
judgment: The criminal petition was dismissed as withdrawn upon the petitioner's request. No further details regarding the grounds for withdrawal or the court's reasoning are provided beyond the dismissal.

instruction: Summarize the facts, legal issue, provisions applied, and the High Court’s decision.
question: What did the High Court decide regarding Quashing of criminal proceedings initiated under Sections 447, 504, and 506 r/w Section 34 of IPC. under Section 482 Cr.P.C. empowers the High Court to pass orders to secure the ends of justice or prevent abuse of the process of any Court. Sections 447 IPC (Criminal Trespass), 504 IPC (Intentional insult with intent to provoke breach of the peace), and 506 IPC (Punishment for criminal intimidation) are the penal provisions under which the complaint was filed.?
facts: The petitioners filed a criminal petition under Section 482 of the Cr.P.C. to quash proceedings in C.C. No. 918 of 2015. The complaint alleged offences under Sections 447, 504, and 506 r/w Section 34 of the IPC. The dispute arose from an alleged trespass and threat related to ancestral property, for which a civil suit for partition was already filed by one of the petitioners.
charge: Quashing of criminal proceedings initiated under Sections 447, 504, and 506 r/w Section 34 of IPC.
law: Code of Criminal Procedure, 1973; Indian Penal Code, 1860
law_content: Section 482 Cr.P.C. empowers the High Court to pass orders to secure the ends of justice or prevent abuse of the process of any Court. Sections 447 IPC (Criminal Trespass), 504 IPC (Intentional insult with intent to provoke breach of the peace), and 506 IPC (Punishment for criminal intimidation) are the penal provisions under which the complaint was filed.
judgment: The High Court quashed the criminal proceedings, holding that the dispute was essentially civil in nature concerning property rights, and criminal proceedings could not be used to settle civil disputes. The court noted that a civil suit for partition was already pending, and the alleged actions did not constitute criminal offences.

instruction: Summarize the facts, legal issue, provisions applied, and the High Court’s decision.
question: What did the High Court decide regarding Quashing of proceedings in FIR No. 352 of 2023 for offences under Sections 447 and 506 r/w Section 34 of IPC. under Section 482 Cr.P.C. allows the High Court to quash proceedings to secure the ends of justice. Sections 447 IPC (Criminal Trespass) and 506 IPC (Punishment for criminal intimidation) are the alleged offences. Section 41-A Cr.P.C. provides for notice of appearance before the police officer.?
facts: The petitioners filed a criminal petition under Section 482 of the Cr.P.C. seeking to quash FIR No. 352 of 2023 registered at Bandlaguda Police Station for alleged offences under Sections 447 and 506 read with Section 34 of the IPC. The case involved alleged criminal trespass and intimidation.
charge: Quashing of proceedings in FIR No. 352 of 2023 for offences under Sections 447 and 506 r/w Section 34 of IPC.
law: Code of Criminal Procedure, 1973; Indian Penal Code, 1860
law_content: Section 482 Cr.P.C. allows the High Court to quash proceedings to secure the ends of justice. Sections 447 IPC (Criminal Trespass) and 506 IPC (Punishment for criminal intimidation) are the alleged offences. Section 41-A Cr.P.C. provides for notice of appearance before the police officer.
judgment: The High Court directed the petitioners/accused to appear before the Investigating Officer on or before a specified date, directing the officer to follow the procedure under Section 41-A Cr.P.C. and the Arnesh Kumar guidelines. The court also stated that there would be no arrest until the police investigate and decide on the documents filed by the petitioners.

instruction: Summarize the facts, legal issue, provisions applied, and the High Court’s decision.
question: What did the High Court decide regarding Quashing of criminal proceedings for offences under Sections 468 and 471 of IPC, related to using forged documents. under Section 482 CrPC - Saving of inherent powers of High Court: Nothing in this Code shall be deemed to limit or otherwise affect the inherent powers of the High Court to make such orders as may be necessary to give effect to any order passed under this Code, or to prevent abuse of the process of any Court or otherwise to secure the ends of justice.?
facts: The petitioners are accused of using a fake letter of credit and acceptance letter to obtain a loan. The bank discounted the letter of credit, and the amount was credited to the petitioner's loan account, which was later closed after repayment. The petitioners are seeking to quash the criminal proceedings initiated based on these allegations.
charge: Quashing of criminal proceedings for offences under Sections 468 and 471 of IPC, related to using forged documents.
law: Indian Penal Code (IPC) and Code of Criminal Procedure (CrPC)
law_content: Section 482 CrPC - Saving of inherent powers of High Court: Nothing in this Code shall be deemed to limit or otherwise affect the inherent powers of the High Court to make such orders as may be necessary to give effect to any order passed under this Code, or to prevent abuse of the process of any Court or otherwise to secure the ends of justice.
judgment: The petition sought to quash criminal proceedings where the petitioner was accused of using fake documents to obtain a loan. The court noted that the loan amount obtained through the alleged fake letter of credit was repaid and the loan account was closed. The court allowed the criminal petition, effectively quashing the proceedings.

instruction: Summarize the facts, legal issue, provisions applied, and the High Court’s decision.
question: What did the High Court decide regarding Granting regular bail to the petitioner/accused in Crime No. 563 of 2023 for offences under Sections 376(3) IPC and Section 5(n)(1) read with Section 6 of the POCSO Act. under Sections 437 and 439 of the Cr.P.C. govern the powers of Magistrate and Court of Session/High Court respectively, to grant bail. Section 376(3) IPC deals with rape of a woman under twelve years of age by a person over eighteen, and Section 5(n)(1) read with Section 6 of the POCSO Act pertains to punishment for penetrative sexual assault of a child.?
facts: The petitioner, accused in a crime registered for offences under Section 376(3) of the IPC and Section 5(n)(1) read with Section 6 of the POCSO Act, sought regular bail. The court had previously dismissed a similar relief on the grounds of the alleged offense involving the accused's own daughter.
charge: Granting regular bail to the petitioner/accused in Crime No. 563 of 2023 for offences under Sections 376(3) IPC and Section 5(n)(1) read with Section 6 of the POCSO Act.
law: Sections 437 & 439 of Cr.P.C., Section 376(3) IPC, Section 5(n)(1) r/w 6 of POCSO Act-2012
law_content: Sections 437 and 439 of the Cr.P.C. govern the powers of Magistrate and Court of Session/High Court respectively, to grant bail. Section 376(3) IPC deals with rape of a woman under twelve years of age by a person over eighteen, and Section 5(n)(1) read with Section 6 of the POCSO Act pertains to punishment for penetrative sexual assault of a child.
judgment: Despite the victim (daughter of the petitioner) giving no objection for the grant of bail, the Court was not inclined to grant regular bail to the petitioner. The criminal petition was dismissed.

instruction: Summarize the facts, legal issue, provisions applied, and the High Court’s decision.
question: What did the High Court decide regarding Quashing of proceedings in C.C. No. 367 of 2022 and dispensing with the personal appearance of the petitioner. under Section 482 Cr.P.C. - Saving of inherent powers of High Court. Nothing in this Code shall be deemed to limit or affect the inherent powers of the High Court to make such orders as may be necessary to give effect to any order under this Code, or to prevent abuse of the process of any Court or otherwise to secure the ends of justice.?
facts: The petitioner, an accused in a criminal case, filed a petition under Section 482 of the Cr.P.C. seeking to quash the proceedings against him. The petitioner also sought to dispense with his personal appearance before the trial court.
charge: Quashing of proceedings in C.C. No. 367 of 2022 and dispensing with the personal appearance of the petitioner.
law_content: Section 482 Cr.P.C. - Saving of inherent powers of High Court. Nothing in this Code shall be deemed to limit or affect the inherent powers of the High Court to make such orders as may be necessary to give effect to any order under this Code, or to prevent abuse of the process of any Court or otherwise to secure the ends of justice.
judgment: The Court dispensed with the personal appearance of the petitioner before the trial court in C.C. No. 367 of 2022, except on dates when his presence is specifically required by the trial court. The petitioner shall be represented by his counsel on all other dates.

instruction: Summarize the facts, legal issue, provisions applied, and the High Court’s decision.
question: What did the High Court decide regarding Quashing of proceedings in DVC No. 120 of 2021. under Section 482 Cr.P.C. deals with the inherent powers of the High Court to make such orders as may be necessary to give effect to any order under this Code, or to prevent abuse of the process of any Court or otherwise to secure the ends of justice.?
facts: The petitioners filed a criminal petition under Section 482 of the Cr.P.C. seeking to quash proceedings in DVC No. 120 of 2021. The respondents included the State of Telangana and the complainant. The case was filed in the V Addl. Metropolitan Magistrate, Cyberabad.
charge: Quashing of proceedings in DVC No. 120 of 2021.
law_content: Section 482 Cr.P.C. deals with the inherent powers of the High Court to make such orders as may be necessary to give effect to any order under this Code, or to prevent abuse of the process of any Court or otherwise to secure the ends of justice.
judgment: The Court held that a petition to quash proceedings in a Domestic Violence Case is not maintainable under Section 482 Cr.P.C. The Court referred to a previous judgment (Gaddameedi Nagamani v. State of Telangana) stating that Section 29 of the Protection of Women from Domestic Violence Act, 2005 provides an efficacious remedy through an appeal against the court's decision to take cognizance. The petitioners were granted liberty to avail this alternative remedy. However, the appearance of the petitioners in the DVC proceedings was dispensed with, except when required by the trial court, and they were to be represented by their counsel.

instruction: Summarize the facts, legal issue, provisions applied, and the High Court’s decision.
question: What did the High Court decide regarding The petitioner seeks a declaration that the action of the respondent police in implicating his son in multiple FIRs is illegal, arbitrary, unjust, and unconstitutional. under Article 226 of the Constitution of India - empowers the High Courts to issue writs in the nature of mandamus for the enforcement of fundamental rights or for any other purpose. Section 151 CPC - provides for the inherent power of the court to make such orders as may be necessary for the ends of justice.?
facts: The petitioner's son, Niranjan Yadav, is remanded in relation to FIR No. 437/2023 and is arrayed as Accused No. 5 in a series of similar cases across various districts. The petitioner seeks to prevent the police from implicating his son in these cases.
charge: The petitioner seeks a declaration that the action of the respondent police in implicating his son in multiple FIRs is illegal, arbitrary, unjust, and unconstitutional.
law: Constitution of India, 1950; Code of Civil Procedure, 1908
law_content: Article 226 of the Constitution of India - empowers the High Courts to issue writs in the nature of mandamus for the enforcement of fundamental rights or for any other purpose. Section 151 CPC - provides for the inherent power of the court to make such orders as may be necessary for the ends of justice.
judgment: The writ petition was closed after the petitioner's counsel submitted that the list of criminal cases where the son of the petitioner is involved was furnished by the Assistant Government Pleader for Home, and therefore, no further orders were required.

instruction: Summarize the facts, legal issue, provisions applied, and the High Court’s decision.
question: What did the High Court decide regarding Quashing of order in P.R.C. No. 52 of 2022 and discharge from liability. under Section 482 Cr.P.C. - inherent powers of the High Court to make such orders as may be necessary to give effect to any order under this Code, or to prevent abuse of the process of any Court or otherwise to secure the ends of justice. Sections 19(a)(vi) read with Rule 106 and Schedule J of the Drugs and Cosmetics Act, 1940 and Drugs and Cosmetics Rules, 1945, and Section 3(d) read with Schedule of the Drugs and Magic Remedies (Objectionable Advertisements) Act, 1954 pertain to prohibited advertisements and remedies for certain diseases.?
facts: The petitioner, a former director of M/s. Gena Pharmaceuticals Limited, is seeking to quash an order passed against him. The de-facto complainant filed a complaint alleging contraventions of the Drugs and Cosmetics Act, 1940, and the Drugs and Magic Remedies (Objectionable Advertisements) Act, 1954, against the company and its directors. The petitioner contends that the proceedings against him are without merit.
charge: Quashing of order in P.R.C. No. 52 of 2022 and discharge from liability.
law: Code of Criminal Procedure, 1973; Drugs and Cosmetics Act, 1940; Drugs and Magic Remedies (Objectionable Advertisements) Act, 1954
law_content: Section 482 Cr.P.C. - inherent powers of the High Court to make such orders as may be necessary to give effect to any order under this Code, or to prevent abuse of the process of any Court or otherwise to secure the ends of justice. Sections 19(a)(vi) read with Rule 106 and Schedule J of the Drugs and Cosmetics Act, 1940 and Drugs and Cosmetics Rules, 1945, and Section 3(d) read with Schedule of the Drugs and Magic Remedies (Objectionable Advertisements) Act, 1954 pertain to prohibited advertisements and remedies for certain diseases.
judgment: The High Court, upon reviewing the case and hearing arguments, allowed the criminal petition and quashed the impugned order against the petitioner, thereby discharging him from liability in connection with P.R.C. No. 52 of 2022.

instruction: Summarize the facts, legal issue, provisions applied, and the High Court’s decision.
question: What did the High Court decide regarding Seeking anticipatory bail under Section 438 of Cr.P.C. under Section 438 of Cr.P.C. pertains to the power of the High Court or Court of Session to direct that in the event of arrest, any person shall be released on bail. Sections 306 r/w 34 of IPC relate to abetment of suicide and common intention.?
facts: The petitioner, Accused No.4, sought anticipatory bail in a case registered for offenses under Sections 306 r/w 34 of IPC. The deceased committed suicide due to alleged harassment and threats by accused Nos. 1 to 3, who threatened to expose photographs and videos of the deceased. The petitioner is the mother of accused No.3.
charge: Seeking anticipatory bail under Section 438 of Cr.P.C.
law_content: Section 438 of Cr.P.C. pertains to the power of the High Court or Court of Session to direct that in the event of arrest, any person shall be released on bail. Sections 306 r/w 34 of IPC relate to abetment of suicide and common intention.
judgment: The High Court granted anticipatory bail to the petitioner, subject to her surrendering before the Station House Officer, executing a personal bond, and cooperating with the investigation.

instruction: Summarize the facts, legal issue, provisions applied, and the High Court’s decision.
question: What did the High Court decide regarding Anticipatory bail under Section 438 of Cr.P.C. under Section 438 of the Cr.P.C. allows a person who apprehends arrest on an accusation of having committed a non-bailable offence to apply to the High Court or Court of Session for a direction that he shall be released on bail if arrested.?
facts: The petitioner, accused no. 1 in a criminal case registered for various offences under the IPC, sought anticipatory bail. This was a subsequent petition after a previous application for anticipatory bail was dismissed by the same court.
charge: Anticipatory bail under Section 438 of Cr.P.C.
law_content: Section 438 of the Cr.P.C. allows a person who apprehends arrest on an accusation of having committed a non-bailable offence to apply to the High Court or Court of Session for a direction that he shall be released on bail if arrested.
judgment: The High Court dismissed the criminal petition for anticipatory bail, stating that there were no changed circumstances from the earlier order where the prayer was refused. However, it directed that if the petitioner surrenders and files a bail application, it shall be disposed of within two working days.

instruction: Summarize the facts, legal issue, provisions applied, and the High Court’s decision.
question: What did the High Court decide regarding Quashing of charge sheet in C.C. No. 1288 of 2019 for alleged offences under Section 188 of the Indian Penal Code and Section 4 read with Section 21 of the Mines and Minerals (Regulation and Development) Act, 1957. under Section 482 Cr.P.C. - For quashing proceedings; Section 195(1)(a) Cr.P.C. - Bar on cognizance of certain offences without prior complaint by a public servant; Section 188 IPC - Disobedience to order duly promulgated by public servant; Section 4 read with Section 21 of MMDR Act - Penalties for contravention of provisions of the Act and rules.?
facts: The petitioners are accused in a case where they allegedly ran an illegal crusher on government land without permission. The police registered a case based on a complaint, and a charge sheet was filed. The petitioners seek to quash the charge sheet.
charge: Quashing of charge sheet in C.C. No. 1288 of 2019 for alleged offences under Section 188 of the Indian Penal Code and Section 4 read with Section 21 of the Mines and Minerals (Regulation and Development) Act, 1957.
law: Code of Criminal Procedure, 1973; Indian Penal Code, 1860; Mines and Minerals (Regulation and Development) Act, 1957
law_content: Section 482 Cr.P.C. - For quashing proceedings; Section 195(1)(a) Cr.P.C. - Bar on cognizance of certain offences without prior complaint by a public servant; Section 188 IPC - Disobedience to order duly promulgated by public servant; Section 4 read with Section 21 of MMDR Act - Penalties for contravention of provisions of the Act and rules.
judgment: The Court heard arguments from both sides regarding the applicability of Section 195(1)(a) of Cr.P.C., which bars the cognizance of offences under Section 188 IPC if the complaint is not made by a public servant. Further arguments were presented concerning the Mines and Minerals Act.

instruction: Summarize the facts, legal issue, provisions applied, and the High Court’s decision.
question: What did the High Court decide regarding Quashing of proceedings under S.C. No. 5/2023 for offences under NDPS Act, TS Excise Act, Disaster Management Act, Epidemic Disease Act, and IPC. under Section 482 of Cr.P.C. - Saving of inherent powers of High Court. The petition seeks to invoke this section to quash the proceedings. The case involves charges under various sections of the NDPS Act (e.g., 8(c), 20(b), 25, 27(a), 29, 37), Section 34 read with Section 15 of TS Excise Act, Section 51(b) of Disaster Management Act, Section 3(1) of Epidemic Disease Act, and Sections 188 and 294 of IPC.?
facts: The petitioner, accused No. 59, filed a criminal petition seeking to quash the proceedings against him in S.C. No. 5/2023, which involves charges under the NDPS Act, TS Excise Act, Disaster Management Act, Epidemic Disease Act, and IPC. The case stemmed from a rave party where substances were allegedly consumed and other violations occurred. The petitioner claims he was apprehended on the road and falsely implicated.
charge: Quashing of proceedings under S.C. No. 5/2023 for offences under NDPS Act, TS Excise Act, Disaster Management Act, Epidemic Disease Act, and IPC.
law: Code of Criminal Procedure, 1973; Narcotic Drugs and Psychotropic Substances Act, 1985; IPC; Disaster Management Act, 2005; Epidemic Disease Act, 1897
law_content: Section 482 of Cr.P.C. - Saving of inherent powers of High Court. The petition seeks to invoke this section to quash the proceedings. The case involves charges under various sections of the NDPS Act (e.g., 8(c), 20(b), 25, 27(a), 29, 37), Section 34 read with Section 15 of TS Excise Act, Section 51(b) of Disaster Management Act, Section 3(1) of Epidemic Disease Act, and Sections 188 and 294 of IPC.
judgment: The Court noted that the petitioner was found present at the rave party premises but there was no specific allegation or test confirming his consumption of ganja or intoxication. The Court also observed that mere presence without involvement in prohibited substances or specific roles doesn't necessarily make the petitioner punishable under all penal provisions, leaving the determination of the petitioner's complicity to the trial court.

instruction: Summarize the facts, legal issue, provisions applied, and the High Court’s decision.
question: What did the High Court decide regarding Challenging the dismissal of an application to recall a witness for further cross-examination. under Section 482 Cr.P.C. allows the High Court to make orders to secure the ends of justice. Section 311 Cr.P.C. empowers the court to recall or re-examine any person present at any stage of the inquiry, trial, or other proceeding, if their evidence appears essential to a just decision.?
facts: The petitioner/accused filed a petition under Section 482 of Cr.P.C. challenging an order of the Metropolitan Magistrate which dismissed their application under Section 311 Cr.P.C. to recall PW1 for further cross-examination. The trial court found the application was filed to delay the proceedings.
charge: Challenging the dismissal of an application to recall a witness for further cross-examination.
law_content: Section 482 Cr.P.C. allows the High Court to make orders to secure the ends of justice. Section 311 Cr.P.C. empowers the court to recall or re-examine any person present at any stage of the inquiry, trial, or other proceeding, if their evidence appears essential to a just decision.
judgment: The Criminal Petition is allowed, setting aside the trial court's order. The trial court is directed to permit the petitioner to cross-examine PW1, with the condition that it must be completed on the date fixed without further adjournment.

instruction: Summarize the facts, legal issue, provisions applied, and the High Court’s decision.
question: What did the High Court decide regarding Quashing of the order dismissing the application for recall of a witness for further cross-examination. under Section 482 Cr.P.C. empowers the High Court to pass orders to secure the ends of justice. Section 311 Cr.P.C. allows the court to recall or re-examine any person if their evidence appears essential for a just decision.?
facts: The petitioner/accused filed a criminal petition under Section 482 of Cr.P.C. seeking to quash an order by the Metropolitan Magistrate that dismissed their application under Section 311 Cr.P.C. to recall PW1 for further cross-examination. The trial court believed the application was intended to prolong the case.
charge: Quashing of the order dismissing the application for recall of a witness for further cross-examination.
law_content: Section 482 Cr.P.C. empowers the High Court to pass orders to secure the ends of justice. Section 311 Cr.P.C. allows the court to recall or re-examine any person if their evidence appears essential for a just decision.
judgment: The Criminal Petition is allowed, setting aside the trial court's order. The trial court is directed to permit the petitioner to cross-examine PW1 on the scheduled date without seeking further adjournments. Miscellaneous applications are also closed.

instruction: Summarize the facts, legal issue, provisions applied, and the High Court’s decision.
question: What did the High Court decide regarding Contempt of court for non-compliance with court orders. under Sections 10 to 12 of the Contempt of Courts Act, 1971, define the powers of courts to punish for contempt and related procedures.?
facts: This contempt case was filed against the District Collector, Karimnagar. The petitioner had obtained an order in a writ petition concerning the connection of a road from Khazipur shivar to Kamareddy.
charge: Contempt of court for non-compliance with court orders.
law_content: Sections 10 to 12 of the Contempt of Courts Act, 1971, define the powers of courts to punish for contempt and related procedures.
judgment: The contempt case is closed as the respondent has implemented the orders of the court. Pending miscellaneous applications are also closed.

instruction: Summarize the facts, legal issue, provisions applied, and the High Court’s decision.
question: What did the High Court decide regarding Quashing of proceedings in FIR No. 634 of 2023 under Sections 341 and 506 of the Indian Penal Code. under Section 482 Cr.P.C. empowers the High Court to pass any order necessary to give effect to any order made under the Code, or to prevent abuse of the process of any Court or otherwise to secure the ends of justice.?
facts: The petitioner, an accused in Crime No. 634 of 2023 registered for alleged offences under Sections 341 and 506 of the Indian Penal Code, filed a petition under Section 482 of Cr.P.C. to quash the proceedings. The case involves the State of Telangana and Smt. Tasleem Begum as respondents.
charge: Quashing of proceedings in FIR No. 634 of 2023 under Sections 341 and 506 of the Indian Penal Code.
law_content: Section 482 Cr.P.C. empowers the High Court to pass any order necessary to give effect to any order made under the Code, or to prevent abuse of the process of any Court or otherwise to secure the ends of justice.
judgment: The High Court directed the petitioner to appear before the Investigating Officer and cooperate with the investigation. It also ordered that no coercive steps shall be taken against the petitioner until the investigation is completed, provided the petitioner cooperates fully.

instruction: Summarize the facts, legal issue, provisions applied, and the High Court’s decision.
question: What did the High Court decide regarding Quashing of proceedings in FIR No. 886 of 2023 and stay of further proceedings including arrest. under Section 482 Cr.P.C. allows the High Court to quash proceedings to prevent abuse of process or secure the ends of justice.?
facts: The petitioner, Sahil @ Raheel Amir, filed a criminal petition under Section 482 of Cr.P.C. seeking to quash proceedings in FIR No. 886 of 2023 registered at Panjagutta Police Station and also sought a stay on further proceedings, including arrest.
charge: Quashing of proceedings in FIR No. 886 of 2023 and stay of further proceedings including arrest.
law_content: Section 482 Cr.P.C. allows the High Court to quash proceedings to prevent abuse of process or secure the ends of justice.
judgment: The learned counsel for the petitioner sought permission to withdraw the Criminal Petition, which was granted by the Court. Consequently, the Criminal Petition was dismissed as withdrawn.

instruction: Summarize the facts, legal issue, provisions applied, and the High Court’s decision.
question: What did the High Court decide regarding To quash FIR No. 183 of 2023 registered under Sections 420 r/w 120b of IPC and to stay further proceedings. under Section 482 Cr.P.C. - Saving of inherent powers of High Court. Section 41-A Cr.P.C. - Notice of appearance before police officer. Section 420 IPC - Cheating. Section 120B IPC - Punishment of criminal conspiracy.?
facts: The petitioners are accused in FIR No. 183 of 2023, registered under Sections 420 and 120b of the Indian Penal Code. The petitioners filed a criminal petition seeking to quash the FIR and stay further proceedings, including their arrest.
charge: To quash FIR No. 183 of 2023 registered under Sections 420 r/w 120b of IPC and to stay further proceedings.
law: Code of Criminal Procedure, 1973 (Cr.P.C.), Indian Penal Code (IPC)
law_content: Section 482 Cr.P.C. - Saving of inherent powers of High Court. Section 41-A Cr.P.C. - Notice of appearance before police officer. Section 420 IPC - Cheating. Section 120B IPC - Punishment of criminal conspiracy.
judgment: The High Court directed the petitioners to appear before the Investigating Officer on or before January 25, 2024, between 02:00 p.m. and 04:00 p.m. The Investigating Officer was instructed to follow the procedure under Section 41-A Cr.P.C. and the guidelines from Arnesh Kumar v. State of Bihar. The police were directed not to take any coercive steps against the petitioners until the investigation is completed. The criminal petition was disposed of.

instruction: Summarize the facts, legal issue, provisions applied, and the High Court’s decision.
question: What did the High Court decide regarding Issuance of passport despite pendency of a criminal case. under The Passport Act, 1967, specifies grounds for refusal of a passport, primarily related to convictions for certain offenses within a preceding period or facing criminal trials. Article 226 allows for the issuance of writs, like mandamus, to direct authorities.?
facts: The petitioner applied for a passport, but his application was refused because a criminal case (CC No.89/2022) was pending against him. He made a representation, but no action was taken. The petitioner is accused in the case under Section 3 and 4 of the Gaming Act, but he has not been convicted.
charge: Issuance of passport despite pendency of a criminal case.
law: The Passport Act, 1967 and Article 226 of the Constitution of India
law_content: The Passport Act, 1967, specifies grounds for refusal of a passport, primarily related to convictions for certain offenses within a preceding period or facing criminal trials. Article 226 allows for the issuance of writs, like mandamus, to direct authorities.
judgment: The Court directed the passport authorities to consider the petitioner's application for a passport without reference to the pendency of the criminal case, relying on Supreme Court precedents that refusal is generally based on conviction, not mere pendency.

instruction: Summarize the facts, legal issue, provisions applied, and the High Court’s decision.
question: What did the High Court decide regarding Quashing of proceedings in Crime No. 309 of 2022 for alleged offences under Sections 406, 420, and 506 of the Indian Penal Code. under Section 482 Cr.P.C. allows the High Court to make such orders as may be necessary to give effect to any order under the Code or to prevent abuse of the process of any Court or otherwise to secure the ends of justice. Section 41-A Cr.P.C. outlines the procedure for appearance of accused persons in certain cases.?
facts: The petitioner, accused no. 1, filed a criminal petition seeking to quash proceedings registered in a crime. The petitioner stated that similar complaints were filed on the same set of facts, leading to FIRs, and in one instance, a charge sheet was filed. The alleged offences carry a punishment of less than seven years.
charge: Quashing of proceedings in Crime No. 309 of 2022 for alleged offences under Sections 406, 420, and 506 of the Indian Penal Code.
law_content: Section 482 Cr.P.C. allows the High Court to make such orders as may be necessary to give effect to any order under the Code or to prevent abuse of the process of any Court or otherwise to secure the ends of justice. Section 41-A Cr.P.C. outlines the procedure for appearance of accused persons in certain cases.
judgment: The High Court, considering that the punishment for the alleged offences was less than seven years and that other similar complaints had been filed, directed the petitioner to appear before the Investigating Officer within a specified period. The Investigating Officer was instructed to follow the procedure under Section 41-A Cr.P.C. and the guidelines in Arnesh Kumar v. State of Bihar, and not to take coercive steps against the petitioner until the investigation is completed.

instruction: Summarize the facts, legal issue, provisions applied, and the High Court’s decision.
question: What did the High Court decide regarding The petitioner sought a writ of mandamus or direction to rectify the mistakes in the charge sheet filed in CC No. 5360/2022, which originated from FIR No. 65/2021, and to consider their representation. under Sections 420, 468, 471 read with 34 of IPC (offences mentioned in FIR). Article 226 of the Constitution of India (for writ of mandamus). Section 151 CPC (for interim relief).?
facts: The petitioner, who was the complainant in a criminal case (FIR No. 65/2021), alleged that the charge sheet filed by the respondent police contained significant errors, including referring to a different crime. The petitioner had made a representation to rectify these errors, but it was not considered. The case was filed under Articles 226 and 151 CPC.
charge: The petitioner sought a writ of mandamus or direction to rectify the mistakes in the charge sheet filed in CC No. 5360/2022, which originated from FIR No. 65/2021, and to consider their representation.
law: Indian Penal Code (IPC), Code of Criminal Procedure (CrPC), Constitution of India
law_content: Sections 420, 468, 471 read with 34 of IPC (offences mentioned in FIR). Article 226 of the Constitution of India (for writ of mandamus). Section 151 CPC (for interim relief).
judgment: The High Court disposed of the writ petition by directing the respondent police officer (Respondent No. 3) to correct the errors in the charge sheet by deleting information related to another case and file an appropriate supplementary charge sheet within four weeks. The lower court was directed to examine the supplementary charge sheet and pass orders accordingly.

instruction: Summarize the facts, legal issue, provisions applied, and the High Court’s decision.
question: What did the High Court decide regarding Seeking regular bail for the petitioner/Accused No.5. under Sections 437 and 439 of Cr.P.C. for seeking regular bail. Offences under Sections 8(c) r/w. 20(b)(ii)(c), 27A, 28 & 29 of the NDPS Act.?
facts: The petitioner, accused No. 5 in an NDPS case, sought regular bail. The trial was supposed to be concluded within six months as per a previous court order, but 15 months have passed since then, and the trial is still pending.
charge: Seeking regular bail for the petitioner/Accused No.5.
law: Code of Criminal Procedure, 1973 (Cr.P.C.); Narcotic Drugs and Psychotropic Substances Act, 1985 (NDPS Act).
law_content: Sections 437 and 439 of Cr.P.C. for seeking regular bail. Offences under Sections 8(c) r/w. 20(b)(ii)(c), 27A, 28 & 29 of the NDPS Act.
judgment: The High Court granted regular bail to the petitioner, considering the significant delay in the conclusion of the trial despite previous court orders. The Court noted that the failure to produce witnesses and conclude the trial cannot be a ground for extending the petitioner's detention, especially since almost three years have passed since his arrest.

instruction: Summarize the facts, legal issue, provisions applied, and the High Court’s decision.
question: What did the High Court decide regarding Seeking regular bail for the accused in a case registered under Section 395 of IPC. under Sections 437 & 439 Cr.P.C. – Provisions related to granting bail. Section 395 IPC – Punishment for dacoity.?
facts: The petitioner/accused filed a criminal petition seeking regular bail in a case registered under Section 395 of the IPC. The court had previously directed the Sessions Court to conclude the trial within six months because the petitioners were in jail.
charge: Seeking regular bail for the accused in a case registered under Section 395 of IPC.
law: Sections 437 & 439 of Cr.P.C., Section 395 of IPC
law_content: Sections 437 & 439 Cr.P.C. – Provisions related to granting bail. Section 395 IPC – Punishment for dacoity.
judgment: The Court found the bail application to be premature based on its previous order directing the conclusion of the trial within six months. The petition was dismissed, but the petitioners were granted liberty to move the court for bail after the expiry of the prescribed time.

instruction: Summarize the facts, legal issue, provisions applied, and the High Court’s decision.
question: What did the High Court decide regarding Quashing of warrant of attachment and stay of proceedings in a maintenance case. under Section 482 of Cr.P.C. - High Court's inherent powers to make such orders as may be necessary to give effect to any order under this Code, or to prevent abuse of the process of any Court or otherwise to secure the ends of justice. This section was invoked to quash the warrant of attachment and stay proceedings.?
facts: The petitioner sought to quash a warrant of attachment and stay further proceedings related to a maintenance case. The case involved a criminal petition filed under Section 482 of Cr.P.C., challenging an order dated 26.09.2022 in M.P.No.9 of 2019 in M.C.No.387 of 2016.
charge: Quashing of warrant of attachment and stay of proceedings in a maintenance case.
law_content: Section 482 of Cr.P.C. - High Court's inherent powers to make such orders as may be necessary to give effect to any order under this Code, or to prevent abuse of the process of any Court or otherwise to secure the ends of justice. This section was invoked to quash the warrant of attachment and stay proceedings.
judgment: The petition was allowed with no costs.

instruction: Summarize the facts, legal issue, provisions applied, and the High Court’s decision.
question: What did the High Court decide regarding Quashing of FIR and criminal proceedings for alleged offenses under Sections 420, 468, & 471 of IPC. under Section 482 of Cr.P.C. - empowers the High Court to quash proceedings to prevent abuse of process or secure justice. Section 41-A Cr.P.C. - procedure for appearance of persons involved in a case where arrest is not required. Sections 420, 468, 471 of IPC - deal with cheating, forgery, and using forged documents as genuine.?
facts: The petitioners, accused in a case registered under FIR No.861 of 2023 for offenses under Sections 420, 468, & 471 of IPC, sought to quash the proceedings. They contended that the case stemmed from civil disputes and that civil court orders were in their favor.
charge: Quashing of FIR and criminal proceedings for alleged offenses under Sections 420, 468, & 471 of IPC.
law_content: Section 482 of Cr.P.C. - empowers the High Court to quash proceedings to prevent abuse of process or secure justice. Section 41-A Cr.P.C. - procedure for appearance of persons involved in a case where arrest is not required. Sections 420, 468, 471 of IPC - deal with cheating, forgery, and using forged documents as genuine.
judgment: The High Court directed the petitioners to appear before the investigating officer and follow the procedure under Section 41-A Cr.P.C. and the Arnesh Kumar guidelines. No coercive steps were to be taken against the petitioners until the investigation is completed. The criminal petition was disposed of accordingly.

instruction: Summarize the facts, legal issue, provisions applied, and the High Court’s decision.
question: What did the High Court decide regarding Quashing of proceedings in FIR No. 92/2023 for offences under Sections 420, 467, 506 read with Section 34 IPC. under Section 482 Cr.P.C. - Saving of inherent powers of High Court; Section 420 IPC - Cheating; Section 467 IPC - Forgery of valuable security or will; Section 506 IPC - Punishment for criminal intimidation; Section 34 IPC - Acts done by several persons in furtherance of common intention; Section 41-A Cr.P.C. - Procedure when police officer need not arrest.?
facts: The petitioners, accused Nos. 2 and 3, are seeking to quash the proceedings against them in FIR No. 92/2023 registered for alleged offences under Sections 420, 467, 506 read with Section 34 of the Indian Penal Code. The case stems from a private complaint filed under Section 200 of Cr.P.C.
charge: Quashing of proceedings in FIR No. 92/2023 for offences under Sections 420, 467, 506 read with Section 34 IPC.
law_content: Section 482 Cr.P.C. - Saving of inherent powers of High Court; Section 420 IPC - Cheating; Section 467 IPC - Forgery of valuable security or will; Section 506 IPC - Punishment for criminal intimidation; Section 34 IPC - Acts done by several persons in furtherance of common intention; Section 41-A Cr.P.C. - Procedure when police officer need not arrest.
judgment: The Court directed the police to issue notice under Section 41-A of Cr.P.C. to the petitioners and to follow the guidelines in Arnesh Kumar v. State of Bihar. The petitioners are to cooperate with the investigation. No coercive steps shall be taken against the petitioners until the investigation is completed. The court noted that Section 467 IPC may not be attracted prima facie.

instruction: Summarize the facts, legal issue, provisions applied, and the High Court’s decision.
question: What did the High Court decide regarding Compounding of offence under Section 138 of Negotiable Instruments Act based on compromise. under Section 397 Cr.P.C. - Calling for records to exercise powers of revision; Section 401 Cr.P.C. - Powers of revision; Section 138 Negotiable Instruments Act - Dishonour of cheque for insufficiency, etc., of funds in the account.?
facts: The petitioner was convicted under Section 138 of the Negotiable Instruments Act. The petitioner and the defacto complainant have entered into a compromise, and an application has been filed to compound the offence. The petitioner has complied with the court's earlier direction to deposit 5% of the settled cheque amount.
charge: Compounding of offence under Section 138 of Negotiable Instruments Act based on compromise.
law_content: Section 397 Cr.P.C. - Calling for records to exercise powers of revision; Section 401 Cr.P.C. - Powers of revision; Section 138 Negotiable Instruments Act - Dishonour of cheque for insufficiency, etc., of funds in the account.
judgment: The Court allowed the application for compounding the offence, noting that the parties had settled the matter out of court and the petitioner had complied with the directions regarding the deposit. The proceedings were deemed to serve no purpose and were accordingly disposed of.

instruction: Summarize the facts, legal issue, provisions applied, and the High Court’s decision.
question: What did the High Court decide regarding Quashing of proceedings in D.V.C.No.97 of 2023 pending on the file of the IX Addl. Junior Civil Judge-cum-Metropolitan Magistrate at Kukatpally. under Section 482 CrPC for quashing of proceedings; Section 29 of the Protection of Women from Domestic Violence Act, 2005, which provides for an appeal against the order of cognizance.?
facts: The petitioners filed a criminal petition under Section 482 of the CrPC seeking to quash proceedings against them in a Domestic Violence Case (DVC) pending before the IX Additional Junior Civil Judge-cum-Metropolitan Magistrate. The State was represented by the Public Prosecutor, and the complainant did not appear.
charge: Quashing of proceedings in D.V.C.No.97 of 2023 pending on the file of the IX Addl. Junior Civil Judge-cum-Metropolitan Magistrate at Kukatpally.
law: Code of Criminal Procedure, 1973; Protection of Women from Domestic Violence Act, 2005
law_content: Section 482 CrPC for quashing of proceedings; Section 29 of the Protection of Women from Domestic Violence Act, 2005, which provides for an appeal against the order of cognizance.
judgment: The High Court held that a criminal petition under Section 482 CrPC to quash proceedings under the DV Act is not maintainable as Section 29 of the DV Act provides an efficacious remedy of appeal. The petitioners were granted liberty to avail the alternative remedy. The personal appearance of the petitioners was dispensed with, except when required by the trial court.

instruction: Summarize the facts, legal issue, provisions applied, and the High Court’s decision.
question: What did the High Court decide regarding Quashing of criminal proceedings or dispensing with personal appearance of the accused. under Section 482 - Saving of inherent powers of High Court. Nothing in this Code shall be deemed to limit or affect the inherent powers of the High Court to make such orders as may be necessary to give effect to any order under this Code, or to prevent abuse of the process of any Court or otherwise to secure the ends of justice.?
facts: The petitioner, Mukara Radha, filed a criminal petition seeking to quash proceedings in C.C.No.440 of 2023 before the Additional Judicial First Class Magistrate at Madhira. However, during the hearing, the petitioner's counsel restricted the prayer to dispensing with the petitioner's appearance before the trial court.
charge: Quashing of criminal proceedings or dispensing with personal appearance of the accused.
law_content: Section 482 - Saving of inherent powers of High Court. Nothing in this Code shall be deemed to limit or affect the inherent powers of the High Court to make such orders as may be necessary to give effect to any order under this Code, or to prevent abuse of the process of any Court or otherwise to secure the ends of justice.
judgment: The Court, considering that the petitioner is a woman and only sought to dispense with her appearance, allowed the prayer. Her appearance was dispensed with subject to her counsel appearing on every date and her filing an affidavit not disputing the proceedings or her identity conducted in her absence. She is required to appear if the court directs.

instruction: Summarize the facts, legal issue, provisions applied, and the High Court’s decision.
question: What did the High Court decide regarding Quashing of order dismissing the application for recall of witness for further cross-examination and directing the trial court to recall PW-1. under Section 482 Cr.P.C. - Powers of the High Court to pass orders to give effect to any order under this Code, or to prevent abuse of the process of any Court or otherwise to secure the ends of justice.?
facts: The petitioner, accused in S.C.SPL No.936 of 2018, sought to recall PW.1 (de facto complainant) for further cross-examination. The trial court had previously allowed a recall application, and PW.1 was cross-examined extensively. However, PW.1 later filed a memo, prompting a fresh recall application which was dismissed by the trial court.
charge: Quashing of order dismissing the application for recall of witness for further cross-examination and directing the trial court to recall PW-1.
law_content: Section 482 Cr.P.C. - Powers of the High Court to pass orders to give effect to any order under this Code, or to prevent abuse of the process of any Court or otherwise to secure the ends of justice.
judgment: The High Court allowed the petition, setting aside the trial court's order. It directed the trial court to recall PW.1 for further cross-examination, specifically concerning the contents of the memo filed by PW.1.

instruction: Summarize the facts, legal issue, provisions applied, and the High Court’s decision.
question: What did the High Court decide regarding Quashing of proceedings in a maintenance case filed under Section 125 of Cr.P.C. under Section 482 of Cr.P.C. for quashing the proceedings in M.C. No. 17 of 2023. The petitioner's original criminal case was filed for offenses under Sections 494, 420, 389, 406, and 506 of IPC.?
facts: The petitioner filed a criminal case against respondent No. 2 stating she was not his legally wedded wife. Respondent Nos. 2 and 3 (wife and daughter) filed a maintenance petition under Section 125 of Cr.P.C. The petitioner seeks to quash these proceedings, alleging the respondent misled the Magistrate Court by not disclosing her previous marriage.
charge: Quashing of proceedings in a maintenance case filed under Section 125 of Cr.P.C.
law: Code of Criminal Procedure (Cr.P.C.) Sections 125, 482 and Indian Penal Code (IPC) Sections 494, 420, 389, 406, 506
law_content: Section 482 of Cr.P.C. for quashing the proceedings in M.C. No. 17 of 2023. The petitioner's original criminal case was filed for offenses under Sections 494, 420, 389, 406, and 506 of IPC.
judgment: The court noted that the question of whether respondent No. 2 is the legally wedded wife requires a trial. The petitioner had previously filed a criminal case against respondent No. 2 for offenses including Section 494 of IPC (bigamy), which is pending. The court dismissed the petition, implying that the dispute should be resolved through the ongoing trial.

instruction: Summarize the facts, legal issue, provisions applied, and the High Court’s decision.
question: What did the High Court decide regarding Seeking to quash criminal proceedings and stay further proceedings in a case registered under the Cr.P.C. under Section 482 of Cr.P.C. - High Court's inherent power to make such orders as may be necessary to give effect to any order under this Code, or to prevent abuse of the process of any Court or otherwise to secure the ends of justice.?
facts: The petitioner filed a criminal petition seeking to quash proceedings in C.C. No. 4286 of 2018 pending before the III Metropolitan Magistrate, Cyberabad. The petitioner also sought a stay on further proceedings. The matter was listed for dismissal.
charge: Seeking to quash criminal proceedings and stay further proceedings in a case registered under the Cr.P.C.
law_content: Section 482 of Cr.P.C. - High Court's inherent power to make such orders as may be necessary to give effect to any order under this Code, or to prevent abuse of the process of any Court or otherwise to secure the ends of justice.
judgment: The criminal petition was dismissed as the petitioner failed to appear and prosecute the case, indicating a lack of interest. The dismissal was for default.

instruction: Summarize the facts, legal issue, provisions applied, and the High Court’s decision.
question: What did the High Court decide regarding Allegations of harassment by police without following due procedure of law, in the guise of investigation, at the instance of a complainant in a matrimonial case. under Section 41-A of Cr.P.C. - Notice of appearance before police officer; Sections 498-A and 406 of IPC - related to cruelty by husband or relatives and criminal breach of trust respectively; Sections 3 & 4 of Dowry Prohibition Act - prohibiting giving and taking of dowry.?
facts: The petitioners, who are family members, are accused in a case registered under Sections 498-A and 406 of IPC and Sections 3 & 4 of the Dowry Prohibition Act based on a complaint by the wife of petitioner No.1. Despite submitting explanations to notices under Section 41-A of Cr.P.C., the police are allegedly harassing them at the behest of the complainant.
charge: Allegations of harassment by police without following due procedure of law, in the guise of investigation, at the instance of a complainant in a matrimonial case.
law_content: Section 41-A of Cr.P.C. - Notice of appearance before police officer; Sections 498-A and 406 of IPC - related to cruelty by husband or relatives and criminal breach of trust respectively; Sections 3 & 4 of Dowry Prohibition Act - prohibiting giving and taking of dowry.
judgment: The writ petition sought a direction to the police to not harass the petitioners. The court noted the registration of a crime under Sections 498-A and 406 IPC and Dowry Prohibition Act and the issuance of notices under Section 41-A Cr.P.C.

instruction: Summarize the facts, legal issue, provisions applied, and the High Court’s decision.
question: What did the High Court decide regarding Quashing of proceedings in a Domestic Violence Case and stay of further proceedings. under Section 482 Cr.P.C. - Saving of inherent powers of High Court. This section allows the High Court to make such orders as may be necessary to give effect to any order under this Code, or to prevent abuse of the process of any Court or otherwise to secure the ends of justice. However, the Court referenced that a petition to quash proceedings in a Domestic Violence Case is not maintainable directly, as Section 29 of the Protection of Women from Domestic Violence Act, 2005 provides an effective remedy.?
facts: The petitioners sought to quash proceedings in a Domestic Violence Case (DVC No. 37 of 2023) pending before a Magistrate Court. They also sought a stay on the proceedings. The case was filed by the wife against the petitioners, who are her husband and his family members.
charge: Quashing of proceedings in a Domestic Violence Case and stay of further proceedings.
law_content: Section 482 Cr.P.C. - Saving of inherent powers of High Court. This section allows the High Court to make such orders as may be necessary to give effect to any order under this Code, or to prevent abuse of the process of any Court or otherwise to secure the ends of justice. However, the Court referenced that a petition to quash proceedings in a Domestic Violence Case is not maintainable directly, as Section 29 of the Protection of Women from Domestic Violence Act, 2005 provides an effective remedy.
judgment: The High Court held that a petition to quash proceedings in a Domestic Violence Case is not maintainable under Section 482 Cr.P.C. The Court stated that Section 29 of the Protection of Women from Domestic Violence Act, 2005, provides an efficacious remedy by way of an appeal against orders taking cognizance. The petitioners were granted liberty to avail this alternative remedy. The appearance of certain petitioners was also dispensed with except when required by the trial court.

instruction: Summarize the facts, legal issue, provisions applied, and the High Court’s decision.
question: What did the High Court decide regarding The petitioner sought to direct the respondents to consider their representation and conduct further investigation in Crime No. 353 of 2023, and to arrest the accused persons. under Article 226 of the Constitution of India (for writ of mandamus), Sections 354-D, 509, 504 of IPC (related to outraging modesty, intentional insult), and Sections 11 and 12 of the POCSO Act (related to offences against children).?
facts: The petitioner, A.B.S. Sastry, filed a writ petition seeking directions to investigate Crime No. 353 of 2023 under Sections 354-D, 509, 504 IPC and Sections 11 r/w 12 of POCSO Act. The petition also prayed for the arrest of the accused.
charge: The petitioner sought to direct the respondents to consider their representation and conduct further investigation in Crime No. 353 of 2023, and to arrest the accused persons.
law: Constitution of India, Indian Penal Code (IPC), Protection of Children from Sexual Offences (POCSO) Act
law_content: Article 226 of the Constitution of India (for writ of mandamus), Sections 354-D, 509, 504 of IPC (related to outraging modesty, intentional insult), and Sections 11 and 12 of the POCSO Act (related to offences against children).
judgment: The petitioner sought to withdraw the writ petition with liberty to avail other remedies. The court granted the permission and dismissed the writ petition as withdrawn.

question: What did the High Court decide regarding Anticipatory bail for the petitioner accused of offences under Section 498-A of IPC and Sections 3 and 4 of DPA. under Section 438 of Cr.P.C. (provisions relating to anticipatory bail) and Section 498-A of IPC (husband or relative of husband of a woman subjecting her to cruelty).?
facts: The petitioner, Sri. K Sreeman Reddy (Accused No. 1), filed a criminal petition seeking anticipatory bail in connection with FIR No. 319 of 2023 registered for offences under Section 498-A of IPC and Sections 3 and 4 of the Domestic Violence Act (DPA).
charge: Anticipatory bail for the petitioner accused of offences under Section 498-A of IPC and Sections 3 and 4 of DPA.
law: Criminal Procedure Code (Cr.P.C.), Indian Penal Code (IPC), Protection from Domestic Violence Act (DPA)
law_content: Section 438 of Cr.P.C. (provisions relating to anticipatory bail) and Section 498-A of IPC (husband or relative of husband of a woman subjecting her to cruelty).
judgment: The court directed the Investigating Officer to follow the procedure under Section 41-A Cr.P.C. and guidelines from Anrnesh Kumar vs. State of Bihar, with the petitioner cooperating with the investigation.

instruction: Summarize the facts, legal issue, provisions applied, and the High Court’s decision.
question: What did the High Court decide regarding Seeking regular bail under Sections 437 and 439 of the Code of Criminal Procedure, 1973, for the petitioner/Accused No.2. under Sections 437 and 439 Cr.P.C. relate to the provisions for granting bail. Section 167(2) Cr.P.C. provides for mandatory bail if the investigation is not completed within a stipulated period. Sections 8(c) r/w 20(b) of the NDPS Act deal with offenses related to the possession of ganja.?
facts: The petitioner, Accused No.2, sought regular bail after being arrested in connection with a crime involving the alleged possession of 225 kgs of ganja. The petitioner's arrest occurred on June 8, 2023, and their bail application was dismissed by the Sessions Judge on December 22, 2023, reportedly because a charge sheet had been filed. However, another accused (A-1) was granted bail on December 29, 2023, on the grounds that the charge sheet was not filed.
charge: Seeking regular bail under Sections 437 and 439 of the Code of Criminal Procedure, 1973, for the petitioner/Accused No.2.
law: Code of Criminal Procedure, 1973; Narcotic Drugs and Psychotropic Substances Act, 1985
law_content: Sections 437 and 439 Cr.P.C. relate to the provisions for granting bail. Section 167(2) Cr.P.C. provides for mandatory bail if the investigation is not completed within a stipulated period. Sections 8(c) r/w 20(b) of the NDPS Act deal with offenses related to the possession of ganja.
judgment: The High Court granted regular bail to the petitioner, noting an inconsistency in the Sessions Court's orders regarding the filing of the charge sheet. The court directed the petitioner to execute a personal bond of Rs. 1,00,000/- with two sureties and to appear before the Station House Officer weekly for eight weeks, and thereafter as required.

instruction: Summarize the facts, legal issue, provisions applied, and the High Court’s decision.
question: What did the High Court decide regarding Seeking anticipatory bail under Section 438 of the Code of Criminal Procedure, 1973, for the petitioners/accused. under Section 438 Cr.P.C. allows individuals to seek anticipatory bail if they apprehend arrest. Section 41-A Cr.P.C. relates to the procedure for appearance of persons concerned in a cognizable offence. Sections 455, 427, 506, and 114 IPC relate to offenses such as lurking house-trespass or house-breaking after preparation for hurt, mischief, criminal intimidation, and abetment.?
facts: The petitioners, accused numbers 1 to 6, 11, 19, 21, and 22, sought anticipatory bail. The FIR was registered following a complaint alleging that the accused trespassed onto the complainant's premises and caused damage to property, suspecting the complainant's family members' involvement in a death. The police added Section 455 IPC, which carries a penalty of up to 10 years, to prevent the issuance of a notice under Section 41-A Cr.P.C.
charge: Seeking anticipatory bail under Section 438 of the Code of Criminal Procedure, 1973, for the petitioners/accused.
law: Code of Criminal Procedure, 1973; Indian Penal Code, 1860
law_content: Section 438 Cr.P.C. allows individuals to seek anticipatory bail if they apprehend arrest. Section 41-A Cr.P.C. relates to the procedure for appearance of persons concerned in a cognizable offence. Sections 455, 427, 506, and 114 IPC relate to offenses such as lurking house-trespass or house-breaking after preparation for hurt, mischief, criminal intimidation, and abetment.
judgment: The High Court granted anticipatory bail to the petitioners. The court noted that the incident arose from a suicide in the village and that no specific overt acts were attributed to the petitioners in the complaint. The petitioners were directed to surrender and furnish bail bonds, and specific reporting conditions were imposed.

law_content: Section 154(3) Cr.P.C. - empowers a person aggrieved by the refusal to record information by the officer in charge of the police station to send the substance of the information to the Superintendent of Police or other empowered officers, who, if of opinion that such information discloses a cognizable offence, will either investigate the case themselves or direct an investigation to be made by any police officer subordinate to them in such manner as they think fit, and the said officer shall have the same powers and shall be bound to perform the same duties as if such information had been given to him and he had been empowered to investigate the case.
judgment: The Court directed the police to proceed with the complaint, make a GD entry, conduct a preliminary enquiry, and take necessary action based on the findings, considering the allegations of cognizable offences and the guidelines laid down by the Supreme Court.
