question: What did the High Court decide regarding Quashing of proceedings in a Domestic Violence Case (DVC No. 130 of 2023). under Section 482 Cr.P.C. - Saving of inherent powers of High Court. Section 29 of the Protection of Women from Domestic Violence Act, 2005 - Provides a remedy by way of an appeal against an order taking cognizance or any order of a Magistrate.?
facts: The petitioners sought to quash the proceedings against them in a Domestic Violence Case (DVC No. 130 of 2023) pending before the Judicial Magistrate. They filed a criminal petition under Section 482 of the Code of Criminal Procedure (Cr.P.C.) for this purpose.
charge: Quashing of proceedings in a Domestic Violence Case (DVC No. 130 of 2023).
law: Code of Criminal Procedure, 1973 and Protection of Women from Domestic Violence Act, 2005
law_content: Section 482 Cr.P.C. - Saving of inherent powers of High Court. Section 29 of the Protection of Women from Domestic Violence Act, 2005 - Provides a remedy by way of an appeal against an order taking cognizance or any order of a Magistrate.
judgment: The criminal petition to quash the DVC proceedings is not maintainable. The court held that Section 29 of the Domestic Violence Act, 2005, provides an efficacious remedy through an appeal. However, the court dispensed with the personal appearance of the petitioners in the DVC case, allowing them to be represented by their counsel, and disposed of the petition.

instruction: Summarize the facts, legal issue, provisions applied, and the High Court’s decision.
question: What did the High Court decide regarding Seeking permission for accused to appear through video conference for procedural steps in a criminal trial. under Section 482 Cr.P.C. - The High Court has the inherent power to make such orders as may be necessary to give effect to any order under this Code, or to prevent abuse of the process of any Court or otherwise to secure the ends of justice.?
facts: The petitioner, accused No. 4 in a criminal case (S.C. No. 5 of 2021), is seeking a direction from the High Court to the trial court to allow them to appear via Webex conference for certain procedural steps like framing of charges and recording of statements, as they are residing abroad.
charge: Seeking permission for accused to appear through video conference for procedural steps in a criminal trial.
law_content: Section 482 Cr.P.C. - The High Court has the inherent power to make such orders as may be necessary to give effect to any order under this Code, or to prevent abuse of the process of any Court or otherwise to secure the ends of justice.
judgment: The High Court directed the trial court to consider the petitioner's application for appearance via video conference expeditiously and pass orders in accordance with law.

instruction: Summarize the facts, legal issue, provisions applied, and the High Court’s decision.
question: What did the High Court decide regarding Anticipatory bail under Section 438 of Cr.P.C. under Section 438 Cr.P.C. allows a person to seek bail in anticipation of arrest. Sections 498-A IPC (husband or relative of husband of a woman subjecting her to cruelty), 420 IPC (cheating), 495 IPC (concealment of previous marriage by person already married), and the Dowry Prohibition Act deal with offences related to marriage and dowry.?
facts: The petitioner, accused of offences under Sections 498-A, 420, 495 IPC and Dowry Prohibition Act, sought anticipatory bail. The de-facto complainant alleged harassment and demand for dowry, and crucially, that the petitioner had concealed a previous marriage. The petitioner's counsel argued that the allegations stemmed from marital discord.
charge: Anticipatory bail under Section 438 of Cr.P.C.
law: Code of Criminal Procedure (Cr.P.C.), Section 438; Indian Penal Code (IPC), Sections 498-A, 420, 495; Dowry Prohibition Act, 1961
law_content: Section 438 Cr.P.C. allows a person to seek bail in anticipation of arrest. Sections 498-A IPC (husband or relative of husband of a woman subjecting her to cruelty), 420 IPC (cheating), 495 IPC (concealment of previous marriage by person already married), and the Dowry Prohibition Act deal with offences related to marriage and dowry.
judgment: The High Court granted anticipatory bail to the petitioner, imposing conditions including surrender before the police, release on bail with sureties, and cooperation with the investigation.

instruction: Summarize the facts, legal issue, provisions applied, and the High Court’s decision.
question: What did the High Court decide regarding Seeking transfer of a criminal case from one court to another. under Section 407 of Cr.P.C. states that an application for transfer of a case from one Criminal Court to another in the same Sessions Division shall not lie to the High Court unless such application has been made to the Sessions Court and rejected by it.?
facts: The petitioner filed a transfer criminal petition seeking to withdraw a case (S.C.No.125 of 2019) from one Metropolitan Sessions Judge and transfer it to another where a related case (S.C.No.191 of 2019) was pending. The petitioner intended to club and conduct a joint trial of interconnected cases.
charge: Seeking transfer of a criminal case from one court to another.
law_content: Section 407 of Cr.P.C. states that an application for transfer of a case from one Criminal Court to another in the same Sessions Division shall not lie to the High Court unless such application has been made to the Sessions Court and rejected by it.
judgment: The petition was dismissed as not maintainable because the petitioner had not first approached the Sessions Court and obtained a rejection order, as required by the proviso to Section 407 of the Cr.P.C.

instruction: Summarize the facts, legal issue, provisions applied, and the High Court’s decision.
question: What did the High Court decide regarding Quashing of proceedings in a Domestic Violence Case (DVC No.08/2019). under Section 482 of Cr.P.C. allows the High Court to quash proceedings. Section 29 of the Protection of Women from Domestic Violence Act, 2005 provides a remedy by way of an appeal against orders taking cognizance.?
facts: The petitioners filed a criminal petition under Section 482 of Cr.P.C. seeking to quash the proceedings in D.V.C.No.S of 2Ol9 pending on the file of XVI Additional Metropolitan Magistrate Court at Rajendranagar, Ranga Reddy District. The case relates to alleged domestic violence.
charge: Quashing of proceedings in a Domestic Violence Case (DVC No.08/2019).
law: Cr.P.C., Protection of Women from Domestic Violence Act, 2005
law_content: Section 482 of Cr.P.C. allows the High Court to quash proceedings. Section 29 of the Protection of Women from Domestic Violence Act, 2005 provides a remedy by way of an appeal against orders taking cognizance.
judgment: The court held that a petition to quash proceedings in a Domestic Violence Case is not maintainable under Section 482 of Cr.P.C. as Section 29 of the Protection of Women from Domestic Violence Act, 2005 provides an efficacious remedy of appeal. The petitioners were granted liberty to avail this alternative remedy. The appearance of petitioners 2 and 3 was dispensed with except when required by the trial court.

instruction: Summarize the facts, legal issue, provisions applied, and the High Court’s decision.
question: What did the High Court decide regarding Quashing of FIR and stay of criminal proceedings. under Section 482 Cr.P.C. - Saving of inherent powers of High Court to make orders necessary to give effect to any order under this Code, or to prevent abuse of the process of any Court or otherwise to secure the ends of justice.?
facts: The petitioners filed a criminal petition seeking to quash FIR No. 418/2023 registered at Maheswaram Police Station under Sections 341, 420, and 506 read with Section 34 of the Indian Penal Code. They also filed an interim application seeking a stay on further proceedings.
charge: Quashing of FIR and stay of criminal proceedings.
law_content: Section 482 Cr.P.C. - Saving of inherent powers of High Court to make orders necessary to give effect to any order under this Code, or to prevent abuse of the process of any Court or otherwise to secure the ends of justice.
judgment: The court directed the petitioners to appear before the Investigating Officer and ordered the officer to follow Section 41-A Cr.P.C. and the guidelines in Arnesh Kumar v. State of Bihar. The police were directed not to take coercive steps until the investigation is complete.

instruction: Summarize the facts, legal issue, provisions applied, and the High Court’s decision.
question: What did the High Court decide regarding The petitioner sought a direction for the police to conduct a fair, efficient, and speedy investigation and file a final report/charge sheet in FIR No. 1307/2022. under Sections 420, 406, 120B, 34 IPC (offences related to cheating, criminal breach of trust, conspiracy, common intention); Section 200, 156 CrPC (procedure for private complaints and police investigation); Article 226 of the Constitution of India (power of High Court to issue writs); Article 14, 21, 300-A of the Constitution of India (fundamental rights).?
facts: The petitioner filed a writ petition seeking a direction for investigation into FIR No. 1307/2022, registered for offences under Sections 420, 406, 120B, and 447 read with Section 34 of the IPC. The petitioner alleged inaction by the police despite the registration of the FIR.
charge: The petitioner sought a direction for the police to conduct a fair, efficient, and speedy investigation and file a final report/charge sheet in FIR No. 1307/2022.
law: Indian Penal Code, Criminal Procedure Code, Constitution of India
law_content: Sections 420, 406, 120B, 34 IPC (offences related to cheating, criminal breach of trust, conspiracy, common intention); Section 200, 156 CrPC (procedure for private complaints and police investigation); Article 226 of the Constitution of India (power of High Court to issue writs); Article 14, 21, 300-A of the Constitution of India (fundamental rights).
judgment: The High Court disposed of the writ petition by directing the police to complete the investigation in Crime No. 1307 of 2022 and file an appropriate final report/charge sheet within three months.

question: What did the High Court decide regarding Anticipatory Bail under Section 438 of Cr.P.C. under Section 438 of the Code of Criminal Procedure, 1973, allows a person apprehending arrest to apply for anticipatory bail. Sections 403, 405, 417, 420, 425, and 506 of the Indian Penal Code deal with offenses like dishonest misappropriation of property, criminal breach of trust, cheating, mischief, and criminal intimidation.?
facts: The petitioner sought anticipatory bail in connection with a crime registered for offenses including cheating and criminal breach of trust. The punishment for these offenses is up to seven years.
charge: Anticipatory Bail under Section 438 of Cr.P.C.
law: Section 438 of Cr.P.C. and Sections 403, 405, 417, 420, 425, 506 of Indian Penal Code
law_content: Section 438 of the Code of Criminal Procedure, 1973, allows a person apprehending arrest to apply for anticipatory bail. Sections 403, 405, 417, 420, 425, and 506 of the Indian Penal Code deal with offenses like dishonest misappropriation of property, criminal breach of trust, cheating, mischief, and criminal intimidation.
judgment: The court directed the Investigating Officer to follow the procedure laid down under Section 41-A Cr.P.C. and the guidelines in Arnesh Kumar v. State of Bihar, and dispose of the criminal petition.

instruction: Summarize the facts, legal issue, provisions applied, and the High Court’s decision.
question: What did the High Court decide regarding Allegations of offences under Sections 406 and 420 of the Indian Penal Code, 1860, concerning breach of trust and cheating. under Section 482 Cr.P.C. empowers the High Court to make such orders as may be necessary to give effect to any order under the Code, or to prevent abuse of the process of any Court or otherwise to secure the ends of justice. Sections 406 and 420 IPC deal with punishment for criminal breach of trust and cheating, respectively. The judgment also references guidelines from Arnesh Kumar v. State of Bihar concerning procedure under Section 41-A Cr.P.C. for offences punishable with imprisonment up to seven years.?
facts: The petitioner, Katel Sunitha Singh, sought to quash criminal proceedings initiated against her for alleged offences under Sections 406 and 420 of the Indian Penal Code, 1860. The proceedings were registered in Crime No. 1203 of 2023 at Jawaharnagar Police Station. The petitioner invoked Section 482 of the Code of Criminal Procedure (Cr.P.C.).
charge: Allegations of offences under Sections 406 and 420 of the Indian Penal Code, 1860, concerning breach of trust and cheating.
law: Code of Criminal Procedure, 1973 (Cr.P.C.) and Indian Penal Code, 1860 (IPC)
law_content: Section 482 Cr.P.C. empowers the High Court to make such orders as may be necessary to give effect to any order under the Code, or to prevent abuse of the process of any Court or otherwise to secure the ends of justice. Sections 406 and 420 IPC deal with punishment for criminal breach of trust and cheating, respectively. The judgment also references guidelines from Arnesh Kumar v. State of Bihar concerning procedure under Section 41-A Cr.P.C. for offences punishable with imprisonment up to seven years.
judgment: The High Court directed the petitioner to appear before the investigating officer on or before January 25, 2024, and the investigating officer was directed to follow the procedure under Section 41-A Cr.P.C. and the guidelines in Arnesh Kumar v. State of Bihar. The police were directed not to take any coercive steps against the petitioner until the investigation is completed.

instruction: Summarize the facts, legal issue, provisions applied, and the High Court’s decision.
question: What did the High Court decide regarding Contempt of Court for willful violation and disobedience of court orders. under Sections 10 to 12 of the Contempt of Courts Act, 1971, which deal with the powers of the court to punish for contempt.?
facts: The petitioner filed a contempt case alleging willful violation and disobedience of a previous court order dated 17.06.2022 in W.P. No. 5653 of 2022. The respondents are accused of not complying with the said order.
charge: Contempt of Court for willful violation and disobedience of court orders.
law_content: Sections 10 to 12 of the Contempt of Courts Act, 1971, which deal with the powers of the court to punish for contempt.
judgment: The contempt case was closed as the court was informed that the order dated 17.06.2022 in W.P. No. 5653 of 2022 had been complied with, a fact confirmed by the petitioner's counsel. No further orders were deemed necessary.

instruction: Summarize the facts, legal issue, provisions applied, and the High Court’s decision.
question: What did the High Court decide regarding Challenging the judgment and confiscation order in SC No. 286 of 2015 for offenses under Sections 420, 386, 496, 327 read with Section 34 of IPC. under Section 454(2) Cr.P.C. provides for appeals against confiscation orders.?
facts: The appellants are challenging a judgment and confiscation order dated 01.05.2023 passed by the Assistant Sessions Judge, Mahbubabad. The appeal is filed under Section 454 (2) of Cr.P.C. against offences punishable under Sections 420, 386, 496, 327 read with Section 34 of IPC.
charge: Challenging the judgment and confiscation order in SC No. 286 of 2015 for offenses under Sections 420, 386, 496, 327 read with Section 34 of IPC.
law_content: Section 454(2) Cr.P.C. provides for appeals against confiscation orders.
judgment: The court disposed of the criminal appeal as the counsel for the appellants intended to file a fresh appeal before the concerned court as per the Bharatiya Nagarik Suraksha Sanhita, 2023. The registry was directed to return the original bundle to the counsel.

instruction: Summarize the facts, legal issue, provisions applied, and the High Court’s decision.
question: What did the High Court decide regarding Failure of police to register a criminal case and arrest alleged offenders based on a private complaint. under Article 226 of the Constitution of India allows High Courts to issue writs, including writs in the nature of mandamus, to direct any person or authority, including government and its officers, to perform their public duties or to refrain from doing something illegal. In this case, it was invoked to direct the police to perform their statutory duty of registering a cognizable offense.?
facts: The petitioner lodged a criminal complaint with the police alleging cognizable offenses. The police failed to register a case or arrest the alleged culprits. The petitioner filed a writ petition seeking a mandamus directing the police to register the FIR and arrest the accused.
charge: Failure of police to register a criminal case and arrest alleged offenders based on a private complaint.
law_content: Article 226 of the Constitution of India allows High Courts to issue writs, including writs in the nature of mandamus, to direct any person or authority, including government and its officers, to perform their public duties or to refrain from doing something illegal. In this case, it was invoked to direct the police to perform their statutory duty of registering a cognizable offense.
judgment: The Court was considering a writ petition seeking a mandamus to direct the police to register a criminal case and arrest the alleged culprits based on the petitioner's complaint. The specific relief sought was to declare the inaction of the police as illegal and to direct them to register the case and make arrests.

instruction: Summarize the facts, legal issue, provisions applied, and the High Court’s decision.
question: What did the High Court decide regarding Quashing of criminal proceedings. under Section 482 Cr.P.C. - The High Court has the power to issue such orders for the ends of justice or to prevent abuse of the process of any Court.?
facts: The petitioners, including Esperanza Corporate (P) Ltd and its Managing Director, filed criminal petitions seeking to quash proceedings in CC No. 16 of 2016. The petitions also sought a stay on further proceedings, including the personal appearance of the accused. A separate petition was filed to vacate an interim order. The respondent is the State of Telangana and its police.
charge: Quashing of criminal proceedings.
law_content: Section 482 Cr.P.C. - The High Court has the power to issue such orders for the ends of justice or to prevent abuse of the process of any Court.
judgment: The case was dismissed.

instruction: Summarize the facts, legal issue, provisions applied, and the High Court’s decision.
question: What did the High Court decide regarding Quashing of criminal proceedings based on compromise. under Section 482 Cr.P.C. - The High Court has the power to issue such orders for the ends of justice or to prevent abuse of the process of any Court. Section 320(5) Cr.P.C. - Procedure for compounding of certain offences where there is no provision for composition of such offence.?
facts: The petitioners, Durga Reddy Mekala and Mohith Reddy Mekala, filed a criminal petition seeking to quash proceedings in Crime No. 263 of 2023. An interlocutory application was filed to record a compromise between the petitioners and the defacto complainant. The court had directed the parties to appear before the High Court Legal Services Committee for identification.
charge: Quashing of criminal proceedings based on compromise.
law_content: Section 482 Cr.P.C. - The High Court has the power to issue such orders for the ends of justice or to prevent abuse of the process of any Court. Section 320(5) Cr.P.C. - Procedure for compounding of certain offences where there is no provision for composition of such offence.
judgment: The criminal petition was allowed, and the proceedings were quashed subject to the petitioners paying specified amounts to the Director, Sainik Welfare, Hyderabad, and the Telangana High Court Advocates Association within two weeks.

instruction: Summarize the facts, legal issue, provisions applied, and the High Court’s decision.
question: What did the High Court decide regarding Quashing of criminal proceedings for alleged offences under IPC Sections 406, 420, and 506. under Section 482 CrPC - Saving of inherent powers of High Court. (Used to quash criminal proceedings). Sections 406, 420, 506 IPC - Offences related to criminal breach of trust, cheating, and criminal intimidation.?
facts: The petitioner, arrayed as an accused, seeks to quash the proceedings in a criminal case registered for alleged offences of criminal breach of trust, cheating, and criminal intimidation. The petitioner also sought interim relief to stay further proceedings and arrest.
charge: Quashing of criminal proceedings for alleged offences under IPC Sections 406, 420, and 506.
law: Code of Criminal Procedure, Indian Penal Code
law_content: Section 482 CrPC - Saving of inherent powers of High Court. (Used to quash criminal proceedings). Sections 406, 420, 506 IPC - Offences related to criminal breach of trust, cheating, and criminal intimidation.
judgment: The Court directed the petitioner to appear before the Investigating Officer by a specified date and instructed the Investigating Officer to follow the procedure laid down under Section 41-A CrPC and relevant Supreme Court guidelines. No coercive steps were to be taken against the petitioner until the investigation is completed. The Criminal Petition was disposed of.

instruction: Summarize the facts, legal issue, provisions applied, and the High Court’s decision.
question: What did the High Court decide regarding Anticipatory Bail under Section 438 of Cr.P.C. deals with the provision for anticipatory bail. Section 43 of the Unlawful Activities (Prevention) Act, 1967, prohibits the grant of anticipatory bail for offenses under that Act.?
facts: The petitioner sought anticipatory bail under Section 438 of Cr.P.C. in connection with FIR No. 82 of 2023. The FIR was registered for offenses under Section 120(b) r/w 34 IPC, Sections 13(2), 17, 18 of the Unlawful Activities (Prevention) Act-1967, and Section 5 of the Explosives Substances Act-1908.
charge: Anticipatory Bail
law: Cr.P.C., Unlawful Activities (Prevention) Act, 1967, Explosives Substances Act, 1908
law_content: Section 438 of Cr.P.C. deals with the provision for anticipatory bail. Section 43 of the Unlawful Activities (Prevention) Act, 1967, prohibits the grant of anticipatory bail for offenses under that Act.
judgment: The petition was dismissed because Section 43 of the Unlawful Activities (Prevention) Act prohibits anticipatory bail for offenses under that Act. However, the court directed that if the petitioner surrenders and files a bail application, it should be disposed of within two working days.

instruction: Summarize the facts, legal issue, provisions applied, and the High Court’s decision.
question: What did the High Court decide regarding Anticipatory Bail under Section 438 of Cr.P.C. allows for the grant of anticipatory bail. Section 306 IPC deals with abetment of suicide.?
facts: The petitioner sought anticipatory bail in connection with Crime No. 419 of 2023, registered for the offense under Section 306 r/w 34 of the Indian Penal Code. The allegation was that the petitioner had demanded repayment of a loan and threatened the deceased, leading to their suicide.
charge: Anticipatory Bail
law_content: Section 438 of Cr.P.C. allows for the grant of anticipatory bail. Section 306 IPC deals with abetment of suicide.
judgment: The court granted anticipatory bail, subject to the petitioner surrendering before the police station, furnishing a personal bond, and appearing regularly for investigation for a period of four weeks, finding that prima facie, the act of abetment was not made out from the narration of the incident.

instruction: Summarize the facts, legal issue, provisions applied, and the High Court’s decision.
question: What did the High Court decide regarding Regular Bail under Section 437 and 439 of Cr.P.C. deal with the grant of bail. Sections 51 & 53 of the NDPS Act relate to offenses concerning narcotic drugs and psychotropic substances.?
facts: The petitioner, accused No. 4, sought regular bail in a case involving offenses under Section 167(2) of Cr.P.C. and Sections 51 & 53 of the Narcotic Drugs and Psychotropic Substances Act, 1985. Allegations related to the seizure of 210 kgs of dry ganja.
charge: Regular Bail
law: Cr.P.C., Narcotic Drugs and Psychotropic Substances Act, 1985
law_content: Section 437 and 439 of Cr.P.C. deal with the grant of bail. Sections 51 & 53 of the NDPS Act relate to offenses concerning narcotic drugs and psychotropic substances.
judgment: The court granted regular bail. This was based on the delay in sampling the seized contraband and the alleged violation of the Supreme Court's observations in Union of India vs. Mohanlal regarding the promptness of sampling. Conditions were imposed for appearance and cooperation with the investigation.

instruction: Summarize the facts, legal issue, provisions applied, and the High Court’s decision.
question: What did the High Court decide regarding Quashing of FIR proceedings in Crime No. 483 of 2019. under Section 482 of Cr.P.C. - Saving of inherent powers of High Court. The High Court may make such orders as may be necessary to give effect to any order under this Code, or to prevent abuse of the process of any Court or otherwise to secure the ends of justice.?
facts: The petitioners filed a petition under Section 482 of the CrPC seeking to quash FIR No. 483 of 2019. The Additional Public Prosecutor submitted that the investigation is complete and a charge sheet has been filed.
charge: Quashing of FIR proceedings in Crime No. 483 of 2019.
law_content: Section 482 of Cr.P.C. - Saving of inherent powers of High Court. The High Court may make such orders as may be necessary to give effect to any order under this Code, or to prevent abuse of the process of any Court or otherwise to secure the ends of justice.
judgment: The criminal petitions were dismissed as infructuous because the investigation was completed and a charge sheet was filed, granting liberty to the petitioners to file a fresh petition challenging the charge sheet.

question: What did the High Court decide regarding Quashing of proceedings in C.C No. 980 of 2018 for offences under Sec.498-A, 406 IPC and Sec.3 and 4 of DP Act. under Section 482 of Cr.P.C. - Saving of inherent powers of High Court. charge: Quashing of proceedings in C.C No. 980 of 2018 for offences under Sec.498-A, 406 IPC and Sec.3 and 4 of DP Act.
law_content: Section 482 of Cr.P.C. - Saving of inherent powers of High Court. Indian Penal Code (IPC) Section 498-A - Husband or relative of husband of a woman subjecting her to cruelty. Section 406 - Punishment for criminal breach of trust. Dowry Prohibition Act (DP Act) Section 3 - Penalty for giving or taking dowry. Section 4 - Penalty for demanding dowry.

question: What did the High Court decide regarding Quashing of proceedings under Sections 498-A and 506 of IPC and Sections 3 and 4 of the DP Act based on compromise. under Section 482 of Cr.P.C - Saving of inherent powers of High Court to make such orders as may be necessary to give effect to any order under this Code, or to prevent abuse of the process of any Court or otherwise to secure the ends of justice. Section 320(6) of Cr.P.C - Allows for compounding of offences by the victim. Sections 498-A and 506 of IPC, Sections 3 and 4 of the DP Act relate to cruelty by husband or relatives, criminal intimidation, and dowry prohibition respectively.?
facts: The petitioner/accused sought to quash proceedings initiated under Sections 498-A and 506 of IPC and Sections 3 and 4 of the DP Act. The criminal petition was filed after the parties entered into a compromise.
charge: Quashing of proceedings under Sections 498-A and 506 of IPC and Sections 3 and 4 of the DP Act based on compromise.
law_content: Section 482 of Cr.P.C - Saving of inherent powers of High Court to make such orders as may be necessary to give effect to any order under this Code, or to prevent abuse of the process of any Court or otherwise to secure the ends of justice. Section 320(6) of Cr.P.C - Allows for compounding of offences by the victim. Sections 498-A and 506 of IPC, Sections 3 and 4 of the DP Act relate to cruelty by husband or relatives, criminal intimidation, and dowry prohibition respectively.
judgment: The High Court allowed the criminal petition and quashed the proceedings based on the compromise entered into between the parties, as evidenced by the joint memos filed and the report from the High Court Legal Services Committee confirming the identity of the parties.

question: What did the High Court decide regarding To declare the inaction of the police in registering a FIR as illegal and arbitrary, and to direct them to register the FIR. under Sections 420 (cheating), 468 (forgery for purpose of cheating), and 471 (using as genuine a forged document) of the Indian Penal Code define criminal offenses related to fraud and forgery.?
facts: The petitioner lodged a complaint with the police alleging commission of a cognizable offense by the respondent. However, the police did not register a FIR. The petitioner filed a writ petition seeking a direction to register the FIR.
charge: To declare the inaction of the police in registering a FIR as illegal and arbitrary, and to direct them to register the FIR.
law_content: Sections 420 (cheating), 468 (forgery for purpose of cheating), and 471 (using as genuine a forged document) of the Indian Penal Code define criminal offenses related to fraud and forgery.
judgment: The writ petition was closed as the police had registered a Zero FIR under Sections 420, 468, and 471 of IPC based on the petitioner's complaint and transferred it for investigation to the jurisdictional police station. The court found the petitioner's grievance redressed.

facts: The petitioner filed a contempt case alleging violation of a High Court order dated 10.07.2023. The respondents submitted a letter stating that the decretal charges have been deposited, indicating compliance with the court's order.
charge: Contempt of Court
law_content: Sections 10 to 12 of the Contempt of Courts Act, 1971, which deal with the powers of the courts to punish for contempt and the procedure related to contempt proceedings.
judgment: The High Court closed the contempt case, finding that the orders of the court had been complied with, and accordingly, there were no orders as to costs.

question: What did the High Court decide regarding Seeking regular bail under Sections 437 and 439 of Cr.P.C. under Sections 437 and 439 of Cr.P.C. pertaining to bail, and Sections 8(c), 20(b)(ii)(C), 27-A, 28, and 29 of the NDPS Act, 1985, which define the offences related to narcotic drugs and psychotropic substances.?
facts: The petitioner is accused No.1 in a case registered under the NDPS Act. He has been in custody for three years. The petitioner sought regular bail on grounds similar to those on which bail was granted to another accused (A-4), specifically the prosecution's failure to conclude witness examination.
charge: Seeking regular bail under Sections 437 and 439 of Cr.P.C.
law: Code of Criminal Procedure, 1973 & NDPS Act, 1985
law_content: Sections 437 and 439 of Cr.P.C. pertaining to bail, and Sections 8(c), 20(b)(ii)(C), 27-A, 28, and 29 of the NDPS Act, 1985, which define the offences related to narcotic drugs and psychotropic substances.
judgment: The High Court allowed the criminal petition, granting regular bail to the petitioner/accused No.1, subject to specific conditions including executing a personal bond, furnishing sureties, and appearing before the police station on Mondays for eight weeks and thereafter as required.

question: What did the High Court decide regarding Quashing of criminal proceedings in C.C.No. 345 of 2020. under Section 482 Cr.P.C. - Saving of inherent powers of High Court to make orders necessary to give effect to any order under this Code, or to prevent abuse of the process of any Court or otherwise to secure the ends of justice.?
facts: The petitioners, mother and brother of accused No. 1, approached the High Court seeking to quash criminal proceedings against them. They argued that they reside separately from the de facto complainant and accused No. 1. The allegations of harassment were bald and lacked specific evidence. The court was asked to consider the lack of direct involvement and the general nature of allegations.
charge: Quashing of criminal proceedings in C.C.No. 345 of 2020.
law_content: Section 482 Cr.P.C. - Saving of inherent powers of High Court to make orders necessary to give effect to any order under this Code, or to prevent abuse of the process of any Court or otherwise to secure the ends of justice.
judgment: The High Court quashed the criminal proceedings against the petitioners (Accused No. 2 & 3) as the allegations were bald and lacked specific evidence, and they resided separately from the accused No. 1 and the de facto complainant.

question: What did the High Court decide regarding Seeking parole for medical treatment and family reasons. under Article 226 of the Constitution of India - Allows High Courts to issue writs for enforcement of fundamental rights or for any other purpose. Jail Manual provisions regarding parole criteria.?
facts: The petitioner's husband, a convicted prisoner, requires eye surgery and wishes to see his bedridden mother. He has undergone a significant portion of his sentence. The jail authorities noted he is involved in other under-trial cases, which might affect parole consideration.
charge: Seeking parole for medical treatment and family reasons.
law_content: Article 226 of the Constitution of India - Allows High Courts to issue writs for enforcement of fundamental rights or for any other purpose. Jail Manual provisions regarding parole criteria.
judgment: The Court directed the jail authorities to grant parole for 20 days for the prisoner to undergo eye surgery and for personal reasons, with a clear instruction to not indulge in criminal activity and to surrender upon completion of parole.

judgment: The High Court allowed the criminal petition, setting aside the trial court's docket order. The court directed the trial court to consider the police's application afresh after giving the petitioner an opportunity of hearing, in the interest of justice.

question: What did the High Court decide regarding Quashing of FIR No. 148 of 2023 and stay of coercive steps. under Section 482 Cr.P.C. empowers the High Court to make such orders as may be necessary to give effect to any order under the Code, or to prevent abuse of the process of any Court or otherwise to secure the ends of justice. State of Bihar scrupulously, consider the explanation offered by the petitioners, and complete the investigation. No coercive steps were to be taken against the petitioners until the investigation was completed.

law_content: Section 378 (4) & (5) CrPC - Appeals in cases instituted upon complaint and appeals by the State Government or any person.

question: What did the High Court decide regarding Criminal Revision Case filed under Sections 397 & 401 of CrPC against the judgment confirming conviction and sentence under Section 392 read with 397 IPC. under Section 392 IPC - Punishment for robbery. Section 397 IPC - Punishment for robbery or dacoity with attempt to cause death or grievous hurt. Section 401 CrPC - Revision of other orders of inferior criminal courts.?
facts: The revision petitioner was convicted under Sections 392 and 397 IPC and sentenced to seven years imprisonment. The conviction was confirmed in appeal. The petitioner contended that the ingredients for Section 397 IPC were not met and that his identity was doubtful due to discrepancies in identification. The prosecution's case involved an auto driver robbing a woman after threatening her and taking her jewelry.
charge: Criminal Revision Case filed under Sections 397 & 401 of CrPC against the judgment confirming conviction and sentence under Section 392 read with 397 IPC.
law: Indian Penal Code, Criminal Procedure Code
law_content: Section 392 IPC - Punishment for robbery. Section 397 IPC - Punishment for robbery or dacoity with attempt to cause death or grievous hurt. Section 401 CrPC - Revision of other orders of inferior criminal courts.
judgment: The Court found that the ingredients for Section 397 IPC were not made out as no deadly weapon was used or grievous hurt was caused in the process of committing robbery. However, the recovery of stolen items at the instance of the accused made the conviction under Section 392 IPC sustainable. The sentence was reduced to two years rigorous imprisonment under Section 392 IPC.

question: What did the High Court decide regarding Seeking release of a seized vehicle pending confiscation proceedings under the Telangana Excise Act, 1968. under Section 34(E) of the Telangana Excise Act, 1968 pertains to offenses under the Act. Section 45 of the Act outlines items liable for confiscation. Section 46 mandates the production of seized items before the Deputy Commissioner for confiscation proceedings. Section 46-C provides for an appeal against confiscation orders. Article 226 of the Constitution allows for the issuance of writs, and Section 151 of the CPC deals with inherent powers of the court.?
facts: The petitioner's vehicle was seized in connection with Crime No. 97 of 2023, registered for an offense under Section 34(E) of the Telangana Excise Act, 1968. The petitioner sought the release of the vehicle, arguing that the inaction of the authorities in releasing it was illegal and arbitrary.
charge: Seeking release of a seized vehicle pending confiscation proceedings under the Telangana Excise Act, 1968.

law_content: Section 34(E) of the Telangana Excise Act, 1968 pertains to offenses under the Act. Section 45 of the Act outlines items liable for confiscation. Section 46 mandates the production of seized items before the Deputy Commissioner for confiscation proceedings. Section 46-C provides for an appeal against confiscation orders. Article 226 of the Constitution allows for the issuance of writs, and Section 151 of the CPC deals with inherent powers of the court.
judgment: The High Court directed the release of the seized vehicle subject to the petitioner furnishing a fixed deposit receipt of Rs. 50,000/-, an undertaking not to alienate the vehicle or the fixed deposit, and producing the original RC book. The court noted that this was in line with its consistent view in similar matters.

judgment: The bail was granted as the seized quantity of cocaine was less than a small quantity, and there were no other pending cases against the petitioner, despite being identified as a peddler.

instruction: Summarize the facts, legal issue, provisions applied, and the High Court’s decision.
question: What did the High Court decide regarding Quashing of FIR and proceedings under Section 482 Cr.P.C. under Section 482 Cr.P.C. - Saving of inherent powers of High Court; Section 376(2)(n) IPC - rape of woman by a person having control over her, or by a person in a position of trust or in a relationship where the victim is dependent on him, or where the offender is in a position of authority; POCSO Act Sections 5 & 6 - Punishment for penetrative sexual assault and sexual assault; PCM Act Section 9 - Prohibition of child marriage.?
facts: The petitioner is accused of marrying a minor girl, resulting in FIR No. 158/2023 for offences including rape of a minor and under the POCSO Act and PCM Act. The petitioner claims the marriage was consensual and the girl was of age, with conflicting evidence on her date of birth.
charge: Quashing of FIR and proceedings under Section 482 Cr.P.C.
law: Cr.P.C., IPC, POCSO Act, PCM Act
law_content: Section 482 Cr.P.C. - Saving of inherent powers of High Court; Section 376(2)(n) IPC - rape of woman by a person having control over her, or by a person in a position of trust or in a relationship where the victim is dependent on him, or where the offender is in a position of authority; POCSO Act Sections 5 & 6 - Punishment for penetrative sexual assault and sexual assault; PCM Act Section 9 - Prohibition of child marriage.
judgment: The court noted that the correct date of birth of the girl is yet to be ascertained. Even if she was below 18 at the time of marriage, it would be a voidable marriage under the Hindu Marriage Act at her option after attaining majority. Given that she is allegedly happily married and has children, the court found it appropriate to allow the investigation to proceed and gather further evidence.

instruction: Summarize the facts, legal issue, provisions applied, and the High Court’s decision.
question: What did the High Court decide regarding Conviction for offences under SCs/STs (POA) Act and IPC. under Section 3(i)(x) of the SCs/STs (POA) Act, 1989 - Intentional insult or intimidation with intent to humiliate a member of a Scheduled Caste or Scheduled Tribe in any place within public view; Section 323 IPC - Punishment for voluntarily causing hurt; Section 374(2) Cr.P.C. - Appeal from conviction.?
facts: The appellant was convicted for the offence under Section 3(i)(x) of the SCs/STs (POA) Act, 1989 and Section 323 of the IPC. The prosecution alleged that the appellant abused and beat the complainant, who belongs to an SC community. The complainant's version was supported by two witnesses.
charge: Conviction for offences under SCs/STs (POA) Act and IPC.
law_content: Section 3(i)(x) of the SCs/STs (POA) Act, 1989 - Intentional insult or intimidation with intent to humiliate a member of a Scheduled Caste or Scheduled Tribe in any place within public view; Section 323 IPC - Punishment for voluntarily causing hurt; Section 374(2) Cr.P.C. - Appeal from conviction.
judgment: The Court found that while the witnesses testified to the beating, they did not state the specific words uttered by the accused. Therefore, it could not be inferred that the accused intended to insult or abuse the complainant based on their caste. The ingredients of Section 3(i)(x) of the SCs/STs (POA) Act were not made out. The conviction under Section 3(i)(x) was set aside, but the conviction and sentence under Section 323 IPC were maintained.

instruction: Summarize the facts, legal issue, provisions applied, and the High Court’s decision.
question: What did the High Court decide regarding Declaration that the inaction of respondent No. 3 in not following Section 154(3) of Cr.PC and not registering an FIR against respondents 7 to 11 is illegal, arbitrary, and violative of constitutional rights, and a direction to register FIR and take action. under Article 226 of the Constitution of India provides for the writ jurisdiction of the High Court. Section 154(3) of Cr.PC deals with the procedure when a person who is required to record information under Section 154(1) refuses to do so. The judgment also references guidelines from the Supreme Court in Lalita Kumari v. Govt. of U.P. regarding the registration of FIRs.?
facts: The petitioner lodged a complaint alleging trespass, house breaking, and theft by respondents 7 to 11. The petitioner contended that the police (respondents 3 to 6) failed to register an FIR and take action as per Section 154(3) of Cr.PC. The police, however, stated that the complaint was found to be false after an inquiry and was closed.
charge: Declaration that the inaction of respondent No. 3 in not following Section 154(3) of Cr.PC and not registering an FIR against respondents 7 to 11 is illegal, arbitrary, and violative of constitutional rights, and a direction to register FIR and take action.
law: Article 226 of the Constitution of India, Section 154(3) of the Code of Criminal Procedure (Cr.PC), and principles from the case of Lalita Kumari vs. Govt. of U.P.
law_content: Article 226 of the Constitution of India provides for the writ jurisdiction of the High Court. Section 154(3) of Cr.PC deals with the procedure when a person who is required to record information under Section 154(1) refuses to do so. The judgment also references guidelines from the Supreme Court in Lalita Kumari v. Govt. of U.P. regarding the registration of FIRs.
judgment: The police conducted an inquiry and found the petitioner's complaint to be false, subsequently closing the matter. As the police had acted on the complaint, the cause of action for the writ petition no longer survived.

instruction: Summarize the facts, legal issue, provisions applied, and the High Court’s decision.
question: What did the High Court decide regarding Quashing of FIR No. 86 of 2014 and a stay on arrest/harassment. under Article 226 of the Constitution of India allows the High Courts to issue writs, including Mandamus, for the enforcement of fundamental rights and for any other purpose.?
facts: The petitioners filed a writ petition seeking to quash an FIR registered against them, arguing it was illegal and unconstitutional. They also sought a direction for the police not to arrest or harass them.
charge: Quashing of FIR No. 86 of 2014 and a stay on arrest/harassment.
law_content: Article 226 of the Constitution of India allows the High Courts to issue writs, including Mandamus, for the enforcement of fundamental rights and for any other purpose.
judgment: The writ petition was dismissed as infructuous because the cause of action no longer survived.

instruction: Summarize the facts, legal issue, provisions applied, and the High Court’s decision.
question: What did the High Court decide regarding Seeking expeditious disposal of a pending criminal case. under Section 482 of the Cr.P.C.: This section provides inherent powers to the High Court to make such orders as may be necessary to give effect to any order under the Code, or to prevent abuse of the process of any Court or otherwise to secure the ends of justice.?
facts: The petitioner, an accused in a criminal case (C.C. No. 1529 of 2021), has been selected for the post of Staff Nurse. To enable consideration for this employment, the petitioner filed a criminal petition seeking a direction to the trial court to expedite the disposal of the pending case.
charge: Seeking expeditious disposal of a pending criminal case.
law_content: Section 482 of the Cr.P.C.: This section provides inherent powers to the High Court to make such orders as may be necessary to give effect to any order under the Code, or to prevent abuse of the process of any Court or otherwise to secure the ends of justice.
judgment: The High Court directed the trial court to conclude the trial in the mentioned criminal case within a period of three months from the date of receipt of a copy of the order.

instruction: Summarize the facts, legal issue, provisions applied, and the High Court’s decision.
question: What did the High Court decide regarding Quashing of proceedings under FIR No. 1328 of 2022 and seeking interim relief against arrest. under Section 482 Cr.P.C. relates to the inherent powers of the High Court to make orders necessary to give effect to any order under this Code, or to prevent abuse of the process of any Court or otherwise to secure the ends of justice. Sections 420 and 417 IPC deal with cheating and punishment for cheating.?
facts: The petitioners, accused numbers 3 and 4 in FIR No. 1328 of 2022, filed a criminal petition seeking to quash the proceedings against them. They also sought a stay of arrest until the disposal of the petition.
charge: Quashing of proceedings under FIR No. 1328 of 2022 and seeking interim relief against arrest.
law: Code of Criminal Procedure (Cr.P.C.), Indian Penal Code (IPC)
law_content: Section 482 Cr.P.C. relates to the inherent powers of the High Court to make orders necessary to give effect to any order under this Code, or to prevent abuse of the process of any Court or otherwise to secure the ends of justice. Sections 420 and 417 IPC deal with cheating and punishment for cheating.
judgment: The High Court directed the petitioners to appear before the Investigating Officer and cooperate with the investigation. The Investigating Officer was directed to follow the procedure under Section 41-A Cr.P.C. and the guidelines in Arnesh Kumar v. State of Bihar. No coercive steps were to be taken against the petitioners until the investigation is completed. The criminal petition was disposed of.

instruction: Summarize the facts, legal issue, provisions applied, and the High Court’s decision.
question: What did the High Court decide regarding Anticipatory bail under Section 438 of Cr.P.C. under Section 438 of Cr.P.C. empowers the High Court or Court of Session to direct that in the event of arrest any person shall be released on bail. Sections 306 and 498-A of the Indian Penal Code relate to abetment of suicide and cruelty by husband or relatives of husband, respectively.?
facts: The petitioners, accused Nos. 2 and 3, sought anticipatory bail in connection with FIR No. 14 of 2024 for offences under Sections 306 and 498-A r/w 34 of the IPC. The FIR was registered based on a complaint alleging that the deceased committed suicide. The petitioners are the paternal uncle and cousin of the deceased's husband (accused No. 1).
charge: Anticipatory bail under Section 438 of Cr.P.C.
law_content: Section 438 of Cr.P.C. empowers the High Court or Court of Session to direct that in the event of arrest any person shall be released on bail. Sections 306 and 498-A of the Indian Penal Code relate to abetment of suicide and cruelty by husband or relatives of husband, respectively.
judgment: The Court granted anticipatory bail to the petitioners, directing them to surrender before the Station House Officer and furnish a personal bond of Rs. 25,000/- each with two sureties. They were also directed to appear before the police on Mondays for four weeks and cooperate with the investigation, finding that prima facie no specific allegations of harassment were made against them.

instruction: Summarize the facts, legal issue, provisions applied, and the High Court’s decision.
question: What did the High Court decide regarding To quash the order dismissing the petition for defreezing bank accounts and to defreeze the petitioner's bank accounts. under Section 482 Cr.P.C. - Saving of inherent powers of High Court to make orders necessary to give effect to any order under this Code, or to prevent abuse of the process of any Court or otherwise to secure the ends of justice.?
facts: The petitioner, accused No. 2, filed a criminal petition under Section 482 of Cr.P.C. seeking to set aside an order that dismissed her petition for defreezing her bank accounts. The accounts were frozen in connection with a crime registered for cheating. The petitioner argued that her accounts were frozen without any court order and that the delay in filing the charge sheet was causing her severe prejudice.
charge: To quash the order dismissing the petition for defreezing bank accounts and to defreeze the petitioner's bank accounts.
law_content: Section 482 Cr.P.C. - Saving of inherent powers of High Court to make orders necessary to give effect to any order under this Code, or to prevent abuse of the process of any Court or otherwise to secure the ends of justice.
judgment: The High Court noted that the freezing of the petitioner's bank accounts occurred without any court order and that the delay in filing the charge sheet was significant. The court agreed that freezing the accounts would cause grave prejudice to the petitioner, especially since her guilt had not yet been proven.

instruction: Summarize the facts, legal issue, provisions applied, and the High Court’s decision.
question: What did the High Court decide regarding Quashing of proceedings in DVC No. 19 of 2023 filed under Section 12 of the Protection of Women from Domestic Violence Act, 2005. under Section 482 of Cr.P.C. pertains to the inherent powers of the High Court to make orders to secure the ends of justice. Section 12 of the Protection of Women from Domestic Violence Act, 2005 deals with the procedure for filing a complaint by an aggrieved person. Section 29 of the same Act provides for an appeal against certain orders.?
facts: The petitioners filed a criminal petition under Section 482 of Cr.P.C. seeking to quash proceedings in a Domestic Violence Case (DVC) filed under Section 12 of the Protection of Women from Domestic Violence Act, 2005. The main contention was that the proceedings were not maintainable.
charge: Quashing of proceedings in DVC No. 19 of 2023 filed under Section 12 of the Protection of Women from Domestic Violence Act, 2005.
law: Cr.P.C., Protection of Women from Domestic Violence Act, 2005
law_content: Section 482 of Cr.P.C. pertains to the inherent powers of the High Court to make orders to secure the ends of justice. Section 12 of the Protection of Women from Domestic Violence Act, 2005 deals with the procedure for filing a complaint by an aggrieved person. Section 29 of the same Act provides for an appeal against certain orders.
judgment: The High Court held that a petition to quash proceedings in a Domestic Violence Case is not maintainable under Section 482 of Cr.P.C. when an efficacious remedy of appeal is available under Section 29 of the Protection of Women from Domestic Violence Act, 2005. The petitioners were granted liberty to avail the appellate remedy, and their appearance in the DVC case was dispensed with except when required by the trial court.

instruction: Summarize the facts, legal issue, provisions applied, and the High Court’s decision.
question: What did the High Court decide regarding Seeking anticipatory bail under Section 438 of Cr.P.C. in connection with an unregistered crime. under Section 438 of Cr.P.C. pertains to the procedure for granting anticipatory bail. The court also referenced guidelines from the Supreme Court in Arnesh Kumar v. State of Bihar regarding procedures when a crime is registered for offenses punishable up to 7 years.?
facts: Petitioners sought anticipatory bail in connection with an unregistered crime. The wife of the first petitioner had filed a complaint, leading to apprehension of arrest. The police stated that no crime had been registered at the time.
charge: Seeking anticipatory bail under Section 438 of Cr.P.C. in connection with an unregistered crime.
law_content: Section 438 of Cr.P.C. pertains to the procedure for granting anticipatory bail. The court also referenced guidelines from the Supreme Court in Arnesh Kumar v. State of Bihar regarding procedures when a crime is registered for offenses punishable up to 7 years.
judgment: The court directed that in the event of registration of a crime for an offense punishable up to 7 years, the police must follow the procedure laid down under Section 41A of Cr.P.C. and the guidelines from Arnesh Kumar v. State of Bihar. The petitioners were also directed to cooperate with the investigating officer.

instruction: Summarize the facts, legal issue, provisions applied, and the High Court’s decision.
question: What did the High Court decide regarding Challenge to an order of maintenance granted by the Family Court. under Section 397 and 401 of Cr.PC allow for revision of criminal orders. Section 498A IPC deals with cruelty by a husband or his relatives. The Dowry Prohibition Act prohibits the giving or taking of dowry.?
facts: The petitioner's marriage was performed with dowry. Later, the wife gave birth to a child, and the petitioner allegedly demanded additional dowry, leading to harassment. The wife had filed a complaint under Section 498A IPC and provisions of the Dowry Prohibition Act. Subsequently, she filed a petition for maintenance before the Family Court, which awarded maintenance to the wife and child. The husband has filed this Criminal Revision Case challenging the maintenance order.
charge: Challenge to an order of maintenance granted by the Family Court.
law: Section 397 and 401 of Cr.PC, Section 498A IPC, Dowry Prohibition Act
law_content: Section 397 and 401 of Cr.PC allow for revision of criminal orders. Section 498A IPC deals with cruelty by a husband or his relatives. The Dowry Prohibition Act prohibits the giving or taking of dowry.
judgment: The Criminal Revision Case was filed challenging the order of maintenance granted by the Family Court. The arguments from both sides regarding the propriety of the maintenance award were presented.

instruction: Summarize the facts, legal issue, provisions applied, and the High Court’s decision.
question: What did the High Court decide regarding Reduction of personal bond amount in a criminal case. under Section 482 Cr.P.C. empowers the High Court to make such orders as may be necessary to give effect to any order under the Code, or to prevent abuse of the process of any Court or otherwise to secure the ends of justice. Sections 451 and 457 Cr.P.C. deal with the disposal of property during the inquiry or trial and the procedure when property is stolen and found.?
facts: The petitioner filed a criminal petition under Section 482 of Cr.P.C. challenging the order of the Junior Civil Judge Cum Judicial Magistrate of First Class regarding the execution of a personal bond of Rs. 4,00,000/- with one surety. The petitioner sought to set aside this condition.
charge: Reduction of personal bond amount in a criminal case.
law_content: Section 482 Cr.P.C. empowers the High Court to make such orders as may be necessary to give effect to any order under the Code, or to prevent abuse of the process of any Court or otherwise to secure the ends of justice. Sections 451 and 457 Cr.P.C. deal with the disposal of property during the inquiry or trial and the procedure when property is stolen and found.
judgment: The High Court reduced the personal bond amount from Rs. 4,00,000/- to Rs. 50,000/- with one surety, while upholding other conditions for the release of the vehicle, in line with a previous order of the court in a similar matter.

instruction: Summarize the facts, legal issue, provisions applied, and the High Court’s decision.
question: What did the High Court decide regarding Grant of regular bail to the petitioner/sole accused. under Sections 437 and 439 of the Cr.P.C. deal with the provisions for granting bail in cases other than those punishable with death or life imprisonment, and the powers of the High Court and Court of Session to grant bail, respectively. Section 376 of the IPC defines the offense of rape.?
facts: The petitioner sought regular bail in a criminal case where he is accused of committing rape. The investigation is complete, and a charge sheet has been filed. The de-facto complainant alleged that the rape occurred when she was under intoxication.
charge: Grant of regular bail to the petitioner/sole accused.
law: Code of Criminal Procedure, Sections 437 and 439; Indian Penal Code, Section 376
law_content: Sections 437 and 439 of the Cr.P.C. deal with the provisions for granting bail in cases other than those punishable with death or life imprisonment, and the powers of the High Court and Court of Session to grant bail, respectively. Section 376 of the IPC defines the offense of rape.
judgment: The High Court allowed the criminal petition, granting regular bail to the petitioner/accused subject to furnishing a personal bond and two sureties, and adherence to conditions stipulated under Section 437(3) of Cr.P.C.

instruction: Summarize the facts, legal issue, provisions applied, and the High Court’s decision.
question: What did the High Court decide regarding Quashing of FIR and proceedings for alleged offences of cheating and forgery. under Section 482 Cr.P.C. empowers the High Court to make such orders as may be necessary to give effect to any order under the Code, or to prevent abuse of the process of any Court or otherwise to secure the ends of justice. Section 41-A Cr.P.C. deals with the procedure when a person is required to appear before a police officer.?
facts: The petitioners, accused in FIR No. 10 of 2024 registered for offences under Sections 419, 420, 468, and 471 of IPC, filed a petition under Section 482 Cr.P.C. to quash the proceedings. The punishment for the alleged offences is less than seven years.
charge: Quashing of FIR and proceedings for alleged offences of cheating and forgery.
law_content: Section 482 Cr.P.C. empowers the High Court to make such orders as may be necessary to give effect to any order under the Code, or to prevent abuse of the process of any Court or otherwise to secure the ends of justice. Section 41-A Cr.P.C. deals with the procedure when a person is required to appear before a police officer.
judgment: The High Court directed the petitioners/accused to appear before the Investigating Officer and cooperate with the investigation. The Investigating Officer was directed to follow the procedure under Section 41-A Cr.P.C. and the guidelines in Arnesh Kumar v. State of Bihar. No arrest shall be made until the police investigate and decide on documents filed by the petitioners.

instruction: Summarize the facts, legal issue, provisions applied, and the High Court’s decision.
question: What did the High Court decide regarding Quashing of FIR proceedings. under Sections 419 (Punishment for personation), 427 (Mischief causing damage to property), and 34 (Acts done by several persons in furtherance of common intention) of the Indian Penal Code.?
facts: The petitioner filed a criminal petition seeking to quash an FIR registered for offences under Sections 419 and 427 read with 34 of the Indian Penal Code. The FIR was filed against the petitioner/accused.
charge: Quashing of FIR proceedings.
law_content: Sections 419 (Punishment for personation), 427 (Mischief causing damage to property), and 34 (Acts done by several persons in furtherance of common intention) of the Indian Penal Code.
judgment: The Court dismissed the criminal petition as infructuous, noting that the investigation was completed, a charge sheet had been filed, and the case was registered, rendering the petition moot. Liberty was granted to the petitioner to move a fresh petition if the cause survived.

instruction: Summarize the facts, legal issue, provisions applied, and the High Court’s decision.
question: What did the High Court decide regarding Offence under Section 138 of the Negotiable Instruments Act. under Section 138 of the Negotiable Instruments Act deals with the offence of dishonour of a cheque for insufficiency, etc., of funds in the drawer's account.?
facts: The appellant, M/s. Maple Logistics Pvt. Ltd., filed a complaint against the respondent/accused for an offence under Section 138 of the Negotiable Instruments Act. The accused, who was the Branch Manager, allegedly collected Rs. 3,49,400/- from a customer but did not show it in company accounts. Towards repayment, the accused issued three cheques, two of which were dishonored due to insufficient funds. The trial court acquitted the accused.
charge: Offence under Section 138 of the Negotiable Instruments Act.
law_content: Section 138 of the Negotiable Instruments Act deals with the offence of dishonour of a cheque for insufficiency, etc., of funds in the drawer's account.
judgment: The High Court upheld the trial court's acquittal, finding that the complainant failed to discharge the burden of proving that the accused misappropriated the sum and also failed to prove other allegations.

instruction: Summarize the facts, legal issue, provisions applied, and the High Court’s decision.
question: What did the High Court decide regarding Quashing of proceedings in Crime No. 794 of 2023 registered under Sections 294-B, 323, and 506 read with Section 34 of the Indian Penal Code. under Section 482 Cr.P.C. - Power of High Court to pass orders to secure the ends of justice; Arnesh Kumar v. State of Bihar guidelines regarding arrest.?
facts: The petitioners, accused Nos. 1 to 3 in FIR No. 794 of 2023, filed a petition seeking to quash the proceedings against them. The case was registered for alleged offences under Sections 294-B, 323, and 506 read with Section 34 of the Indian Penal Code.
charge: Quashing of proceedings in Crime No. 794 of 2023 registered under Sections 294-B, 323, and 506 read with Section 34 of the Indian Penal Code.
law_content: Section 482 Cr.P.C. - Power of High Court to pass orders to secure the ends of justice; Arnesh Kumar v. State of Bihar guidelines regarding arrest.
judgment: The Court directed the petitioners to appear before the investigating officer and ordered the officer to follow the procedure under Section 41-A Cr.P.C. and the guidelines in Arnesh Kumar v. State of Bihar. No coercive steps were to be taken against the petitioners until the investigation is completed.

instruction: Summarize the facts, legal issue, provisions applied, and the High Court’s decision.
question: What did the High Court decide regarding The petitioner sought a writ of mandamus to declare the inaction of the police in registering and investigating a complaint as illegal and violative of the Cr.P.C and the Constitution, and to direct them to proceed as per law. under Article 226 of the Constitution of India (for issuing writ of mandamus) and Section 154(3) of the Code of Criminal Procedure (regarding procedure upon receipt of information about cognizable offence).?
facts: The petitioner filed a written complaint with the police regarding alleged cognizable offences. However, the police failed to register a crime or investigate the matter. The petitioner approached the High Court seeking directions to register the crime, investigate, arrest the culprits, and file a charge sheet.
charge: The petitioner sought a writ of mandamus to declare the inaction of the police in registering and investigating a complaint as illegal and violative of the Cr.P.C and the Constitution, and to direct them to proceed as per law.
law: Constitution of India, Code of Criminal Procedure, 1973
law_content: Article 226 of the Constitution of India (for issuing writ of mandamus) and Section 154(3) of the Code of Criminal Procedure (regarding procedure upon receipt of information about cognizable offence).
judgment: The High Court directed the police to furnish a copy of the closure report/final report to the petitioner to enable them to pursue appropriate remedies under the law.

instruction: Summarize the facts, legal issue, provisions applied, and the High Court’s decision.
question: What did the High Court decide regarding Seeking regular bail for the petitioner/accused in a case involving death due to negligent driving. under Sections 437 and 439 of Cr.P.C (for seeking bail), Sections 304-II and 337 of IPC (offences related to causing death by negligence), and Sections 181 and 196 of MV Act.?
facts: The petitioner is accused in a crime registered for offences under Sections 304-II, 337 of IPC and Sections 181, 196 of MV Act. The police registered the case after the petitioner's negligent driving caused an accident resulting in a death. The petitioner claims the police have wrongly invoked Section 304-II IPC instead of Section 304A IPC.
charge: Seeking regular bail for the petitioner/accused in a case involving death due to negligent driving.
law: Code of Criminal Procedure, 1973, Indian Penal Code, 1860, Motor Vehicles Act, 1988
law_content: Sections 437 and 439 of Cr.P.C (for seeking bail), Sections 304-II and 337 of IPC (offences related to causing death by negligence), and Sections 181 and 196 of MV Act.
judgment: The Court granted regular bail to the petitioner, subject to furnishing a personal bond with sureties, appearing before the SHO weekly for four weeks, and abiding by other conditions under Section 437(3) of Cr.P.C.

instruction: Summarize the facts, legal issue, provisions applied, and the High Court’s decision.
question: What did the High Court decide regarding Seeking release of a seized auto-rickshaw on interim custody, challenging the trial court's order denying the same. under Section 482 of Cr.P.C. (inherent powers of the High Court) and Section 451 of Cr.P.C. (procedure for custody and disposal of seized property).?
facts: The petitioner, owner of an auto-rickshaw, filed a petition seeking interim custody of his seized vehicle. The vehicle was seized in connection with a crime where a passenger was found traveling with ganja. The petitioner claims the vehicle was used for transporting passengers, not contraband, and hence should be released.
charge: Seeking release of a seized auto-rickshaw on interim custody, challenging the trial court's order denying the same.
law_content: Section 482 of Cr.P.C. (inherent powers of the High Court) and Section 451 of Cr.P.C. (procedure for custody and disposal of seized property).
judgment: The High Court directed the trial court to return the seized vehicle to the petitioner on interim custody, upon furnishing a personal bond with surety, depositing the original RC, and undertaking not to alienate or alter the vehicle.

instruction: Summarize the facts, legal issue, provisions applied, and the High Court’s decision.
question: What did the High Court decide regarding Withdrawal of Criminal Revision Case. under Sections 397 and 401 CrPC deal with the High Court's power to call for records and examine proceedings of inferior criminal courts and revise such orders.?
facts: The petitioner filed a criminal revision case challenging an order passed by the Special Judge concerning the release of a seized mobile phone in connection with a criminal case registered under the SCs & STs (POA) Act. The petitioner sought to withdraw the revision case.
charge: Withdrawal of Criminal Revision Case.
law_content: Sections 397 and 401 CrPC deal with the High Court's power to call for records and examine proceedings of inferior criminal courts and revise such orders.
judgment: The petitioner was granted permission to withdraw the Criminal Revision Case, and accordingly, the case was dismissed as withdrawn.

instruction: Summarize the facts, legal issue, provisions applied, and the High Court’s decision.
question: What did the High Court decide regarding Seeking to quash criminal proceedings based on a compromise between the petitioners and the second respondent, and to compound the offences. under Section 482 Cr.P.C. allows the High Court to make such orders as may be necessary to give effect to any order under the Code or to prevent abuse of the process of any Court or otherwise to secure the ends of justice. Section 320 Cr.P.C. deals with compounding of offences. Sections 3 and 4 of the Dowry Prohibition Act are non-compoundable offences.?
facts: The petitioners are accused in a criminal case. They have filed a petition under Section 482 of Cr.P.C. to quash the proceedings due to a settlement reached with the second respondent (defacto complainant). Applications have also been filed to compound the offences under Section 320 of Cr.P.C.
charge: Seeking to quash criminal proceedings based on a compromise between the petitioners and the second respondent, and to compound the offences.
law: Criminal Procedure Code, 1973, Section 482, Section 320, Dowry Prohibition Act, Sections 3 and 4
law_content: Section 482 Cr.P.C. allows the High Court to make such orders as may be necessary to give effect to any order under the Code or to prevent abuse of the process of any Court or otherwise to secure the ends of justice. Section 320 Cr.P.C. deals with compounding of offences. Sections 3 and 4 of the Dowry Prohibition Act are non-compoundable offences.
judgment: The court noted that the parties had compromised the matter during the pendency of the criminal petition and filed applications to record the compromise and compound the offences. The Public Prosecutor opposed the compromise, citing the non-compoundable nature of the offences under the Dowry Prohibition Act. The court referenced a Supreme Court judgment concerning the spirit of compromise.

instruction: Summarize the facts, legal issue, provisions applied, and the High Court’s decision.
question: What did the High Court decide regarding Quashing of FIR proceedings and seeking directions to follow Section 41-A of Cr.P.C. under Section 482 Cr.P.C. - Powers of High Court to pass any order necessary to give effect to any order under the Code, or to prevent abuse of the process of any Court or otherwise to secure the ends of justice. Sections 406 and 420 IPC - Cheating and Criminal Breach of Trust. Section 41-A Cr.P.C. - Notice of appearance before police officer.?
facts: The petitioner, arrayed as Accused No.2, filed a criminal petition under Section 482 of Cr.P.C. seeking to quash proceedings in FIR No. 420 of 2023, registered for alleged offences under Sections 406 and 420 of IPC. The petitioner argued that the case is civil in nature and the complainant is trying to convert it into a criminal matter. The petitioner also pointed out that similar relief was granted to Accused No.1 in the same FIR.
charge: Quashing of FIR proceedings and seeking directions to follow Section 41-A of Cr.P.C.
law: Code of Criminal Procedure, 1973 (Cr.P.C.), Indian Penal Code, 1860 (IPC)
law_content: Section 482 Cr.P.C. - Powers of High Court to pass any order necessary to give effect to any order under the Code, or to prevent abuse of the process of any Court or otherwise to secure the ends of justice. Sections 406 and 420 IPC - Cheating and Criminal Breach of Trust. Section 41-A Cr.P.C. - Notice of appearance before police officer.
judgment: The High Court, considering the punishment prescribed for the offences was less than seven years, directed the petitioner (Accused No.2) to appear before the Investigating Officer by a specified date. The Investigating Officer was directed to follow the procedure laid down under Section 41-A Cr.P.C. and the guidelines in Arnesh Kumar v. State of Bihar. No arrest or coercive steps were to be taken against the petitioner until the investigation and decision on documents submitted by the petitioner were completed.

instruction: Summarize the facts, legal issue, provisions applied, and the High Court’s decision.
question: What did the High Court decide regarding Quashing of criminal proceedings under Section 186 IPC based on compromise. under Section 320(2) CrPC - This section deals with compounding of offences. It allows parties to compound certain offences with the permission of the court. Section 320(6) CrPC allows compounding of certain offences by the victim with the permission of the High Court. In this case, it was used to record a compromise and quash proceedings.?
facts: The petitioner/accused sought to quash criminal proceedings initiated against them under Section 186 IPC. The parties have since compromised the matter. The court directed them to appear before the High Court Legal Services Committee for identification and a report.
charge: Quashing of criminal proceedings under Section 186 IPC based on compromise.
law_content: Section 320(2) CrPC - This section deals with compounding of offences. It allows parties to compound certain offences with the permission of the court. Section 320(6) CrPC allows compounding of certain offences by the victim with the permission of the High Court. In this case, it was used to record a compromise and quash proceedings.
judgment: The criminal petition was allowed, and the proceedings in C.C.No.773 of 2021 were quashed subject to the payment of Rs.5,000/- to the Director, Sainik Welfare, Hyderabad, and Rs.5,000/- to the Telangana High Court Advocates Association.

instruction: Summarize the facts, legal issue, provisions applied, and the High Court’s decision.

facts: The petitioner filed a criminal petition seeking anticipatory bail in connection with a registered crime. The learned counsel for the petitioner submitted that the cause in the criminal petition no longer survives for adjudication and has become infructuous.
charge: Grant of anticipatory bail under Section 438 of Cr.P.C.
law_content: Section 438 of Cr.P.C - Direction required in case of arrest to be released on bail for non-bailable offence.
judgment: The Criminal Petition was dismissed as infructuous, recording the submission of the learned counsel for the petitioner.

instruction: Summarize the facts, legal issue, provisions applied, and the High Court’s decision.
question: What did the High Court decide regarding Directing the police to investigate a registered crime and file a charge sheet. under Article 226 of the Constitution of India empowers the High Court to issue writs, including Mandamus, to direct authorities to perform their public duties. Sections 447, 427, and 506 of the IPC deal with criminal trespass, mischief, and criminal intimidation.?
facts: The petitioner reported a crime under Sections 447, 427, and 506 of the IPC. The police registered a case but did not conduct a thorough investigation or file a charge sheet. The petitioner filed a writ petition seeking a direction for proper investigation.
charge: Directing the police to investigate a registered crime and file a charge sheet.
law: Constitution of India, Indian Penal Code (IPC)
law_content: Article 226 of the Constitution of India empowers the High Court to issue writs, including Mandamus, to direct authorities to perform their public duties. Sections 447, 427, and 506 of the IPC deal with criminal trespass, mischief, and criminal intimidation.
judgment: The High Court directed the police to complete the investigation expeditiously, preferably within three months, and file an appropriate charge sheet/final report.

instruction: Summarize the facts, legal issue, provisions applied, and the High Court’s decision.
question: What did the High Court decide regarding Compounding of offences under Sections 498-A, 406, 506 IPC and Section 4 of Dowry Prohibition Act based on compromise. under Section 320(2) of Cr.P.C. - This section allows for the compounding of certain offences with the permission of the Court. Section 498-A IPC relates to cruelty by a husband or relatives of the husband, Section 406 IPC pertains to criminal breach of trust, and Section 506 IPC deals with punishment for criminal intimidation. Section 4 of the Dowry Prohibition Act deals with the penalty for giving or taking dowry.?
facts: The petitioners/accused, along with the de-facto complainant, have entered into a compromise in a criminal case involving alleged offences under Sections 498-A, 406, and 506 of the Indian Penal Code and Section 4 of the Dowry Prohibition Act. They have filed applications to record this compromise and compound the offences.
charge: Compounding of offences under Sections 498-A, 406, 506 IPC and Section 4 of Dowry Prohibition Act based on compromise.
law: Indian Penal Code, 1860; Dowry Prohibition Act, 1961; Code of Criminal Procedure, 1973
law_content: Section 320(2) of Cr.P.C. - This section allows for the compounding of certain offences with the permission of the Court. Section 498-A IPC relates to cruelty by a husband or relatives of the husband, Section 406 IPC pertains to criminal breach of trust, and Section 506 IPC deals with punishment for criminal intimidation. Section 4 of the Dowry Prohibition Act deals with the penalty for giving or taking dowry.
judgment: The Court allowed the applications to record the compromise and compound the offences, permitting the parties to settle the matter.
