judgment: The criminal petition was closed as infructuous because the case was referred as 'False' by the police, and no further adjudication was required.

question: What did the High Court decide regarding Seeking to intervene and vacate an ad-interim order that stayed a lookout circular issued against respondent no. 1, who is the appellant's husband. under Sections 498-A and 504 of the Indian Penal Code (cruelty by husband or relatives and intentional insult); Sections 3 and 4 of the Dowry Prohibition Act (demand and giving of dowry); Section 151 CPC (inherent powers of the court for intervening in proceedings).?
facts: The appellant is the wife of respondent no. 1. Respondent no. 1 was subject to a lookout circular in relation to a case registered under Sections 498-A, 504 IPC, and Sections 3 and 4 of the Dowry Prohibition Act. A single judge had stayed the operation of the lookout circular. The appellant, not being a party to the writ petition, sought to intervene.
charge: Seeking to intervene and vacate an ad-interim order that stayed a lookout circular issued against respondent no. 1, who is the appellant's husband.
law: Indian Penal Code (IPC), Dowry Prohibition Act, Civil Procedure Code (CPC)
law_content: Sections 498-A and 504 of the Indian Penal Code (cruelty by husband or relatives and intentional insult); Sections 3 and 4 of the Dowry Prohibition Act (demand and giving of dowry); Section 151 CPC (inherent powers of the court for intervening in proceedings).
judgment: The Writ Appeal was disposed of by granting liberty to the appellant to file an application seeking impleadment in the writ petition and to seek vacation of the ad-interim order. The learned Single Judge was requested to deal with such an application expeditiously.

facts: The petitioners filed a criminal petition under Section 482 of Cr.P.C. seeking to quash an FIR and to stay proceedings, including arrest. The FIR was registered against them.

judgment: The criminal petition was dismissed as infructuous because the case was referred to as civil in nature during the pendency of the petition. The court noted the submission made by the Additional Public Prosecutor.

question: What did the High Court decide regarding Illegal detention and harassment by police without proper procedure. under Article 226 of the Constitution of India (Writ jurisdiction), Section 41-A Cr.P.C. (Notice of appearance before police officer), Arnesh Kumar v. State of Bihar guidelines (procedure for arrest).?
facts: The petitioner alleges that the police are summoning and detaining him without an FIR and forcing him to admit to a crime registered under FIR No. 84 of 2023. He seeks a direction to prevent such illegal actions and harassment.
charge: Illegal detention and harassment by police without proper procedure.
law: Constitution of India, Code of Criminal Procedure (CrPC)
law_content: Article 226 of the Constitution of India (Writ jurisdiction), Section 41-A Cr.P.C. (Notice of appearance before police officer), Arnesh Kumar v. State of Bihar guidelines (procedure for arrest).
judgment: The Court directed the respondents to issue notice to the petitioner under Section 41-A Cr.P.C. and follow the guidelines issued in Arnesh Kumar's case if the petitioner's presence is required for investigation.

instruction: Summarize the facts, legal issue, provisions applied, and the High Court’s decision.
question: What did the High Court decide regarding Quashing of FIR and stay of arrest proceedings. under Section 482 Cr.P.C. - Saving of inherent powers of High Court. Section 3(1)(r) SC ST (POA) Act, 2015 - Punishment for intentional insult or intimidation with intent to humiliate a member of a Scheduled Caste or Scheduled Tribe. Section 34 IPC - Acts done by several persons in furtherance of common intention. Section 41-A Cr.P.C. - Notice of appearance before police officer.?
facts: The petitioner, arrayed as an accused, filed a criminal petition under Section 482 of Cr.P.C. seeking to quash proceedings in FIR No. 361 of 2023. The petitioner also sought a stay on further proceedings, including arrest, until the disposal of the quash petition. The FIR was registered for alleged offences under Section 3(1)(r) of the SC ST (POA) Act, 2015 read with Section 34 of IPC.
charge: Quashing of FIR and stay of arrest proceedings.
law_content: Section 482 Cr.P.C. - Saving of inherent powers of High Court. Section 3(1)(r) SC ST (POA) Act, 2015 - Punishment for intentional insult or intimidation with intent to humiliate a member of a Scheduled Caste or Scheduled Tribe. Section 34 IPC - Acts done by several persons in furtherance of common intention. Section 41-A Cr.P.C. - Notice of appearance before police officer.
judgment: The High Court directed the petitioner/accused to appear before the Investigating Officer on or before 30.01.2024. The Investigating Officer was instructed to follow the procedure under Section 41-A Cr.P.C. and the guidelines in Arnesh Kumar v. State of Bihar. The Court ordered that there shall be no arrest until the police investigate and decide on the documents filed by the petitioner in response to the Section 41-A notice.

instruction: Summarize the facts, legal issue, provisions applied, and the High Court’s decision.
question: What did the High Court decide regarding Quashing of proceedings under Section 420 IPC and Sections 3(1)(r)(s) of SCs and STs (POA) Act, 2015. under Section 482 of Cr.P.C. empowers the High Court to make such orders as may be necessary to give effect to any order under the Code, or to prevent abuse of the process of any Court or otherwise to secure the ends of justice. The guidelines from Arnesh Kumar v. State of Bihar regarding Section 41-A Cr.P.C. and arrest procedures were also considered.?
facts: The petitioner, arrayed as Accused No. 1, filed a criminal petition seeking to quash the proceedings initiated against him in Crime No. 6 of 2024. The FIR was registered for alleged offences under Section 420 of the Indian Penal Code and Sections 3(1)(r)(s) of the SCs and STs (Prevention of Atrocities) Act, 2015. The petitioner also sought a stay on the proceedings.
charge: Quashing of proceedings under Section 420 IPC and Sections 3(1)(r)(s) of SCs and STs (POA) Act, 2015.
law: Cr.P.C., IPC, SCs and STs (POA) Act, 1989
law_content: Section 482 of Cr.P.C. empowers the High Court to make such orders as may be necessary to give effect to any order under the Code, or to prevent abuse of the process of any Court or otherwise to secure the ends of justice. The guidelines from Arnesh Kumar v. State of Bihar regarding Section 41-A Cr.P.C. and arrest procedures were also considered.
judgment: The Court directed the petitioner to appear before the Investigating Officer on or before 07.02.2024 and asked the Investigating Officer to follow the procedure laid down under Section 41-A Cr.P.C. and the guidelines from Arnesh Kumar v. State of Bihar. The Court also ordered that there shall be no arrest until the police investigate and take a decision on the documents filed by the petitioner. The criminal petition was disposed of with these directions.

question: What did the High Court decide regarding The petitioner is accused of offences under Sections 505(1)(c), 505(2), and 507 of the IPC. under Section 482 Cr.P.C. allows the High Court to make such orders as may be necessary to give effect to any order under the Code, or to prevent abuse of the process of any Court or otherwise to secure the ends of justice. Section 41-A Cr.P.C. relates to notice of appearance before police officer.?
facts: The petitioner, Akula Satish, is accused in Crime No. 1202 of 2021 for offences under Sections 505(1)(c), 505(2), and 507 of the Indian Penal Code (IPC). He filed a criminal petition under Section 482 of the Code of Criminal Procedure (Cr.P.C.) seeking to quash these proceedings and also sought a stay on further proceedings and coercive steps.
charge: The petitioner is accused of offences under Sections 505(1)(c), 505(2), and 507 of the IPC.
law_content: Section 482 Cr.P.C. allows the High Court to make such orders as may be necessary to give effect to any order under the Code, or to prevent abuse of the process of any Court or otherwise to secure the ends of justice. Section 41-A Cr.P.C. relates to notice of appearance before police officer.
judgment: The Court, considering that the punishment for the alleged offences is less than seven years, directed the petitioner (Accused No.1) to appear before the Investigating Officer by a specific date. The Investigating Officer was directed to follow the procedure under Section 41-A Cr.P.C. and the guidelines in Arnesh Kumar v. State of Bihar, without making any arrest until a decision is taken on documents filed by the petitioner. The criminal petition was disposed of with these directions.

The petitioner's counsel later submitted that the cause in the writ petition no longer survives.

law_content: Article 226 - Power of High Courts to issue certain writs, more particularly a writ of Mandamus.
judgment: The writ petition was disposed of as infructuous because the cause of action no longer survived, and no further orders were required.

question: What did the High Court decide regarding Quashing of FIR and proceedings under Sections 448, 506, 324 read with Section 34 of the IPC. under Section 482 Cr.P.C. - Saving of inherent powers of High Court. Nothing in this Code shall be deemed to limit or affect the inherent powers of the High Court to make such orders as may be necessary to give effect to any order under this Code, or to prevent abuse of the process of any Court or otherwise to secure the ends of justice.?
facts: The petitioners filed a criminal petition under Section 482 of the Cr.P.C. seeking to quash the FIR registered against them. The FIR was filed for offences punishable under Sections 448, 506, and 324 read with Section 34 of the Indian Penal Code. During the pendency of the petition, the police filed a charge sheet.
charge: Quashing of FIR and proceedings under Sections 448, 506, 324 read with Section 34 of the IPC.
law_content: Section 482 Cr.P.C. - Saving of inherent powers of High Court. Nothing in this Code shall be deemed to limit or affect the inherent powers of the High Court to make such orders as may be necessary to give effect to any order under this Code, or to prevent abuse of the process of any Court or otherwise to secure the ends of justice.

question: What did the High Court decide regarding Challenge to conviction under Section 138 of the Negotiable Instruments Act. under Section 138 NI Act - Dishonour of cheque for insufficiency, etc., of funds in the account. Where any cheque drawn by a person on an account maintained by him with a banking company for payment of any amount of money to another person from out of that account is returned by the banking company unpaid, either because the amount of money standing to the credit of that account is insufficient to honour the cheque or that it exceeds the amount arranged to be paid from that account by an agreement with that banking company, such person shall be deemed to have committed an offence and shall, without prejudice to any other provision of this Act, be punished in the manner prescribed therefore.?
facts: The petitioner was accused of an offence under Section 138 of the Negotiable Instruments Act for dishonoring a cheque. The trial court convicted him, and the appellate court confirmed the conviction. The petitioner filed a criminal revision case against the appellate court's judgment.
charge: Challenge to conviction under Section 138 of the Negotiable Instruments Act.
law: Negotiable Instruments Act, 1881; Code of Criminal Procedure, 1973
law_content: Section 138 NI Act - Dishonour of cheque for insufficiency, etc., of funds in the account. Where any cheque drawn by a person on an account maintained by him with a banking company for payment of any amount of money to another person from out of that account is returned by the banking company unpaid, either because the amount of money standing to the credit of that account is insufficient to honour the cheque or that it exceeds the amount arranged to be paid from that account by an agreement with that banking company, such person shall be deemed to have committed an offence and shall, without prejudice to any other provision of this Act, be punished in the manner prescribed therefore.
judgment: The Court heard arguments from both sides concerning the conviction under Section 138 of the NI Act and relied on Supreme Court decisions regarding the object of penal provisions in the NI Act.

question: What did the High Court decide regarding The petitioner seeks a direction for a fair investigation and filing of a charge sheet in relation to an FIR, alleging inaction and violation of principles of natural justice and constitutional rights. under Article 226 of the Constitution of India for issuing a writ of mandamus; Sections 447, 427, and 506 of the Indian Penal Code defining offences related to criminal trespass, mischief, and criminal intimidation; Criminal Procedure Code for investigation and charge sheet procedures.?
facts: The petitioner, M/s. SJM Associates, filed a writ petition seeking a mandamus to direct the police to conduct a fair investigation and file a charge sheet concerning FIR Crime No. 1377 of 2022, registered under Sections 447, 427, and 506 of the IPC. The petitioner alleged inaction by the police despite the FIR being registered on November 17, 2022.
charge: The petitioner seeks a direction for a fair investigation and filing of a charge sheet in relation to an FIR, alleging inaction and violation of principles of natural justice and constitutional rights.
law: Constitution of India, Indian Penal Code, Criminal Procedure Code
law_content: Article 226 of the Constitution of India for issuing a writ of mandamus; Sections 447, 427, and 506 of the Indian Penal Code defining offences related to criminal trespass, mischief, and criminal intimidation; Criminal Procedure Code for investigation and charge sheet procedures.
judgment: The writ petition is filed seeking a direction to conduct a fair investigation and file a charge sheet. The Assistant Government Pleader for Home stated that investigation is ongoing but was affected by police personnel being deputed for general elections. The court acknowledged the situation and the case is being processed.

instruction: Summarize the facts, legal issue, provisions applied, and the High Court’s decision.
question: What did the High Court decide regarding The petitioners sought to quash the proceedings in a Domestic Violence Case (DVC No. 16 of 2022) pending before the II Additional Metropolitan Magistrate. under Section 482 of the Cr.P.C. for inherent powers of the High Court to quash proceedings; Section 29 of the Protection of Women from Domestic Violence Act, 2005, which provides a remedy by way of an appeal against orders taking cognizance.?
facts: The petitioners filed a criminal petition under Section 482 of the Cr.P.C. seeking to quash the proceedings in DVC No. 16 of 2022. The court noted that the Act itself provides a remedy by way of an appeal against the court below's action in taking cognizance and numbering the D.V.C.
charge: The petitioners sought to quash the proceedings in a Domestic Violence Case (DVC No. 16 of 2022) pending before the II Additional Metropolitan Magistrate.
law: Code of Criminal Procedure, Protection of Women from Domestic Violence Act, 2005
law_content: Section 482 of the Cr.P.C. for inherent powers of the High Court to quash proceedings; Section 29 of the Protection of Women from Domestic Violence Act, 2005, which provides a remedy by way of an appeal against orders taking cognizance.
judgment: The court held that a petition to quash proceedings in a Domestic Violence Case is not maintainable under Section 482 Cr.P.C. when an efficacious remedy by way of appeal is available under Section 29 of the Protection of Women from Domestic Violence Act, 2005. The petitioners were granted liberty to avail the said alternative remedy, and their appearance in the DVC was dispensed with except when required by the trial court.

instruction: Summarize the facts, legal issue, provisions applied, and the High Court’s decision.
question: What did the High Court decide regarding Quashing of proceedings in DVC No.16 of 2022. under Section 482 Cr.P.C.: Empowers the High Court to pass any order necessary to give effect to any order under the Code, or to prevent abuse of the process of any Court or otherwise to secure the ends of justice. Section 29 of the Protection of Women from Domestic Violence Act, 2005: Provides for an appeal against the order of the Magistrate taking cognizance or passing an order in a DVC case.?
facts: The petitioner sought to quash proceedings in a Domestic Violence Case (DVC) filed against him. The petitioner is a police constable. The case was filed by a private party. The State was also a respondent.
charge: Quashing of proceedings in DVC No.16 of 2022.
law: Code of Criminal Procedure (Cr.P.C.), Protection of Women from Domestic Violence Act, 2005
law_content: Section 482 Cr.P.C.: Empowers the High Court to pass any order necessary to give effect to any order under the Code, or to prevent abuse of the process of any Court or otherwise to secure the ends of justice. Section 29 of the Protection of Women from Domestic Violence Act, 2005: Provides for an appeal against the order of the Magistrate taking cognizance or passing an order in a DVC case.
judgment: The High Court held that a petition to quash proceedings in a Domestic Violence Case is not maintainable under Section 482 Cr.P.C. The petitioner should avail the appellate remedy under Section 29 of the Domestic Violence Act. The petitioner's appearance in the lower court was dispensed with, and the criminal petition was disposed of accordingly.

question: What did the High Court decide regarding Quashing of proceedings in CC No. 14 of 2019. under Section 482 of Cr.P.C. - The High Court has inherent powers to make such orders as may be necessary to give effect to any order under this Code, or to prevent abuse of the process of any Court or otherwise to secure the ends of justice.?
facts: The petitioner filed a criminal petition seeking to quash proceedings in CC No. 14 of 2019. The case was pending before the Judicial First Class Magistrate at Alair. The petitioner also sought a stay of further proceedings, including their appearance in court.

question: What did the High Court decide regarding Criminal Revision Case filed under Sections 397 and 401 of Cr.PC challenging the acquittal for offences under Sections 498-A, 304-B, 306 of IPC and Sections 3 & 4 of the Dowry Prohibition Act. under Section 498-A IPC (Husband or relative of husband of a woman subjecting her to cruelty), Section 304-B IPC (Dowry death), Section 306 IPC (Abetment of suicide), Section 3 & 4 of Dowry Prohibition Act (Prohibition of giving and taking dowry). Sections 397 & 401 Cr.PC (Powers of revision of High Court).?
facts: The defacto complainant's daughter married accused No. 1. Allegations of marital cruelty and suspicion of infidelity by the accused were made. The deceased allegedly committed suicide. The trial court acquitted the accused, relying on a letter suggesting the deceased had an affair and recorded conversations to that effect. The defacto complainant challenged this acquittal.
charge: Criminal Revision Case filed under Sections 397 and 401 of Cr.PC challenging the acquittal for offences under Sections 498-A, 304-B, 306 of IPC and Sections 3 & 4 of the Dowry Prohibition Act.
law: Indian Penal Code (IPC), Dowry Prohibition Act, Code of Criminal Procedure (Cr.PC)
law_content: Section 498-A IPC (Husband or relative of husband of a woman subjecting her to cruelty), Section 304-B IPC (Dowry death), Section 306 IPC (Abetment of suicide), Section 3 & 4 of Dowry Prohibition Act (Prohibition of giving and taking dowry). Sections 397 & 401 Cr.PC (Powers of revision of High Court).
judgment: The High Court considered the arguments regarding the alleged fabrication of evidence (Ex.D1 letter) and its confrontation to witnesses. The court noted that the letter was confronted to PW4, but not to the parents and family friend, limiting the complainant's ability to question it or send it for expert opinion. The judgment implies the revision was filed to question the acquittal.

question: What did the High Court decide regarding Criminal Revision Cases filed under Sections 397 & 401 of Cr.P.C. aggrieved by the orders made in Crl.M.P. No. 25 & 27 of 2010 in S.C. No. 496 of 2007, for proceeding against sureties under Section 446 of Cr.PC. under Section 446 Cr.PC (Procedure when bond has been forfeited), Sections 397 & 401 Cr.PC (Powers of revision of High Court), Section 482 Cr.PC (Saving of inherent powers of High Court).?
facts: The petitioners stood as sureties for accused A-7 and A-9 in a criminal case. The State initiated proceedings against them under Section 446 of Cr.PC for failing to produce the accused. The sureties claimed that A-7 and A-9 were kidnapped after their release from jail, making their production impossible. A previous High Court order had directed the police to trace the missing accused.
charge: Criminal Revision Cases filed under Sections 397 & 401 of Cr.P.C. aggrieved by the orders made in Crl.M.P. No. 25 & 27 of 2010 in S.C. No. 496 of 2007, for proceeding against sureties under Section 446 of Cr.PC.
law_content: Section 446 Cr.PC (Procedure when bond has been forfeited), Sections 397 & 401 Cr.PC (Powers of revision of High Court), Section 482 Cr.PC (Saving of inherent powers of High Court).
judgment: The High Court allowed the Criminal Revision Cases, setting aside the orders that directed the sureties to produce the accused or pay the penalty. The court found it incorrect to force sureties to produce accused who were admittedly kidnapped, as their production was impossible under such circumstances.

question: What did the High Court decide regarding Declaration of illegal and arbitrary action of respondent No.4 in not registering complaints and providing police protection, and consequently directing the registration of complaints and provision of protection. under Section 154 of Cr.P.C. - Information relating to the commission of a cognizable offence, if given orally to an officer in charge of a police station, shall be reduced to writing by the officer himself or under his direction and be read over to the informant, and every such information so reduced to writing as aforesaid shall be signed by the person giving it, and shall be entered in a book to be kept by such officer in such form as the State Government may prescribe.?
facts: The petitioner lodged written complaints on 09.01.2024 and 10.01.2024 with respondent No.4, stating that these complaints revealed the commission of a cognizable offense. The petitioner alleged that respondent No.4 had not taken any action under Section 154 of Cr. P.C. as per the guidelines issued by the Hon'ble Apex Court in Lalita Kumari v. State of Uttar Pradesh. The petitioner sought directions for police protection and registration of the complaints.
charge: Declaration of illegal and arbitrary action of respondent No.4 in not registering complaints and providing police protection, and consequently directing the registration of complaints and provision of protection.
law_content: Section 154 of Cr.P.C. - Information relating to the commission of a cognizable offence, if given orally to an officer in charge of a police station, shall be reduced to writing by the officer himself or under his direction and be read over to the informant, and every such information so reduced to writing as aforesaid shall be signed by the person giving it, and shall be entered in a book to be kept by such officer in such form as the State Government may prescribe.
judgment: The writ petition was disposed of as infructuous because the respondent authorities had already registered a case (Crime No.26 of 2024) under Sections 448, 342, 363, 509, and 506 read with 34 of I.P.C. based on the petitioner's complaints, and investigation had commenced. Therefore, the petitioner's grievance was deemed redressed.
category: Criminal: Writ Petition (Failure to Register FIR)

judgment: The High Court noted that the police had registered a case based on the petitioner's complaint. Therefore, the petitioner's grievance was redressed, and the writ petition was closed.

judgment: The appeal challenges the trial court's acquittal of the accused under Section 138 of the NI Act. Conditions were imposed including executing personal bonds, providing sureties, and reporting to the police station periodically.

instruction: Summarize the facts, legal issue, provisions applied, and the High Court’s decision.
question: What did the High Court decide regarding Seeking a writ of mandamus to declare the inaction of the police in investigating a kidnapping case as illegal and to direct them to conclude the investigation and file a report. under Section 363 IPC (punishment for kidnapping), provisions of CrPC regarding investigation timelines, and Article 226 of the Constitution (writ jurisdiction).?
facts: The petitioner's son was allegedly kidnapped, and an FIR was registered under Section 363 of the IPC. The petitioner claims that the police have failed to conduct a proper investigation even after more than a year, despite the prescribed time limit for investigation under the CrPC.
charge: Seeking a writ of mandamus to declare the inaction of the police in investigating a kidnapping case as illegal and to direct them to conclude the investigation and file a report.

law_content: Section 363 IPC (punishment for kidnapping), provisions of CrPC regarding investigation timelines, and Article 226 of the Constitution (writ jurisdiction).
judgment: The High Court disposed of the writ petition by directing the Station House Officer to complete the investigation in Crime No. 748 of 2022 as expeditiously as possible, preferably within two months, and to file a charge sheet.

instruction: Summarize the facts, legal issue, provisions applied, and the High Court’s decision.
question: What did the High Court decide regarding Conviction for offences under Sections 376 and 506 of IPC. under Section 376 IPC (Rape), Section 506 IPC (Criminal Intimidation), Sections 397 & 401 CrPC (Revisionary powers of High Court).?
facts: The petitioner was convicted for rape under Section 376 IPC and intimidation under Section 506 IPC. The victim, aged below 18, became pregnant and accused the petitioner. The petitioner's counsel argued that there was a significant delay in lodging the complaint and that the evidence regarding the victim's age was not conclusive.
charge: Conviction for offences under Sections 376 and 506 of IPC.
law: Indian Penal Code (IPC), Code of Criminal Procedure (CrPC)
law_content: Section 376 IPC (Rape), Section 506 IPC (Criminal Intimidation), Sections 397 & 401 CrPC (Revisionary powers of High Court).
judgment: The High Court noted that while the victim's age was a basis for the conviction, the evidence regarding her age was not conclusive. The court also observed that without convincing evidence of threat or coercion, a rape conviction might not be sustainable, especially if the relationship was admitted but pregnancy occurred. The case was presented as a revision against conviction and bail was previously granted by the High Court.

facts: The petitioners, accused numbers 2 to 4 in FIR No. 264 of 2023, filed a petition seeking to quash the proceedings against them. They are the parents and brother of the primary accused (A.1). question: What did the High Court decide regarding Quashing of criminal proceedings under Section 482 of Cr.P.C. under Section 482 - Saving of inherent powers of High Court. This section provides that nothing in this Code shall be deemed to limit or affect the inherent powers of the High Court to make such orders as may be necessary to give effect to any order under this Code, or to prevent abuse of the process of any Court or otherwise to secure the ends of justice.?
facts: The petitioners, employees of Kognivera IT Solutions Private Limited, are accused in a criminal complaint alleging theft of technology. The complaint was filed by an employee of a different company, Digisprint. The petitioners claim they were made accused without proper notice and that the main accused have absconded.

law_content: Section 482 - Saving of inherent powers of High Court. This section provides that nothing in this Code shall be deemed to limit or affect the inherent powers of the High Court to make such orders as may be necessary to give effect to any order under this Code, or to prevent abuse of the process of any Court or otherwise to secure the ends of justice.
judgment: The court found merit in the petitioners' submission that the company, whose employees they are, was not made a party to the complaint. facts: The petitioner applied for the renewal of his passport. The Regional Passport Office did not renew it, citing the petitioner's status as an accused in criminal cases involving offenses under Sections 120B, 403, 406, 409, 41B, and 420 of the IPC. The petitioner argued that these cases were still at the crime stage and he had not received any summons, thus the pendency should not be a ground for denial.

judgment: The Court, noting that the issue was covered by previous judgments of the High Court, impliedly found merit in the petitioner's plea that mere pendency of criminal cases without summons should not be a ground for denying passport renewal. The order mentions "This court opines that mere pendenc" suggesting a direction or consideration in favor of the petitioner.

judgment: The High Court set aside the impugned order of the trial court, granting the petitioner permission to travel abroad. The court noted that similar relief had been granted in other proceedings, and the trial court's order should not prevent the petitioner from travelling.

judgment: The High Court granted anticipatory bail to the petitioners, subject to their surrendering before the Station House Officer and executing personal bonds with sureties. question: What did the High Court decide regarding Appeal against conviction for offences under Section 498-A of IPC and Section 4 of the Dowry Prohibition Act. under Section 498-A IPC - Husband or relative of husband of a woman subjecting her to cruelty; Section 4 of Dowry Prohibition Act - Penalty for demanding dowry; Section 374(2) CrPC - Appeal in the court of session.?
facts: The appellants (husband and mother-in-law) were convicted by the trial court for offences under Section 498-A of IPC and Section 4 of the Dowry Prohibition Act. The prosecution's case was that the deceased was harassed for additional dowry and committed suicide. The trial court acquitted them of Sections 304-B IPC and 3 of DP Act due to lack of proximity between demand and death. The appellants appealed this conviction.

judgment: The Court heard arguments from both sides. The appellants' counsel argued that the conviction under Section 498-A IPC was erroneous if the allegation of dowry demand was disbelieved for Section 304-B IPC. The Public Prosecutor argued that acquittal under Section 304-B did not negate the demand itself. The judgment details were truncated, but the appeal was filed against the conviction.

judgment: The writ petition was filed seeking to declare the action of registering the FIR and filing the private complaint as illegal and arbitrary and to quash the FIR.

question: What did the High Court decide regarding Quashing of proceedings in DVC No.28 of 2022. under Section 482 Cr.P.C. - Saving of inherent powers of High Court. Section 29 of the Domestic Violence Act, 2005 - Appeal.?
facts: The petitioners filed a criminal petition under Section 482 of Cr.P.C. to quash proceedings in DVC No.28 of 2022. The case was filed under the Domestic Violence Act. The court noted that Section 29 of the Domestic Violence Act provides an appeal remedy.

The petitioners were advised to avail the remedy of appeal as provided under Section 29 of the Domestic Violence Act. The appearance of the petitioners was dispensed with, except when required by the trial court.

facts: The petitioners, who are accused in Crime No. 207 of 2023 for offences under Sections 294-B, 324, 506 r/w 34 IPC, sought to quash the FIR and stay further proceedings, including the filing of a charge sheet. They also sought protection from arrest.

The appellant sought to set aside the impugned judgment, while the Assistant Public Prosecutor contended that the trial court rightly passed the judgment. The court was to scrutinize oral and documentary evidence, noting that the accused did not deny the subject cheque or his signature.

question: What did the High Court decide regarding Criminal Appeal against dismissal of complaint under Section 256 Cr.P.C. under Section 378(4) Cr.P.C. pertains to appeals in cases of acquittal. Section 256 Cr.P.C. deals with the procedure when the complainant is absent, allowing for dismissal of the complaint if the complainant fails to appear without sufficient cause after a summons or warrant has been issued to the accused.?
facts: The appeal was filed against an order of the Magistrate dismissing a complaint. The Magistrate dismissed the complaint because both the complainant and the accused were absent on multiple occasions, and the complainant's counsel indicated the matter had been settled out of court, implying no further interest in prosecuting the case. The appellant challenged this dismissal.
charge: Criminal Appeal against dismissal of complaint under Section 256 Cr.P.C.
law: Section 378(4) of the Code of Criminal Procedure (Cr.P.C), 1973, Section 256 of the Code of Criminal Procedure (Cr.P.C), 1973
law_content: Section 378(4) Cr.P.C. pertains to appeals in cases of acquittal. Section 256 Cr.P.C. deals with the procedure when the complainant is absent, allowing for dismissal of the complaint if the complainant fails to appear without sufficient cause after a summons or warrant has been issued to the accused.
judgment: The Court found no infirmity in the Magistrate's order of dismissal, as the complainant had shown no interest in prosecuting the case. Therefore, the Criminal Appeal was dismissed.

judgment: The High Court directed the petitioners to appear before the Investigating Officer and cooperate with the investigation. The Investigating Officer was instructed to follow the procedure under Section 41-A Cr.P.C. and the guidelines in Arnesh Kumar v. State of Bihar. question: What did the High Court decide regarding Quashing of criminal proceedings under Section 482 Cr.P.C. against the petitioner, accused No. 68, for alleged participation in a party during the pandemic. under Section 482 Cr.P.C. saves the inherent powers of the High Court to make such orders as may be necessary to give effect to any order under the Code or to prevent abuse of the process of any Court or otherwise to secure the ends of justice. Section 188 IPC deals with disobedience to order duly promulgated by public servant.?
facts: The petitioner was implicated as accused No. 68 in a case related to a party where DJ sound and consumption of alcoholic drinks were alleged. The police seized items and concluded that all gathered members were liable under penal provisions, the Disaster Management Act, and the Epidemic Diseases Act. The petitioner claims to have nothing to do with the party and was falsely implicated.
charge: Quashing of criminal proceedings under Section 482 Cr.P.C. against the petitioner, accused No. 68, for alleged participation in a party during the pandemic.
law_content: Section 482 Cr.P.C. saves the inherent powers of the High Court to make such orders as may be necessary to give effect to any order under the Code or to prevent abuse of the process of any Court or otherwise to secure the ends of justice. Section 188 IPC deals with disobedience to order duly promulgated by public servant.
judgment: The High Court quashed the proceedings against the petitioner, stating that mere presence at the scene of the alleged party does not attract any of the alleged offenses. No specific role was attributed to the petitioner, and there was no evidence of him consuming prohibited substances or being under the influence of alcohol. The court also noted the prohibition under Section 195(1)(a) of Cr.P.C. for taking cognizance of offenses under Section 188 IPC without a complaint from the public servant concerned.

instruction: Summarize the facts, legal issue, provisions applied, and the High Court’s decision.
question: What did the High Court decide regarding Challenge to the condition of furnishing a personal bond of Rs. 7,00,000/- for interim custody of a seized vehicle. under Section 482 of Cr.P.C. - This section empowers the High Court to make orders necessary to give effect to any order under the Code, or to prevent abuse of the process of any Court or otherwise to secure the ends of justice. In this case, it was invoked to modify the bail bond condition.?
facts: The petitioner, Shaik Shaker, filed a criminal petition challenging the trial court's order imposing a condition of furnishing a personal bond of Rs. 7,00,000/- with one surety for granting interim custody of his vehicle. The vehicle was seized as it was found in a parking lot where another stolen vehicle was present.
charge: Challenge to the condition of furnishing a personal bond of Rs. 7,00,000/- for interim custody of a seized vehicle.
law_content: Section 482 of Cr.P.C. - This section empowers the High Court to make orders necessary to give effect to any order under the Code, or to prevent abuse of the process of any Court or otherwise to secure the ends of justice. In this case, it was invoked to modify the bail bond condition.
judgment: The High Court reduced the personal bond amount from Rs. 7,00,000/- to Rs. 50,000/- with one surety, considering that the petitioner was the registered owner and the vehicle was not involved in any offence.

instruction: Summarize the facts, legal issue, provisions applied, and the High Court’s decision.
question: What did the High Court decide regarding Quashing of proceedings in DVC.No.37 of 2023 and stay of further proceedings. under Section 482 Cr.P.C. grants inherent powers to the High Court to make orders necessary to give effect to any order under the Code, or to prevent abuse of the process of any Court or otherwise to secure the ends of justice. Section 29 of the Protection of Women from Domestic Violence Act, 2005 provides for an appeal against the orders of the Magistrate.?
facts: The petitioners filed a criminal petition under Section 482 of Cr.P.C. seeking to quash the proceedings initiated against them in a Domestic Violence Case (DVC.No.37 of 2023) pending before the Judicial Magistrate First Class. They also sought to stay further proceedings and dispense with their personal appearance.
charge: Quashing of proceedings in DVC.No.37 of 2023 and stay of further proceedings.
law: Code of Criminal Procedure, 1973; Protection of Women from Domestic Violence Act, 2005
law_content: Section 482 Cr.P.C. grants inherent powers to the High Court to make orders necessary to give effect to any order under the Code, or to prevent abuse of the process of any Court or otherwise to secure the ends of justice. Section 29 of the Protection of Women from Domestic Violence Act, 2005 provides for an appeal against the orders of the Magistrate.
judgment: The High Court held that a petition to quash proceedings in a Domestic Violence Case is not maintainable under Section 482 Cr.P.C. when an efficacious remedy by way of an appeal is available under Section 29 of the DV Act. The petitioners were granted liberty to avail the alternative remedy. However, their personal appearance in the DVC proceedings was dispensed with, subject to them being represented by their counsel.

instruction: Summarize the facts, legal issue, provisions applied, and the High Court’s decision.
question: What did the High Court decide regarding Grant of anticipatory bail to the petitioner pending trial of Crime No.295 of 2023. under Section 438 Cr.P.C. allows a person apprehended on an accusation of having committed a non-bailable offence to apply to the High Court or Court of Session for a direction that in the event of his arrest, he shall be released on bail. Section 41-A Cr.P.C. outlines the procedure for the notice of appearance before the police officer for offenses punishable with imprisonment up to seven years.?

Section 41-A Cr.P.C. outlines the procedure for the notice of appearance before the police officer for offenses punishable with imprisonment up to seven years.
judgment: The Court directed the Investigating Officer to strictly follow the procedure laid down under Section 41-A Cr.P.C. and the guidelines formulated by the Supreme Court in Arnesh Kumar v. State of Bihar for offenses punishable up to seven years. The petitioner was also directed to cooperate with the Investigating Officer. The criminal petition was disposed of with these directions.

The petitioner's earlier bail application was dismissed. The prosecution's case is that the deceased had an affair with the sister of accused No. 1, who is the wife of the petitioner. The petitioner claims he was not present at the scene.
charge: Offenses under Sections 302, 120(B), and 201 of the Indian Penal Code (IPC).
law: Code of Criminal Procedure (Cr.P.C.), Indian Penal Code (IPC)
law_content: Sections 437 & 439 Cr.P.C. - Provisions related to bail. The court considered the lack of changed circumstances since the previous dismissal of the bail application.
judgment: The criminal petition for bail was dismissed as there were no changed circumstances from the previous order refusing bail.

question: What did the High Court decide regarding Offenses under Sections 420, 323, 504 read with 34 of the Indian Penal Code (IPC). under Section 482 Cr.P.C. - Saving of inherent powers of High Court. This section allows the High Court to quash proceedings if it finds them to be an abuse of the process of the court or to secure the ends of justice. The court found the allegations against the petitioners to be vague and a result of the cancelled engagement.?
facts: The petitioners are seeking to quash criminal proceedings registered for offenses under Sections 420, 323, 504 read with 34 of the IPC. The case stems from a complaint by the second respondent after her engagement with accused No. 1 was cancelled. There is a history of cross-complaints between the parties. The petitioners, accused Nos. 2 to 5, are family members of accused No. 1, and the petitioners argue that the allegations against them are vague.
charge: Offenses under Sections 420, 323, 504 read with 34 of the Indian Penal Code (IPC).
law: Code of Criminal Procedure (Cr.P.C.), Indian Penal Code (IPC)
law_content: Section 482 Cr.P.C. - Saving of inherent powers of High Court. This section allows the High Court to quash proceedings if it finds them to be an abuse of the process of the court or to secure the ends of justice. The court found the allegations against the petitioners to be vague and a result of the cancelled engagement.
judgment: The criminal petition was allowed, and the proceedings against the petitioners in C.C.No.6389 of 2020 were quashed.

facts: The petitioners, accused Nos. 1 to 3, seek anticipatory bail in connection with an FIR registered for offenses including criminal trespass, intimidation, and attempt to murder. The FIR was based on a private complaint alleging trespass, threats with an axe and revolver, and an attempt to kill the complainant.

law_content: Section 438 of Cr.P.C. deals with the provision of anticipatory bail. Sections 447, 506, and 307 of IPC relate to criminal trespass, criminal intimidation, and attempt to murder, respectively.
judgment: The Court granted anticipatory bail to the petitioners/accused Nos. 1 to 3, subject to conditions including surrender before the Station House Officer by a specific date, furnishing personal bonds and sureties, and appearing before the Station House Officer on Mondays for four weeks and as required for investigation.

facts: The petitioner, an accused in FIR No. 1291 of 2021, filed a criminal petition under Section 482 of Cr.P.C. seeking to quash the proceedings. No. 369 of 2024) for another accused in the same FIR.

judgment: Considering the petitioner's condition (pregnancy) and the prior order in a related case, the High Court directed the police to complete the investigation without taking any coercive steps against the petitioner. The petitioner was also directed to cooperate with the investigation.

question: What did the High Court decide regarding Quashing of proceedings in FIR No. 467 of 2023 for alleged offences under Sections 420, 403, and 406 read with Section 34 of the IPC. under Section 482 Cr.P.C. - Powers of the High Court to pass any order for the purpose of securing the ends of justice. judgment: The High Court directed the petitioners to appear before the Investigating Officer, who was instructed to follow the procedure under Section 41-A Cr.P.C. and the guidelines from Arnesh Kumar v. State of Bihar. No coercive steps were to be taken against the petitioners until the investigation is completed. The criminal petition was disposed of.

Excise Act, Section 51(b) of Disaster Management Act, 2005, Section 3(1) of Epidemic Disease Act, 1897, and Sections 188 and 294 of IPC. under Section 482 Cr.P.C. - Inherent powers of the High Court to quash proceedings. Sections 8(c), 20(b), 25, 27(a), 29, 37 of NDPS Act - offences related to possession, consumption, and transportation of narcotic drugs and psychotropic substances.?
facts: The petitioner, accused no. 32, was found in a farmhouse where a rave party was allegedly held. Ganja and other substances were seized from other individuals at the party. The petitioner claims he was falsely implicated and has no connection to the party.
charge: Quashing of proceedings in S.C.No.5/2023 for alleged offences under Sections 8(c), 20(b), 25, 27(a), 29, 37 of the NDPS Act, Sections 34 read with 15 of T.S. Excise Act, Section 51(b) of Disaster Management Act, 2005, Section 3(1) of Epidemic Disease Act, 1897, and Sections 188 and 294 of IPC.
law: Code of Criminal Procedure, 1973; Narcotic Drugs and Psychotropic Substances Act, 1985; T.S. Excise Act; Disaster Management Act, 2005; Epidemic Disease Act, 1897; Indian Penal Code, 1860.
law_content: Section 482 Cr.P.C. - Inherent powers of the High Court to quash proceedings. Sections 8(c), 20(b), 25, 27(a), 29, 37 of NDPS Act - offences related to possession, consumption, and transportation of narcotic drugs and psychotropic substances.
judgment: The court noted that it was not the case that the petitioner was subjected to any tests to confirm consumption of prohibited substances. Unless the police specify the petitioner's role or possession of any prohibited substance, he cannot be punished. The judgment is truncated, but the initial observation suggests a potential for quashing.

instruction: Summarize the facts, legal issue, provisions applied, and the High Court’s decision.
question: What did the High Court decide regarding Quashing of proceedings under SC.NDPS No.5/2023, filed for offences under the NDPS Act, T.S. Excise Act, Disaster Management Act, Epidemic Disease Act, and IPC. under Section 482 Cr.P.C. - Powers of the High Court to pass any order for the ends of justice or to prevent abuse of the process of any Court.?
facts: The petitioner, accused no. 25, was apprehended at a farmhouse where a rave party was allegedly taking place with consumption of alcohol and ganja. The police seized ganja, iPhones, and LSD blots from other accused. The petitioner claims he was falsely implicated and was apprehended on the road.
charge: Quashing of proceedings under SC.NDPS No.5/2023, filed for offences under the NDPS Act, T.S. Excise Act, Disaster Management Act, Epidemic Disease Act, and IPC.
law: Code of Criminal Procedure, 1973; Narcotic Drugs and Psychotropic Substances Act, 1985; T.S. Excise Act; Disaster Management Act, 2005; Epidemic Disease Act, 1997; Indian Penal Code.
law_content: Section 482 Cr.P.C. - Powers of the High Court to pass any order for the ends of justice or to prevent abuse of the process of any Court.
judgment: The court noted that the petitioner was found on the premises of the farmhouse where the alleged rave party was ongoing. However, it was not the case that the petitioner was subjected to tests to confirm consumption of ganja or alcohol, nor was it specified that he was found with any prohibited substance. The court found it difficult to make the petitioner punishable under the penal provisions without such specifics and reserved judgment.

instruction: Summarize the facts, legal issue, provisions applied, and the High Court’s decision.

judgment: The court observed that the petitioner was found at the farmhouse where the rave party was held. However, there was no indication that the petitioner was tested for drug or alcohol consumption, nor was it specified that he possessed any prohibited substances. The court found it challenging to hold the petitioner punishable under the penal provisions without such specific evidence and deferred the decision.

Excise Act, Section 51(b) of Disaster Management Act, Section 3(i) of Epidemic Disease Act, and Sections 188 and 294 of IPC. under Section 482 Cr.P.C. - Saving of inherent powers of High Court to make orders necessary to give effect to any order under this Code, or to prevent abuse of the process of any Court or otherwise to secure the ends of justice. Sections 8(c), 20(b), 25, 27(a), 29, 31 of NDPS Act - Provisions related to offences concerning narcotic drugs and psychotropic substances.?
facts: The petitioner, Accused No. 90, was apprehended on the road and implicated in a rave party case where ganja was allegedly consumed. The petitioner claims he is a driver and has no connection to the rave party, asserting false implication. The prosecution contends that all accused, including the petitioner, violated government directions during the pandemic.
charge: Quashing of proceedings in S.C. No. 5 of 2023 pending on the file of the 1st Additional District and Sessions Court, Bhongir, for offences under Sections 8(c), 20(b), 25, 27(a), 29, 31 of NDPS Act, Section 34 of T.S. Excise Act, Section 51(b) of Disaster Management Act, Section 3(i) of Epidemic Disease Act, and Sections 188 and 294 of IPC.
law: Cr.P.C., NDPS Act, T.S. Excise Act, Disaster Management Act, Epidemic Disease Act, IPC
law_content: Section 482 Cr.P.C. - Saving of inherent powers of High Court to make orders necessary to give effect to any order under this Code, or to prevent abuse of the process of any Court or otherwise to secure the ends of justice. Sections 8(c), 20(b), 25, 27(a), 29, 31 of NDPS Act - Provisions related to offences concerning narcotic drugs and psychotropic substances.
judgment: The High Court noted that the petitioner was found on the premises of the farmhouse where the rave party was occurring. However, there was no specific role attributed to the petitioner, nor was it indicated that he was found inhaling ganja or under the influence of alcohol. Without such specifics, the court questioned the basis for implicating the petitioner, suggesting that a more detailed examination of the petitioner's specific involvement was necessary before dismissing the petition outright.

question: What did the High Court decide regarding Anticipatory bail under Section 438 CrPC for alleged offences of cheating, criminal breach of trust, and criminal conspiracy. under Section 438 CrPC - empowers the High Court or Court of Session to direct that in the event of his arrest on indictment, any person shall be released on bail. State of Bihar, given that the prescribed punishment for the alleged offences is less than seven years. The petitioner was directed to cooperate with the investigation.

question: What did the High Court decide regarding Dishonour of cheque punishable under Section 138 of the Negotiable Instruments Act, 1881. under Section 138 - Punishes dishonor of a cheque for insufficiency of funds in the account.?
facts: The appellant filed a criminal complaint against the respondent for an offence under Section 138 of the Negotiable Instruments Act, 1881, due to dishonor of a cheque. The trial court acquitted the accused, leading to the present appeal.
charge: Dishonour of cheque punishable under Section 138 of the Negotiable Instruments Act, 1881.
law_content: Section 138 - Punishes dishonor of a cheque for insufficiency of funds in the account.
judgment: The Criminal Appeal was dismissed. The court noted that the appellant (complainant) failed to prove his case beyond reasonable doubt, and that the legal presumption in favor of the holder of the cheque needs to be rebutted by the accused with sufficient evidence. The court did not express any opinion on the merits of the case.

question: What did the High Court decide regarding The petitioner seeks a writ of mandamus to declare the inaction of the police in registering an FIR on her complaint as illegal and arbitrary, and to direct them to register the FIR immediately for the alleged offenses under the Indian Penal Code. under Section 154(3) Cr.P.C. outlines the procedure when a complaint is made to a police officer who fails to register an FIR; in such cases, the informant can approach the Superintendent of Police. Article 226 of the Constitution of India empowers the High Court to issue writs, including mandamus, to direct authorities to perform their legal duties.?
facts: The petitioner filed a complaint with the police alleging offenses under Sections 384, 419, 420, 447, 406, 464, 468, 471, and 506 of the IPC against private respondents. The petitioner claims that the police (respondent no. 4) failed to register an FIR on her complaint, which she believes discloses cognizable offenses.

law_content: Section 154(3) Cr.P.C. outlines the procedure when a complaint is made to a police officer who fails to register an FIR; in such cases, the informant can approach the Superintendent of Police. Article 226 of the Constitution of India empowers the High Court to issue writs, including mandamus, to direct authorities to perform their legal duties.
judgment: The writ petition was filed seeking a direction to the police to register an FIR based on the petitioner's complaint alleging various IPC offenses. The petitioner argued that the police's inaction was illegal and arbitrary, and a violation of the guidelines in Lalita Kumari v. Govt. of Uttar Pradesh. The court was asked to direct the police to register the FIR. The case highlights the procedure for handling complaints and the role of the High Court in ensuring police action.

facts: The petitioner filed a writ petition seeking renewal of his passport, which was denied by the Regional Passport Office on the ground of a pending criminal case under Sections 406, 420, 506 r/w 34 of IPC. The petitioner sought renewal without reference to the pending criminal case.
charge: Denial of passport renewal due to a pending criminal case.
law: The Passports Act, 1967; Constitution of India, Article 226; Indian Penal Code, Sections 406, 420, 506.
law_content: Section 6(2)(f) of The Passports Act, 1967, permits refusal of a passport if an applicant is facing trial. However, Supreme Court precedent indicates that refusal is only justified in specific circumstances, such as conviction involving moral turpitude with a sentence of two years or more, or if an appeal is dismissed.
judgment: The High Court directed the Passport Authority to consider renewing the petitioner's passport without reference to the pending criminal case, citing Supreme Court judgments that limit the grounds for passport refusal when criminal cases are pending but no conviction or final order has been passed.

instruction: Summarize the facts, legal issue, provisions applied, and the High Court’s decision.
question: What did the High Court decide regarding Seeking regular bail for the petitioner/Accused No.3. under Sections 437 and 439 of the Code of Criminal Procedure, 1973, govern the granting of bail by Magistrate Courts and Courts of Session/High Courts, respectively. The specific sections of IPC, TSPSA, EXPLSA, and UAA detail the alleged offences.?
facts: The petitioner, accused No.3, has filed a criminal petition seeking regular bail. The alleged offences include sections of the IPC and the TSPSA, EXPLSA, and UAA. A significant point raised is that 90 days have passed without a charge sheet being filed, and the petitioner apprehends the police might seek an extension.
charge: Seeking regular bail for the petitioner/Accused No.3.
law: Sections 437 and 439 of Cr.P.C, IPC, TSPSA, EXPLSA, UAA
law_content: Sections 437 and 439 of the Code of Criminal Procedure, 1973, govern the granting of bail by Magistrate Courts and Courts of Session/High Courts, respectively. The specific sections of IPC, TSPSA, EXPLSA, and UAA detail the alleged offences.
judgment: The court observed that if an application for mandatory bail under Section 167(2) Cr.P.C is filed before the police file an extension application, the bail application shall be considered and disposed of on the same day. The criminal petition is disposed of with this observation.

facts: The petitioner/de facto complainant filed a criminal revision case challenging a judgment of acquittal passed by the Magistrate for offences under Section 498-A of the Indian Penal Code and Sections 3 and 4 of the Dowry Prohibition Act. The respondents were the State and the accused.

law_content: Section 397 and 401 CrPC (used for filing the revision) and Section 378 CrPC (governing appeals against acquittal).
judgment: The High Court dismissed the criminal revision case as not maintainable, stating that in cases of acquittal, if the complainant-victim is aggrieved, an appeal must be filed before the Sessions Court under Section 378 of the CrPC. The court noted that a criminal revision is not the appropriate remedy in such circumstances.

question: What did the High Court decide regarding Challenge to the conditions imposed by the Single Judge while quashing the Look Out Circular (LOC). under IPC Sections 420 (cheating), 406 (criminal breach of trust), 506 (criminal intimidation) read with 120B (criminal conspiracy); Section 41A CrPC (notice of appearance before police officer); Article 226 of the Constitution (writ jurisdiction for enforcement of fundamental rights).?
facts: The appellant, engaged in cosmetics manufacturing, filed a complaint leading to an FIR for offenses under IPC Sections 420, 406, 506 read with 120B. A charge sheet was filed. The appellant sought quashing of the LOC which was issued to restrict his movement. He was detained at the airport and released. The appellant's petition to travel abroad was closed as premature by the trial court, and his representation to authorities yielded no response, prompting a writ petition. The Single Judge quashed the LOC subject to certain conditions, which the appellant is challenging in this intra-court appeal.
charge: Challenge to the conditions imposed by the Single Judge while quashing the Look Out Circular (LOC).
law: Indian Penal Code, 1860; Code of Criminal Procedure, 1973; Constitution of India, 1950 (Article 226)
law_content: IPC Sections 420 (cheating), 406 (criminal breach of trust), 506 (criminal intimidation) read with 120B (criminal conspiracy); Section 41A CrPC (notice of appearance before police officer); Article 226 of the Constitution (writ jurisdiction for enforcement of fundamental rights).
judgment: The appellant contests the conditions imposed by the Single Judge, arguing they are not contemplated under the CrPC and that the Single Judge exceeded powers under Article 226 by imposing them, as only the trial court could impose such conditions. The Deputy Solicitor General supported the Single Judge's order. The court is considering the rival submissions and the record.

question: What did the High Court decide regarding Conviction under Sections 302 and 498-A IPC. under Section 302 IPC - Punishment for murder. Section 498-A IPC - Husband or relative of husband of a woman subjecting her to cruelty.?
facts: The appellant was convicted under Sections 302 and 498-A of the IPC for the death of his wife. The prosecution's case was that the appellant, after a quarrel, poured kerosene on his wife and set her on fire. The deceased, in her dying declaration, stated that the appellant was responsible for her death and had affairs with another woman. The appellant appealed this conviction.
charge: Conviction under Sections 302 and 498-A IPC.
law_content: Section 302 IPC - Punishment for murder. Section 498-A IPC - Husband or relative of husband of a woman subjecting her to cruelty.
judgment: The appeal was allowed, and the conviction and sentence were set aside. The court found that the dying declaration was not sufficient on its own to convict the appellant, especially considering the lack of corroboration and the inconsistencies in the evidence.

question: What did the High Court decide regarding Quashing of proceedings in FIR No. 63 of 2016 and stay of coercive steps. under Section 482 Cr.P.C. - Saving of inherent powers of High Court. This section allows the High Court to make such orders as may be necessary to give effect to any order under this Code, or to prevent abuse of the process of any Court or otherwise to secure the ends of justice. The court can quash proceedings if it is found that they are an abuse of the process of court or to secure the ends of justice. Section 41-A Cr.P.C. relates to notice of appearance before police officer, which mandates police officers to issue a notice to the accused to appear before them for the purpose of investigation if the accused is not arrested.?
facts: The petitioner, accused No. 4 in FIR No. 63 of 2016 registered at PS Medchal, filed a Criminal Petition under Section 482 of Cr.P.C. seeking to quash the proceedings and stay any coercive steps against him. The case involves alleged offences under Sections 406, 420, 419, 468, 471 read with Section 120(b) of the Indian Penal Code.
charge: Quashing of proceedings in FIR No. 63 of 2016 and stay of coercive steps.
law_content: Section 482 Cr.P.C. - Saving of inherent powers of High Court. This section allows the High Court to make such orders as may be necessary to give effect to any order under this Code, or to prevent abuse of the process of any Court or otherwise to secure the ends of justice. The court can quash proceedings if it is found that they are an abuse of the process of court or to secure the ends of justice. Section 41-A Cr.P.C. relates to notice of appearance before police officer, which mandates police officers to issue a notice to the accused to appear before them for the purpose of investigation if the accused is not arrested.
judgment: The High Court, considering that the prescribed punishment for the alleged offences is less than seven years, directed the petitioner to appear before the Investigating Officer on a specified date and time. The Investigating Officer was directed to follow the procedure under Section 41-A Cr.P.C. and the guidelines in Arnesh Kumar v. State of Bihar. No coercive steps were to be taken against the petitioner until the investigation is completed, provided the petitioner cooperates and provides necessary documents. The Criminal Petition was disposed of with these directions.

facts: The petitioner, Accused No.8, sought anticipatory bail under Section 438 Cr.P.C. in connection with a case registered under the NDPS Act. The prosecution's case involved the seizure of Nitravet tablets from other accused, whose confessions implicated the petitioner. The petitioner claimed innocence, stating no contraband was recovered from him and that he was a contract employee.
charge: Grant of anticipatory bail under Section 438 Cr.P.C. to Accused No.8.

judgment: The petition was allowed. The court held that confessions recorded under Section 67 of the NDPS Act are inadmissible in evidence, as per the Supreme Court's decision in Toofan Singh v. State of Tamilnadu. Since the only material connecting the petitioner to the crime was the inadmissible confession of co-accused, anticipatory bail was granted.

facts: The petitioners/accused are challenging proceedings initiated on a complaint alleging offences under Section 498-A, 406 IPC and Sections 4 and 6 of the Dowry Prohibition Act. The alleged incidents took place outside India, in the USA.
charge: To quash the C.C.No. 412014 on the file of the XV Addl. Chief Metropolitan Magistrate, Nampally, Hyderabad.
law: The Code of Criminal Procedure (Cr.P.C.), Indian Penal Code (IPC), Dowry Prohibition Act
law_content: Section 482 of Cr.P.C. – Saving of inherent powers of High Court to make orders necessary to give effect to any order under this Code, or to prevent abuse of the process of any Court or otherwise to secure the ends of justice. Section 188 of Cr.P.C. – Offence committed outside India.
judgment: The Criminal Petition is filed seeking to quash proceedings for offences under Section 498-A, 406 IPC and Dowry Prohibition Act. A key contention is that the alleged incidents occurred outside India, questioning the jurisdiction without prior sanction as per Section 188 of Cr.P.C.

instruction: Summarize the facts, legal issue, provisions applied, and the High Court’s decision.
question: What did the High Court decide regarding Conviction under Section 302 and 379 of IPC. under Section 302 IPC - Punishment for murder; Section 379 IPC - Punishment for theft.?
facts: The appellant was convicted for the offense under Section 302 of IPC and sentenced to life imprisonment. The prosecution's case was that the deceased, Anke Jeyamma, a daily wage laborer, left her house to pay house tax and never returned. Her decomposed body was found, appearing to have been strangled, with missing ornaments. The accused was arrested and confessed to the murder and theft of ornaments. Evidence from PWs 4 and 5, who last saw the deceased with the accused, and the recovery of ornaments formed the basis of the conviction.
charge: Conviction under Section 302 and 379 of IPC.
law_content: Section 302 IPC - Punishment for murder; Section 379 IPC - Punishment for theft.
judgment: The appeal was allowed, and the conviction and sentence were set aside.

instruction: Summarize the facts, legal issue, provisions applied, and the High Court’s decision.
question: What did the High Court decide regarding Quashing of criminal proceedings under Section 482 Cr.P.C. under Section 482 Cr.P.C. empowers the High Court to make orders to secure the ends of justice or prevent abuse of process of any Court. Sections 420, 468, 471, 447, and 506 IPC deal with cheating, forgery, using forged documents, criminal trespass, and criminal intimidation respectively. Section 34 IPC deals with acts done by several persons in furtherance of common intention. Section 156 Cr.P.C. deals with the police officer's power to investigate cognizable cases. The court also referred to guidelines from Arnesh Kumar v. State of Bihar regarding procedure for arrest.?
facts: The petitioners, accused Nos. 3 and 4, sought to quash the proceedings against them in Crime No. 34 of 2023 registered at Nagole Police Station. The alleged offences are punishable under Sections 420, 468, 471, 447, and 506 read with Section 34 of the Indian Penal Code, and Section 156 of the Criminal Procedure Code.
charge: Quashing of criminal proceedings under Section 482 Cr.P.C.
law: Code of Criminal Procedure, 1973 (Cr.P.C.) and Indian Penal Code, 1860 (IPC)
law_content: Section 482 Cr.P.C. empowers the High Court to make orders to secure the ends of justice or prevent abuse of process of any Court. Sections 420, 468, 471, 447, and 506 IPC deal with cheating, forgery, using forged documents, criminal trespass, and criminal intimidation respectively. Section 34 IPC deals with acts done by several persons in furtherance of common intention. Section 156 Cr.P.C. deals with the police officer's power to investigate cognizable cases. The court also referred to guidelines from Arnesh Kumar v. State of Bihar regarding procedure for arrest.
judgment: The High Court directed the petitioners to appear before the Investigating Officer on or before 08.02.2024 between 02:00 p.m and 04:00 p.m. The Investigating Officer was directed to follow the procedure laid down under Section 41-A Cr.P.C. and the guidelines in Arnesh Kumar v. State of Bihar. No coercive steps shall be taken against the petitioners until the investigation is completed.

instruction: Summarize the facts, legal issue, provisions applied, and the High Court’s decision.
question: What did the High Court decide regarding Quashing of charge sheet and dispensing with appearance of certain accused. under Section 482 Cr.P.C. is invoked to seek quashing of proceedings. Sections 326, 323, 504, and 506 IPC deal with voluntarily causing grievous hurt, voluntarily causing hurt, intentional insult, and criminal intimidation, respectively. Section 34 IPC deals with acts done by several persons in furtherance of common intention.?
facts: The petitioners, accused Nos. 1 to 6, sought to quash the charge sheet in C.C.No. 238 of 2020 pending before the Additional Judicial First Class Magistrate at Sangareddy. The alleged offences are under Sections 326, 323, 504, 506 R/w 34 IPC.
charge: Quashing of charge sheet and dispensing with appearance of certain accused.
law: Code of Criminal Procedure, 1973 (Cr.P.C.) and Indian Penal Code, 1860 (IPC)
law_content: Section 482 Cr.P.C. is invoked to seek quashing of proceedings. Sections 326, 323, 504, and 506 IPC deal with voluntarily causing grievous hurt, voluntarily causing hurt, intentional insult, and criminal intimidation, respectively. Section 34 IPC deals with acts done by several persons in furtherance of common intention.
judgment: The High Court dispensed with the appearance of petitioners/Accused Nos. 2, 3, and 6 before the trial court, except when their presence is specifically required. They are to be represented by their counsel. The Criminal Petition was disposed of with this direction.

instruction: Summarize the facts, legal issue, provisions applied, and the High Court’s decision.
question: What did the High Court decide regarding Quashing of FIR proceedings and stay of further proceedings. under Section 482 Cr.P.C. allows the High Court to pass any order necessary to give effect to any order under the Code or to prevent abuse of the process of any Court or otherwise to secure the ends of justice. Sections 323 (voluntarily causing hurt), 290 (public nuisance), and 506 (criminal intimidation) of IPC, and Section 3(1)(x)(s) of the SC/ST Act concerning atrocities.?
facts: The petitioner, an accused in FIR No. 1201 of 2023 registered at Jawaharnagar Police Station, sought to quash the proceedings against him. The FIR was registered for alleged offences under Sections 323, 290, and 506 of the Indian Penal Code and Section 3(1)(x)(s) of the Scheduled Castes and Scheduled Tribes (Prevention of Atrocities) Act. The petitioner also sought a stay of further proceedings.
charge: Quashing of FIR proceedings and stay of further proceedings.
law: Code of Criminal Procedure, 1973; Indian Penal Code, 1860; Scheduled Castes and Scheduled Tribes (Prevention of Atrocities) Act, 1989
law_content: Section 482 Cr.P.C. allows the High Court to pass any order necessary to give effect to any order under the Code or to prevent abuse of the process of any Court or otherwise to secure the ends of justice. Sections 323 (voluntarily causing hurt), 290 (public nuisance), and 506 (criminal intimidation) of IPC, and Section 3(1)(x)(s) of the SC/ST Act concerning atrocities.
judgment: The Court directed the petitioner to appear before the Investigating Officer and instructed the officer to follow the procedure laid down under Section 41-A Cr.P.C. and the guidelines from Arnesh Kumar v. State of Bihar. The petitioner was also directed to cooperate with the investigation. The criminal petition was disposed of with these directions.

instruction: Summarize the facts, legal issue, provisions applied, and the High Court’s decision.
question: What did the High Court decide regarding Withdrawal of a criminal appeal. under Section 378(a) of Cr.P.C. pertains to appeals in cases of acquittal. The appeal was filed under this section challenging a judgment. The court allowed the withdrawal of the criminal appeal.?
facts: The appellant filed a criminal appeal challenging a judgment passed by the Special Magistrate. During the hearing, the appellant's counsel sought permission to withdraw the appeal as they had no instructions, while also seeking liberty to pursue other remedies.
charge: Withdrawal of a criminal appeal.
law_content: Section 378(a) of Cr.P.C. pertains to appeals in cases of acquittal. The appeal was filed under this section challenging a judgment. The court allowed the withdrawal of the criminal appeal.
judgment: The criminal appeal was dismissed as withdrawn with liberty granted to the appellant to work out other available remedies.
